headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good morning. My name is Brent, and I will be your conference operator today. At this time I would like to welcome everyone to the UHS Fourth Quarter 2015 and Year-end Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] Thank you. And I'd like to turn the c
componenttext: Good morning. My name is Brent, and I will be your conference operator today. At this time I would like to welcome everyone to the UHS Fourth Quarter 2015 and Year-end Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] Thank you. And I'd like to turn the call over to Steve Filton, CFO. Please go ahead.

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Brent. Good morning. Alan Miller, our CEO, is also joining us this morning. Welcome to this review of Universal Health Services results for the full year and fourth quarter ended December 31, 2015. During the conference call, Alan and I will
componenttext:
Thank you, Brent. Good morning. Alan Miller, our CEO, is also joining us this morning. Welcome to this review of Universal Health Services results for the full year and fourth quarter ended December 31, 2015. 
During the conference call, Alan and I will be using words such as believes, expects, anticipates, estimates and similar words that represent forecasts, projections and forward-looking statements. For anyone not familiar with the risks and uncertainties inherent in these forward-looking statements, I recommend a careful reading of the section on risk factors and forward-looking statements and risk factors in our Form 10-K for the year ended December 31, 2015. 
We would like to highlight just a couple of developments and business trends before opening the call up to questions.
As discussed in our press release last night, the company recorded net income attributable to UHS per diluted share of $6.76 for the year and $1.74 for the quarter. After adjusting for the incentive income and expenses associated with the implementation of electronic health records applications at our acute care hospitals as well as the other items attributable to last year's fourth quarter as disclosed on the Supplemental Schedule included with last night's earnings release, adjusted net income attributable to UHS increased approximately 12% to $170.7 million or $1.71 per diluted share for the quarter ended December 31, 2015, as compared to $152 million or $1.51 per diluted share during the fourth quarter of 2014.
On a same-facility basis, revenues in our behavioral health division increased 3.6% during the fourth quarter of 2015. Adjusted admissions and adjusted patient days to our behavioral health facilities owned for more than a year increased 0.2% and 0.7%, respectively, during the fourth quarter of 2015. Revenue per adjusted patient day rose 2.5% during the fourth quarter of 2015 over the comparable prior year quarter. We define operating margins as operating income or net revenues, less salaries, wages and benefits, other operating expenses and supplies expense, divided by net revenues. Operating margins for our behavioral health hospitals owned for more than a year were 27.1% and 27.9% during the quarters ended December 31, 2015 and '14, respectively. 
On a same-facility basis, in our acute care division, revenues increased 7.3% during the fourth quarter of 2015. Adjusted admissions increased 4.8%, while revenue per adjusted admission increased 3.3%. On a same-facility basis, operating margins for our acute care hospitals increased to 17.2% during the fourth quarter of 2015 as compared to 16.8% during the fourth quarter of 2014. 
Our cash generated from operating activities was $1.021 billion during 2015 as compared to $1.036 billion during 2014. This small decrease is primarily attributable to $199 million unfavorable change in working capital accounts experienced during 2015 as compared to 2014, resulting mainly from the timing of disbursements.
Our accounts receivable days outstanding decreased to 52 days during the fourth quarter of 2015 as compared to 54 days during the fourth quarter of 2014. At December 31, 2015, our ratio of debt-to-total capitalization was 45%. We spent $110 million on capital expenditures during the fourth quarter of 2015 and $379 million during the full year of 2015. During 2016, we expect to spend approximately $400 million to $425 million on capital expenditures, which include expenditures for capital equipment, renovations, new projects at existing hospitals and construction of new facilities.
In conjunction with our share repurchase program that commenced during the third quarter of 2014, during the fourth quarter of 2015, we repurchased 478,000 shares of our stock at a cost of $58 million. Subsequent to December 31, 2015, we purchased an additional 887,000 shares at an aggregate cost of $99 million. $77 million remains on the previous authorization, and yesterday, our Board of Directors approved an additional $400 million in share repurchases. Our estimated range of adjusted net income attributable to UHS for the year ended December 31, 2016 is $7.12 to $7.58 per diluted share. This guidance range excludes the unfavorable $0.17 per diluted share of EHR impact expected during 2016, as described in our press release. This guidance range represents an increase of approximately 4% to 10% over the adjusted net income attributable to UHS of $6.87 per diluted share for the year ended December 31, 2015, as calculated on the Supplemental Schedule included in last night's press release.
During 2016, our net revenues are estimated to be approximately $9.75 billion to $9.85 billion, representing an increase of approximately 8% to 9% over 2015 net revenues. 
We are pleased to answer your questions at this time.

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] Your first question comes from the line of A.J. Rice with UBS.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Your first question comes from the line of A.J. Rice with UBS.

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Maybe just to drill down a little further on the components of the 2016 guidance, Steve. Possibly, can you give us any commentary around your thoughts on revenue or EBITDAR growth by segment? And are there any other items in there that impact the guidance
componenttext: Maybe just to drill down a little further on the components of the 2016 guidance, Steve. Possibly, can you give us any commentary around your thoughts on revenue or EBITDAR growth by segment? And are there any other items in there that impact the guidance like acquisitions, further share buybacks or new development that we should think about?

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, A.J. So I think we've been fairly transparent over the course of last few months in talking about our outlook for next year. In terms of the 2 segments, I think, on the acute side, we see revenue growth of about 6% next year in the acute division, s
componenttext: Okay, A.J. So I think we've been fairly transparent over the course of last few months in talking about our outlook for next year. In terms of the 2 segments, I think, on the acute side, we see revenue growth of about 6% next year in the acute division, same-store. On the behavioral side, probably a little bit lower, maybe 5%. I think the acute care 6% is split fairly evenly between price and volume. And I think the behavioral 5% is percentage probably weighted a little more towards volume rather than to price. And I think in both divisions, we expect margins to increase slightly if we can achieve those revenue growth levels. In terms of unusual items or other things that are sort of not included in what I just went through, we have talked, for many quarters now, that we will be opening a new sixth acute care hospital in Las Vegas. We estimate that to occur in the beginning of the fourth quarter of 2016. That's probably a $5 million to $10 million EBITDA drag on the back half of next year as we have preopening and then -- preopening costs and startup losses. And it's probably a bit more of a drag at the net income line as the depreciation and interest associated with that facility comes online. We'll probably lose a few million dollars next year on the foreign exchange impact in U.K. We probably will lose a few million dollars on a decline in, what we call, special Medicaid reimbursement monies, which will be UPL and disproportionate share on provider taxes. And I think the only other sort of probably noteworthy item about our guidance is that as has always been our historical practice, we assume that our free cash flow is dedicated to the repayment of debt. And all -- the only sort of share repurchase or other deployment of capital that we build into our guidance and build into our model is that, which has already occurred. And so I think it's a fairly conservative way of thinking about 2016 capital deployment because repayment of debt at the moment is the least accretive of all of our capital deployment options.

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: And on that last point, I would assume you're including the $99 million you've purchased to date? Or is that not included in guidance year-to-date this year?
componenttext: And on that last point, I would assume you're including the $99 million you've purchased to date? Or is that not included in guidance year-to-date this year?

componenttextpreview: That is included.
componenttext: That is included.

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. Maybe my follow-up will be just so you're assuming that you get a rebound in the psych revenues, so your long-term target of at least 5%, obviously, the last 2 quarters, you've been a little bit below that. Can you comment on a little more? I know y
componenttext: Okay. Maybe my follow-up will be just so you're assuming that you get a rebound in the psych revenues, so your long-term target of at least 5%, obviously, the last 2 quarters, you've been a little bit below that. Can you comment on a little more? I know you've talked about some shortages in clinicians. Is that still the primary driver? And how quick can that be addressed?

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I mean, I would point out, A.J., that I think one of the drivers of the somewhat softer behavioral revenues in Q4 was a pretty difficult comparison to last year, particularly on the volume side. I think same-store admissions, behavioral admissions in
componenttext: Yes. I mean, I would point out, A.J., that I think one of the drivers of the somewhat softer behavioral revenues in Q4 was a pretty difficult comparison to last year, particularly on the volume side. I think same-store admissions, behavioral admissions in the fourth quarter of last year were up 6.8%. And so I think we always knew that was going be a tough nut to compare to in the fourth quarter of 2015. Additionally, as you alluded to, we have talked in the last quarter or 2 about the fact that in some of our markets, and I think the national data is supportive of this as well, we're facing a shortage, to some degree, of psychiatrists in many cases and, in some cases, nursing and other clinical professionals. And again, in some markets, that's causing us to not be able to treat all the patients who present themselves for admission, and it mutes our volume and, ultimately, our revenue numbers in some of those markets. We feel like the 5% number that I have identified as being our embedded in our guidance, revenue guidance, for next year, is absolutely achievable. We are working our way through the shortages in many of these markets. The comparisons certainly become easier as the year goes on. Next year, I would suggest that, that 5% may be a little bit back-end-loaded as we work through the comparisons and work through some of the clinical shortages. But I think we feel like the number is eminently achievable.

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: A.J., it's about how we put together the guidance, et cetera, and all of the charges we have as we go through it. I want to point out that Anderson Hospital, which will open, as you mentioned, in the fourth quarter, will cost us in the short run, obviousl
componenttext: A.J., it's about how we put together the guidance, et cetera, and all of the charges we have as we go through it. I want to point out that Anderson Hospital, which will open, as you mentioned, in the fourth quarter, will cost us in the short run, obviously. But Temecula Hospital, which we opened a couple of years ago, has been running well low ahead of budget. So we've made some pretty good investments.

componenttext: Yes, I know. I mean, Las Vegas is a market that keeps on giving, I guess, for you guys as in Southern California, too, to some degree.

componenttext: Just want to go into the acute care side of things and the margins. I guess, this is the second quarter of 7% type growth and margin contraction. Just want to see if you go through some of the issues. Is it the same issues that were impacting Q3 margins that were impacting Q4? And why do you feel comfortable that margins are going to be up next year or this year?

componenttext: So I'm not sure where the commentary on margin contraction comes from, Kevin. I mean, in my remarks, I pointed out that on a same-facility basis, acute care margins were 17.2% in the fourth quarter of '15 versus 16.8% in the fourth quarter of '14. So...

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, I'm sorry. I guess, the issues that you talked about in Q3 then, have they been addressed in Q4?
componenttext: Okay, I'm sorry. I guess, the issues that you talked about in Q3 then, have they been addressed in Q4?

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I think we had clinical shortages, personnel shortages on the acute in Q3, as did some of our peers. And what we said at the time was that we thought we could hire enough permanent nurses to generally overcome most of the problem. We thought that we'
componenttext: Yes. I think we had clinical shortages, personnel shortages on the acute in Q3, as did some of our peers. And what we said at the time was that we thought we could hire enough permanent nurses to generally overcome most of the problem. We thought that we'd make progress in the fourth quarter and continue to make progress into the first part of 2016. And I think that's the way it shaped up. We definitely made progress in Q4, and I think we'll mix of further progress in the first half of '16.

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: And the, I guess, the bad debt spiked in Q3. I guess, it was up year-over-year in Q4 but down sequentially from where you were. Can talk a little bit about the trends there?
componenttext: And the, I guess, the bad debt spiked in Q3. I guess, it was up year-over-year in Q4 but down sequentially from where you were. Can talk a little bit about the trends there?

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I mean, so I think what you're looking at the uncompensated care numbers, and they are certainly up in Q4, that's almost always going to be the case simply as a function of pricing because of the way we calculate that. Our uninsured admission growth
componenttext: Yes. I mean, so I think what you're looking at the uncompensated care numbers, and they are certainly up in Q4, that's almost always going to be the case simply as a function of pricing because of the way we calculate that. Our uninsured admission growth in Q4 actually slowed a little bit. In Q3, our uninsured admission growth was tracking ahead of our overall admission growth. And that trend reversed itself in Q4 where our -- while our overall uninsured admissions were up. They were up slightly slower than our overall admissions. So I think our payer mix seems to be settling in to a bit more of a stable environment in Q4. And again, I think we're just pleased, extremely pleased, that the overall, even after uncompensated care is included, 7-plus percent growth in acute care revenues in Q4.

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: And do you expect payer mix to be stable into 2016?
componenttext: And do you expect payer mix to be stable into 2016?

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: That's generally our expectation, to be fair. Payer mix is probably the most difficult sort of all the assumptions and all the metrics to predict. But our general sense is that the 2 items that have affected payer mix over the last few years, the ACA and
componenttext: That's generally our expectation, to be fair. Payer mix is probably the most difficult sort of all the assumptions and all the metrics to predict. But our general sense is that the 2 items that have affected payer mix over the last few years, the ACA and its favorable impact on improving payer mix. And we think that, that has been moderating over the last few years and will continue to moderate next year. And it's part of the reason why we think our acute care revenue growth moderates from the 8% or so in '15 to more like 6% in '16. And then the improving economies, I don't think we necessarily feel like our local market economies are improving as rapidly as they were in '14 and '15. But I think we feel like they certainly will remain stable in '16.

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Josh Raskin with Barclays.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Josh Raskin with Barclays.

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Steven, I think you might have alluded to this a little bit, but just a question broadly on labor cost. I think you mentioned on the psych side, still seeing more, I guess, on the physician, I guess, a little bit in nursing. But anything more broadly in t
componenttext: Steven, I think you might have alluded to this a little bit, but just a question broadly on labor cost. I think you mentioned on the psych side, still seeing more, I guess, on the physician, I guess, a little bit in nursing. But anything more broadly in terms of labor costs and more specifically on the acute care side?

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: I mean, I think what we said in Q3 vis-a-vis the acute care labor sort of situation was that we felt like our use of temporary nurses or registry nurses worse greater than it should be. That's a function, I think, of a number of things, including turnover
componenttext: I mean, I think what we said in Q3 vis-a-vis the acute care labor sort of situation was that we felt like our use of temporary nurses or registry nurses worse greater than it should be. That's a function, I think, of a number of things, including turnover rates that we'd like to drive somewhat lower, decisions that are made exactly when and how to hire permanent nurses, et cetera. And I think we generally attributed the increase in salary expense and the pressure on salary expense in Q3 to some inefficiencies in terms of not hiring as many permanent nurses as we needed to in Q3. And again, I think we felt like that was a transient problem that we could address. And as I was commenting to Kevin, I think we felt like we did address it in Q4. Clearly, the numbers got better. And I think our expectation is, frankly, they'll continue to improve into 2016.

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And you put contract labor in Other Expense, right? It's not in the SEB line, is that right?
componenttext: Okay. And you put contract labor in Other Expense, right? It's not in the SEB line, is that right?

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: So contract nurses are in the salary line. Contract physicians are in the Other Operating Expense line.
componenttext: So contract nurses are in the salary line. Contract physicians are in the Other Operating Expense line.

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then just a second question, just on the buybacks. You guys have been a little bit more active to start the year. Should we read into that in terms of anything around the M&A landscape or other uses? I mean, you guys obviously don't have a lever
componenttext: Okay. And then just a second question, just on the buybacks. You guys have been a little bit more active to start the year. Should we read into that in terms of anything around the M&A landscape or other uses? I mean, you guys obviously don't have a leverage issue in my opinion. So I'm sure you can do both. But I just want to make sure we shouldn't be reading into the environment or something like that.

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: So I think, Josh, we share your view that our leverage levels are such that we are flexible enough to do any number of things to respond to M&A opportunities as well as to be a share repurchaser of that if the market sort of dictates that. Our commentary
componenttext: So I think, Josh, we share your view that our leverage levels are such that we are flexible enough to do any number of things to respond to M&A opportunities as well as to be a share repurchaser of that if the market sort of dictates that. Our commentary in the last few quarters, and I would repeat it, I don't think it has changed in Q4, is that we think M&A landscape is still active for us on both sides of the business. We completed 2 reasonably sized behavioral deals in the back half of last year and continue to look at others into '16. We've commented that the landscape and the market for acute care deals that are, I think, more suitable in our minds for what has been historically our market profile of kind of more suburban, midsized urban markets, larger hospitals, larger hospital systems, seems more active. So it's always difficult to predict which of those deals or how many of those deals might ultimately prove to be actionable or executable. But we certainly feel like it is more active. But also, like many of you, I think, we have viewed the decline in our stock over the last couple of quarters as really not something that has been justified by the underlying fundamentals of the business, which we don't feel have changed very much over the last 6 months. And as a consequence, we feel that there's a degree of confidence in our underlying business and feel like the current valuations of our stock are compelling opportunity as well. And that's why we've become more active acquirer of shares as well. So I think, as you suggested, I think we're going -- given our balance sheet and our flexibility, we're going to pursue any and all of these opportunities that continue to make economic sense for us.

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Matthew Borsch with Goldman Sachs.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Matthew Borsch with Goldman Sachs.

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just first, soapbox comment, which, I guess, you've gotten before that we appreciate the fact that you don't waste 20, 25 minutes of your time and  our time reading through the press release and go right two questions. So let me ask about the bad debt tre
componenttext: Just first, soapbox comment, which, I guess, you've gotten before that we appreciate the fact that you don't waste 20, 25 minutes of your time and  our time reading through the press release and go right two questions. So let me ask about the bad debt trends recognizing that the strong acute revenue growth was more important than that. Can you give us any granularity? Last quarter, you talked about the South Texas market being an area where you saw an uptick in uncompensated care. Is that continuing? Or is there anything to spike out from there?

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: So Matt, I think, from a geographic perspective, we have said now, frankly, for several quarters, that if you look at our acute care results overall, the Las Vegas market, the Southern California market has generally been tracking sort of above the averag
componenttext: So Matt, I think, from a geographic perspective, we have said now, frankly, for several quarters, that if you look at our acute care results overall, the Las Vegas market, the Southern California market has generally been tracking sort of above the average acute care result. And I think that's true sort of across the board in terms of volumes and revenue and payer mix and bad debt. And we've said that the Texas market and markets, because we have multiple markets in Texas, have generally been lagging the average. And I think that was true in Q4. I'm not exactly sure why that is. Obviously, there is a great deal of focus and speculation that, that's oil and gas-related and driven. We tend not to be in markets that are directly impacted by the oil and gas business. So I'm not certain that, that's the main driver or the only driver for sure. But certainly, our Texas markets for the last several quarters have been underperforming the acute care average.

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: And one more question, if I could, on different topic. Amidst all the pressure on insurers, on the ACA exchange business, what are you generally seeing in terms of the dynamic for commercial rate negotiations, both as it relates to the business and genera
componenttext: And one more question, if I could, on different topic. Amidst all the pressure on insurers, on the ACA exchange business, what are you generally seeing in terms of the dynamic for commercial rate negotiations, both as it relates to the business and generally the larger core group businesses as well?

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. So let me address that, I think, both in terms of volume and price. And I'll make the comment, and I think we've been making this comment and expressing this view longer and probably more adamantly than some of our peers, Matt, as we've always found
componenttext: Yes. So let me address that, I think, both in terms of volume and price. And I'll make the comment, and I think we've been making this comment and expressing this view longer and probably more adamantly than some of our peers, Matt, as we've always found it difficult to precisely carve out our ACA experience and sort of separate out exactly what our ACA commercial experience and rates are versus our overall commercial experience. And I would say, we continue. And honestly, as the ACA has progressed and we're now well into our third year, I'd say, into our fourth year of it, I think that we find that even more difficult. But so my commentary is probably more about commercial rates just generally than about ACA rates, specifically. And that is, we don't see tremendous changes either in our rate of increase. I think our commercial rates of increase still average in the 6%, 6.5% range, varies, to some degree by contract, by market, but I think that's still our average. I don't think we're really seeing significant changes in other terms, in benefit plan design. We're not seeing an emphasis on narrow networks that I think we actually expected we would see more of, et cetera. So I think as we enter '16 and as we think about creating our model for '16, it is more of the same as much as anything.

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Ralph Giacobbe with Citi.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Ralph Giacobbe with Citi.

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just want to go back to the staffing shortages and maybe, more particularly, I think you mentioned psychiatrists. That doesn't sound overly transient, but maybe you could talk through the dynamics there, how you tend to sort of fix that and whether this i
componenttext: Just want to go back to the staffing shortages and maybe, more particularly, I think you mentioned psychiatrists. That doesn't sound overly transient, but maybe you could talk through the dynamics there, how you tend to sort of fix that and whether this is also an area of sort of higher wage pressure that we should expect on the behavioral side of the business so far.

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. So look, I think that your comment, Ralph, in the sense that I believe we're facing psychiatry shortages in specific markets because I think nationally, the data suggests that the number of new psychiatrists over the last decade have not kept up or
componenttext: Sure. So look, I think that your comment, Ralph, in the sense that I believe we're facing psychiatry shortages in specific markets because I think nationally, the data suggests that the number of new psychiatrists over the last decade have not kept up or have lagged the overall number of new doctors. So the percentage of psychiatrists is actually declining. And I agree with you. That is kind of a more structural issue. I believe the market tends to correct for that in that as the demand for psychiatrists increases, as psychiatrists' earnings increase, more and more people get attracted to the field. More and more practicing psychiatrists will choose to devote at least some of their hours to clinical activities rather than to academic or other activities. So I do think there is some market correction that goes on for all of this. In addition, I think -- and the trend, what my commentary about as being a transient problem, is really meant to imply that, I believe, we can pull levers in our markets to address the issue. We can more aggressively recruit for psychiatrists. We can bring psychiatrists into a market that has a shortage. Your comment that, that may cost us more money, and in fact, I think it does cost us more money if you look at one of the reasons I think that our behavioral margins have come under pressure is because the cost of acquiring psychiatrists has also gone up, in addition to there being some pressure on our volumes. And the other thing that I think we do in markets where the regulatory environment allows us to is we create physician extenders, nurses and other clinicians who can do some of the tasks that psychiatrists are sometimes asked to do. And that helps us as well in terms of not having enough psychiatrists. So we're doing all of those things and pulling all those levers and aggressively focused on the issue. And to some degree, I think our confidence that we are going to do those things better than some of our peers in our markets causes me to comment or to believe that this is a transient sort of issue that we can overcome.

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. But the behavioral revenue up 5%, we should think of an ability to still get to sort of EBITDA growth on a same-store basis of at least that 5% versus maybe a little bit more.
componenttext: Okay. But the behavioral revenue up 5%, we should think of an ability to still get to sort of EBITDA growth on a same-store basis of at least that 5% versus maybe a little bit more.

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: That's certainly what we have embedded in our guidance.
componenttext: That's certainly what we have embedded in our guidance.

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. All right. Fair enough. And then just quickly on the cute side. You've posted volume trends sort of well in excess of peers for several quarters now. I know you're in a sort of small subset of markets and have a little bit of smaller hospital base.
componenttext: Okay. All right. Fair enough. And then just quickly on the cute side. You've posted volume trends sort of well in excess of peers for several quarters now. I know you're in a sort of small subset of markets and have a little bit of smaller hospital base. But any sense of dynamics within your specific markets about whether you think all hospitals within your areas are seeing similar trends? Or do you think you're taking market share? Have you seen hospital closures? Just anything that stands out around the sort of disproportionately better volume trends you're seeing.

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think as your question suggests, Ralph, it's a combination of factors. We tended to be in markets that were disproportionately hurt by the recession and had higher unemployment rates. I think that a number of sell side folks did analyses during the rece
componenttext: I think as your question suggests, Ralph, it's a combination of factors. We tended to be in markets that were disproportionately hurt by the recession and had higher unemployment rates. I think that a number of sell side folks did analyses during the recession of where unemployment was the highest. And when they compared the public companies, I think we often fared the worst during the sort of height of the recession in places like Las Vegas and Southern California, South Florida, South Texas. But what we suggested at that time, and we believed, was when the economy recovered and when those local market economies recovered, we would benefit disproportionately from those recoveries. And I think that has certainly been an element of what has happened over the course of the last few years. As Las Vegas has come, I would suggest roaring back. We really benefited from that, for example. But I think we also believe that in many of our markets, we are aggressively increasing our market share. Both Alan and I mentioned the fact that a big California market, which is Riverside County. We built a new hospital several years ago in the Las Vegas market. We're building a new hospital to open later this year. We continue to take those very obvious actions and other not-so-obvious actions to cement, enhance and increase our market share in most of our acute care markets. And I think we have done that fairly successfully over the last few years as well. So I think both of those dynamics are at play when you see the really robust and industry-leading acute care revenue growth that we've been putting up.

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Gary Lieberman with Wells Fargo.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Gary Lieberman with Wells Fargo.

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is Ryan on for Gary. I was hoping you could drill more into your behavioral revenue growth guidance. The 5% is towards the low end, I guess, of your past ranges and certainly below where you've grown in recent past. So I thought I was hoping maybe yo
componenttext: This is Ryan on for Gary. I was hoping you could drill more into your behavioral revenue growth guidance. The 5% is towards the low end, I guess, of your past ranges and certainly below where you've grown in recent past. So I thought I was hoping maybe you could just provide a little more color on the reimbursement environment. And what makes you sort of a little cautious on that outlook?

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure, Ryan. So actually, I think, as sort of the conversation and commentary has been so far in the call, the issue for us is not so much caution about the pricing environment, which, I think, actually has been fairly healthy. And I think even if you look
componenttext: Sure, Ryan. So actually, I think, as sort of the conversation and commentary has been so far in the call, the issue for us is not so much caution about the pricing environment, which, I think, actually has been fairly healthy. And I think even if you look at Q4, the 2.5% pricing growth on our revenue per day in behavioral is, quite frankly, as good as that and a little better than we expected. So that, I don't think, is the concern going into or the caution going into 2016. I think what we -- the caution is some of the volume pressures that we've seen over the last few quarters. And I think those volume pressures are manifested in a few different areas. The area that we talked about the most historically and certainly over the last few quarters has been length-of-stay compression, that even when we were posing really strong admission growth, length-of-stay compression was muting or diminishing that growth to a degree. I think the length-of-stay pressure is starting to alleviate some. And so we're hopeful that, that will continue. But the admissions office that we've seen as a result of again, 2 things. Very difficult comparisons in the beginning of '16, that, I think, clouds some of our guidance for the year; and then some of the issues we've had over the clinician shortages of we been talking about. And while, as I've said in my previous commentary, I think we can address those, it may take a quarter or 2. So I think that's really what has caused us to be a little more muted about our behavioral revenue growth. And obviously, in the long term, we think that the tailwinds for behavioral revenue growth have a lot of potential. We haven't really talked in this call about the potential for the IND exclusion being partially or fully lifted. But we believe that will occur. And when it does, that will provide an opportunity for sort of another step-up in behavioral volumes that we're likely to see not so much in '16, but in '17 and thereafter.

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, that's very helpful. And then my second question. If you take a look at your segment EBITDAR on a same-store basis, I realized there was some margin pressure on the behavioral side. But just even on a year-over-year EBITDAR growth basis, it looked l
componenttext: Okay, that's very helpful. And then my second question. If you take a look at your segment EBITDAR on a same-store basis, I realized there was some margin pressure on the behavioral side. But just even on a year-over-year EBITDAR growth basis, it looked like combined, the segments were up nicely. But then comparing that with the consolidated EBITDAR, the growth year-over-year wasn't as much. So I was just wondering if there's anything on non-same-store basis or on a corporate overhead basis that I should be thinking about. Or am I not thinking about this correctly?

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: I mean, there's nothing that really stands out, Ryan. I will make a comment that we did have a favorable malpractice adjustment last year. And I know just from talking to some analysts last night that not everybody was taking that into account. So I would
componenttext: I mean, there's nothing that really stands out, Ryan. I will make a comment that we did have a favorable malpractice adjustment last year. And I know just from talking to some analysts last night that not everybody was taking that into account. So I would just ask people to go back and make sure they -- we, if you will, equalized that adjustment in our Supplemental Schedule. So I would just sort of ask everybody to focus on making sure they've done that. I think, other than that, I can't think of any really significant changes, other than as we disclosed last year, we acquired an insurance company, insurance product in our acute care division last year. That's been a little bit of a drag, although I don't think it's a huge deal mover.

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Ana Gupte with Leerink.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Ana Gupte with Leerink.

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Again, coming back to bad debt, you have improved your bad debt pretty nicely, I think, sequentially. And in the third quarter, a lot of the companies had issues. For the most part, there's been some improvement into the fourth quarter. There was speculat
componenttext: Again, coming back to bad debt, you have improved your bad debt pretty nicely, I think, sequentially. And in the third quarter, a lot of the companies had issues. For the most part, there's been some improvement into the fourth quarter. There was speculation around exchanges. I think the ACA talked about Medicaid application processing and communities, taken that write-down on collectibility of the consumer cautionary piece of it. Was this just a spike and a blip in the third quarter? And do you feel like kind of the woods and so we should look at your bad debt flat now into 2016, taking the baseline from 4Q? Or are there any uncertainties as you look at a revenue cycle management and you to what happened there?

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. So to be perfectly candid, I think we struggled in Q3 with explaining the increase in uncompensated volumes. As you suggest, some of our peers offered explanations that included some level of disenrollment in the exchanges, as exchange participants
componenttext: Sure. So to be perfectly candid, I think we struggled in Q3 with explaining the increase in uncompensated volumes. As you suggest, some of our peers offered explanations that included some level of disenrollment in the exchanges, as exchange participants found their previous going up, or they suggested that maybe some exchange participants had sort of gamed the system and enrolled to get certain care but then disenrolled when they got that care. Those explanations seemed reasonable, and we can sort of find of anecdotal examples within our own experiences to support those explanations, but don't really have the sort of vast database to really be able to validate them in any sort of pervasive our comprehensive way. And I think our fourth quarter experience would suggest that even if those explanations were valid in Q3, they didn't necessarily extend into Q4. The other sort of question you asked about, which, I think, we certainly would concur with the experience, I mean, we have seen that as the ACA has been implemented and as exchange plans have become more prevalent and many of them have sort of high deductible, high coinsurance components to them, that the level of -- or the amount of the bill due from the patient has gone up. And as a consequence, the level of bad debt on that portion of the bill has also gone up. We believe that our accounting for that change has been sort of real-time and current all along and has been reflected over the course of the last several years in our current results. So I don't feel like we feel like there's any sort of catch-up required in the way that we're recognizing that phenomena for financial statement purposes.

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, that's very helpful. And on the volume, just coming back to the acute care volume. I think it sounds like you're saying to an earlier question that it was more secular growth than share shifting from other players in the markets that you're in. As y
componenttext: Okay, that's very helpful. And on the volume, just coming back to the acute care volume. I think it sounds like you're saying to an earlier question that it was more secular growth than share shifting from other players in the markets that you're in. As you saw the 4Q trends on both volumes and on acuity and then coming into the first quarter, anything you're seeing in the first quarter relative to the fourth quarter from a seasonality perspective or the acuity or types of procedures and services that would tell us what the drivers of that volume growth is?

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. So just to go back, Ana, I would say that what -- my answer before was really meant to say that I think our acute care revenues, in general, are benefiting from both the improvement in our end market economies as well as the ACA benefit. And honestly
componenttext: Yes. So just to go back, Ana, I would say that what -- my answer before was really meant to say that I think our acute care revenues, in general, are benefiting from both the improvement in our end market economies as well as the ACA benefit. And honestly, I think, sometimes, it's difficult for us to distinguish precisely between the two. And market share gains as well. So again, I think one of those dynamics are contributing. In terms of, I think, sort of forward-looking into just the early part of '16, I think -- and I think most of the surveys have sort of suggested this, that the end of '15 and the beginning of January were sort of slow from a volume perspective on the acute side. I think that may be attributable to the fact that it was a late starting and relatively slow flu season. But I would say, over the course of the last 6 weeks from the middle of January to the end of February, acute care activity, at least, at our hospitals, seems to be pretty robust and certainly doesn't give us any pause about being able to continue to achieve the numbers that we identified before.

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: One final question. On the IND exclusion, there was an very recent news flow last week that CMS sent this to the Office of Management and Budget. Were there any changes or markups from the behavioral hospital industry and/or managed Medicaid in the versio
componenttext: One final question. On the IND exclusion, there was an very recent news flow last week that CMS sent this to the Office of Management and Budget. Were there any changes or markups from the behavioral hospital industry and/or managed Medicaid in the version that come there relative to what you saw last May?

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: We believe that the version, particularly in terms of the provisions that are most relevant to us, remains intact, and viewed the news item that you point out as a good one and a positive one in the sense that even though the process is moving albeit a li
componenttext: We believe that the version, particularly in terms of the provisions that are most relevant to us, remains intact, and viewed the news item that you point out as a good one and a positive one in the sense that even though the process is moving albeit a little bit slower than we would like, it is moving. And as I was saying before, I think we expect that pending CMS rule to be issued sometime this year. And we would hope that the effective date would be no later than the beginning of next year. And that would provide a tailwind for our behavioral business and our behavioral volumes going into next year.

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: We didn't. We didn't get that specific question. The U.K. commentary over the last few quarters has been that both our original Cygnet acquisition as well as our subsequent Alpha acquisition and our smaller one-offs and new beds are really generally doing
componenttext: We didn't. We didn't get that specific question. The U.K. commentary over the last few quarters has been that both our original Cygnet acquisition as well as our subsequent Alpha acquisition and our smaller one-offs and new beds are really generally doing quite well. Occupancy rates for our U.K. behavioral hospitals, on average, are in the low 90s. And we continue to look for further expansion opportunities and the ability to grow that platform in U.K., which we're continuing to remain very enthusiastic about.

componenttext: Do you think their review of the priority transaction, the transaction with the priority group, do you think that would provide some opportunities for one-off facility pickups?

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Obviously, it's hard for me to answer that question because I think it's a function of: A, what the Trade Commission in the U.K. decides to do, if anything, when they review the transaction; and obviously B, what [indiscernible] decides to do with their p
componenttext: Obviously, it's hard for me to answer that question because I think it's a function of: A, what the Trade Commission in the U.K. decides to do, if anything, when they review the transaction; and obviously B, what [indiscernible] decides to do with their portfolio of hospitals, either in response to the Trade Commission action or in response to other priorities that they may have. So again, I think we're looking at all opportunities in the U.K. and will respond to any and all opportunities that arise, whether they're from the transaction or from, I think, a host of other sources that we're obviously exploring at the same time.

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 26, 2016

componenttext: Okay. And lastly, in April, the comprehensive joint replacement bundling initiative begins. Have you made -- I'm sure you made arrangements to prepare for that. Maybe if you could discuss that a little bit.

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. So all of our acute care hospitals have participated in the Medicare's bundle payment demonstrated projects so far. I think again, a thing our experience is, in any way, unique. I think we're finding the data that Medicare, is providing both in terms
componenttext: Yes. So all of our acute care hospitals have participated in the Medicare's bundle payment demonstrated projects so far. I think again, a thing our experience is, in any way, unique. I think we're finding the data that Medicare, is providing both in terms of the amount and level and timeliness of that data to be somewhat insufficient for us to be able to really participate in this and sort of a meaningful way and make meaningful changes. So I think we're probably likely to actually step back our level of activity and step back in when I think the program is working sort of more efficiently and I think some of the kinks are worked out. But to your point, I mean, I think we've -- sort of from an infrastructure perspective, prepared and feel very prepared for what we think is going to be the long-term sort of trends in this industry, which are more coordinated, more collaborative payments, more risk-based payments. We've done a lot of work over the last several years to be prepared for that and I think feel like we are.

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 26, 2016

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 26, 2016

componenttext: Just curious, any commentary on surgical volumes and ED volumes? What were they? And how does that compare to recent trends?

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. So Frank, I think surgical volumes, as has been the trend for the last few years, continue to outpace even our admissions growth. And I think on the surgical side, surgical volumes are up overall in Q4. We've returned a little bit more to what we've
componenttext: Yes. So Frank, I think surgical volumes, as has been the trend for the last few years, continue to outpace even our admissions growth. And I think on the surgical side, surgical volumes are up overall in Q4. We've returned a little bit more to what we've been seeing the historical pattern where, I think, out-patient volumes are up like 4% and in-patient volumes are up 2%. We went through a few quarters where in-patient was actually outpacing out-patient. Now it's really contributing to some very strong revenue and revenue acuity. This is a bit more normalized, but again, in the end, still helping us put up 7% acute care revenue growth, which we're quite pleased with.

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 26, 2016

componenttext: Got you. And just curious, you announced an acquisition back in the fall. I haven't heard you talk much about in the addiction treatment area, the foundation of acquisition. Just wondered if you could give us an update there on how the transaction has been working and from our perspective, we had a chance we allegedly accretive adjust any color there. .

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: And I'm sorry, Frank. I didn't really [indiscernible] beginning. Did you ask about foundations?

componenttext: Yes, yes.

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, I'm sorry. I thought you were. So foundations, which was a behavioral acquisition that we did in October of last year, really, from our perspective, was intended to enhance our presence in addiction recovery business. UHS has been in the addiction r
componenttext: Okay, I'm sorry. I thought you were. So foundations, which was a behavioral acquisition that we did in October of last year, really, from our perspective, was intended to enhance our presence in addiction recovery business. UHS has been in the addiction recovery business press long as we've been in the behavioral business for 30-plus years. But the foundations model, business model, is a bit different. It's a bit more of an out-of-network model, although it's a fairly balanced in an out of network sort of source of patients. And it's much more of a direct-to-consumer marketing sort of model than our traditional referral-based model. And what we thought is that the foundations approach and the foundations infrastructure and their very nuanced patient capture system, and technology that they have would be a nice complement, both to our existing addiction treatment businesses as well as to other like diagnosis businesses, things like autism and eating disorders. And I think that's really the way it's shaping up. So I think that the early results from foundations are good, and they're encouraging. But I think what we're really most excited about is really sort of taking the best of both of our models, if you will, and sort of combining them, not only in the addiction business, but in some of these other similar diagnoses and service line businesses. And we think the real payoff is further down the road.

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'm curious about a couple of things. So you guys can put capital in, kind of broadly, 3 different buckets. You can continue to add on in the U.K. You can do American behavioral or American kind of addiction assets or you can look at large U.S. acute asse
componenttext: I'm curious about a couple of things. So you guys can put capital in, kind of broadly, 3 different buckets. You can continue to add on in the U.K. You can do American behavioral or American kind of addiction assets or you can look at large U.S. acute assets. Do you have any preference? Or is it all sort of case-by-case?

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: And john, I would add to that, which I know you did purposely leave out. The opportunity to repurchase our own shares, which we been doing as well. I think we have always made the argument, and I think we make the maybe argument because we really believe
componenttext: And john, I would add to that, which I know you did purposely leave out. The opportunity to repurchase our own shares, which we been doing as well. I think we have always made the argument, and I think we make the maybe argument because we really believe it, that we are relatively ambivalent about where we were investing our next dollar of capital. And I say,  I use the term ambivalent to mean that we would like to invest our next dollar of capital wherever it is going to earn the best return or certainty, earn over our hurdle rate of return. And if there are opportunities in each of those markets that you described, I think we feel like we have the opportunity or [indiscernible] financial and capital flexibility to do that. On the other hand, I think one of the hallmarks of UHS as a disciplined investor over the years is that if those opportunities are not compelling and they don't meet our return hurdles, we're okay with waiting until we find some that do. And I think that's going to be our approach going forward. It's been our historical approach. And I think the only sort of comment that we've made in the last few quarters as we think that pipeline is fairly active. And we would hope that we'll be able to find some actionable deals out of that pipeline.

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And I guess, as a follow-on to that. We do you guys look at any intensity in the prior deal? And was there anything about that, that you didn't like, either the price or the mix of assets or just doubling down in the U.K.?
componenttext: Okay. And I guess, as a follow-on to that. We do you guys look at any intensity in the prior deal? And was there anything about that, that you didn't like, either the price or the mix of assets or just doubling down in the U.K.?

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: I mean, we're not going to comment on any specific transaction. But I think that most of the transactions that get announced in the public space our transactions that are made available to most of the public players. And on those transactions, we certainl
componenttext: I mean, we're not going to comment on any specific transaction. But I think that most of the transactions that get announced in the public space our transactions that are made available to most of the public players. And on those transactions, we certainly sort of do our due diligence and do our work. And I think we look at the opportunity, just as I described. What's the historical growth rate of the assets that are being sold? What's the likely future growth rate? What's the price? And as a consequence, what's the likely return? And there are deals that we either choose not to participate in or somebody chooses to pay more for, and that's okay with us. I think we historically have gotten most of the deals that we thought really made compelling sense. We don't get them all, but I think we have found that our relatively judicious and deliberative approach to capital deployment has served us well over the years and continue to believe that's the case.

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: John, Steve [indiscernible] it very, very adequately. But as you pointed it out, we have a number of areas that be can invest. I think we are a prudent investor. And it's a question of which appears to have growth possibilities, what's the price. And we'r
componenttext: John, Steve [indiscernible] it very, very adequately. But as you pointed it out, we have a number of areas that be can invest. I think we are a prudent investor. And it's a question of which appears to have growth possibilities, what's the price. And we're indifferent with regard to which area we put it into. We're certainly concerned about the level of debt of the corporation and the equity and you know that.

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: So would you -- I mean, as the world moves more out-patient, you've got this impressive fleet of in-patient assets. But are you thinking, is there any thought in the Board level down the road that maybe we need to make a bigger step on an out-patient basi
componenttext: So would you -- I mean, as the world moves more out-patient, you've got this impressive fleet of in-patient assets. But are you thinking, is there any thought in the Board level down the road that maybe we need to make a bigger step on an out-patient basis? Or do you think you're adequately covered kind of just blocking and tackling market-by-market?

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: I mean, John, we don't talk about out-patient sort of as a discrete business strategy because, I think, we believe that there is an integrated out-patient strategy in every single one of our acute care markets. We certainly acknowledge the trend that ever
componenttext: I mean, John, we don't talk about out-patient sort of as a discrete business strategy because, I think, we believe that there is an integrated out-patient strategy in every single one of our acute care markets. We certainly acknowledge the trend that everybody has seen over the last few years of a shift of, traditionally, in-patient procedures to out-patient. And I think in virtually all of our markets, we could discuss in some detail how we've tried to take advantage of that, the facilities that we've either built on our own or acquired, the specific marketing sorts of emphases that we've taken up. But I think we have not -- and we have not embarked on a sort of a discrete out-patient strategy, meaning that we've not necessarily been interested in obtaining or embarking on out-patient revenue growth outside of our markets but are very aggressively pursuing this strategy within our existing markets.

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then just lastly, what is spurring? I mean, a couple of you, you and your peer group, there seems to be just a little bit more at the conversation level or acute care assets. And I'm talking about the type of acute care assets that you're screen
componenttext: Okay. And then just lastly, what is spurring? I mean, a couple of you, you and your peer group, there seems to be just a little bit more at the conversation level or acute care assets. And I'm talking about the type of acute care assets that you're screening not rule or small market. What do you think is driving that?

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think, John, that as acute care hospitals in general think about the changing health care landscape, they see, as a question before suggested, a move, a long-term move from fee-for-service reimbursement to some sort of risk-based reimbursement, whether
componenttext: I think, John, that as acute care hospitals in general think about the changing health care landscape, they see, as a question before suggested, a move, a long-term move from fee-for-service reimbursement to some sort of risk-based reimbursement, whether that's bundled payments, as we were talking about before, or ACO-type payments or capitated payments. That's a huge change and a huge change in the requirements and the expertise of running acute care hospitals. And I think a lot of the hospitals that we talk to worry about their ability to compete in that sort of new landscape, either from a physical facility perspective, an information technology perspective, a relationship with physician perspective. I think there are a whole host of changes that hospitals will have to make. And some hospitals, certainly not all, but some hospitals, I think, are deciding that they prefer to have help, either greater expertise or greater capital infusion or some combination of both, as they embark on those challenges. And in my mind, that's probably what's driving this increased level of interest and activity.

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Paula Torch with Avondale Partners.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Paula Torch with Avondale Partners.

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: I just have one question on the acute care business. You mentioned the gain in market share as well as seeing benefits from end market economies and ACA. Just wondering on the market share side. If you can remind us what kind of investments you're making
componenttext: I just have one question on the acute care business. You mentioned the gain in market share as well as seeing benefits from end market economies and ACA. Just wondering on the market share side. If you can remind us what kind of investments you're making their to keep that edge and to grow your market share. And do you think that, that's a piece that could continue on into 2017 and beyond?

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. That's a difficult question to answer in a short way, Paula because, again, I think it is largely a market-by-market discussion because I think that the strategies in each market are not necessarily the same. But we certainly have talked over the yea
componenttext: Yes. That's a difficult question to answer in a short way, Paula because, again, I think it is largely a market-by-market discussion because I think that the strategies in each market are not necessarily the same. But we certainly have talked over the years about investing in physician ownership and physician practices. We've invested in information technology so that we have a more integrated approach with our physicians. We've invested in physical facilities and kind of continuing on to what I was saying to John and upgrading our out-patient capabilities in particular. We've acquired a number of out-patient facilities in our markets over the last few years. So again, in the context of having a few more minutes to sort of talk about it, I'd love to sort of talk about maybe some of the individual strategies and individual markets. But suffice it to say at this point that I think it's a sort of multi-pronged approach in each of our markets.

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, that's fair. And just maybe if I could follow up that when you talk about sort of the secular improvement and how much room do you see for economic improvement in some of your markets? Are we sort of full here? Or do you think there's still some roo
componenttext: Okay, that's fair. And just maybe if I could follow up that when you talk about sort of the secular improvement and how much room do you see for economic improvement in some of your markets? Are we sort of full here? Or do you think there's still some room like in areas like Texas and for example?

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Look, I'm not a macro economist by any means, Paula. So I answer questions like this with a lot of trepidation. But I will say that during the recession, we saw the negative impacts of this long and profound recession, over the course, I would argue
componenttext: Yes. Look, I'm not a macro economist by any means, Paula. So I answer questions like this with a lot of trepidation. But I will say that during the recession, we saw the negative impacts of this long and profound recession, over the course, I would argue of, in some cases, 4 or 5 years in some of our markets, beginning as early as 2009 and continuing in many of these markets through 2013. And so it would not be surprising to me that the recovery in those same markets was over a similar period. And we're probably 3 years or so in most of these markets into the recovery. So while I think the impact is probably starting to diminish, I would still think we have another year or 2 of positive runway in a lot of these markets.

componenttext: Good morning. My name is Brent, and I will be your conference operator today. At this time I would like to welcome everyone to the UHS Fourth Quarter 2015 and Year-end Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] I now like to turn the call over to Steve Filton, CFO. Please go ahead.

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Brent. Good morning. Alan Miller, our CEO, is also joining us this morning. Welcome to this review of Universal Health Services results for the full year and fourth quarter ended December 31, 2015. During the conference call Alan and I will b
componenttext:
Thank you, Brent. Good morning. Alan Miller, our CEO, is also joining us this morning. Welcome to this review of Universal Health Services results for the full year and fourth quarter ended December 31, 2015. 
During the conference call Alan and I will be using words such as believes, expects, anticipates, estimates and similar words that represent forecasts, projections and forward-looking statements. For anyone not familiar with the risks and uncertainties inherent in these forward-looking statements, I recommend a careful reading of the section on risk factors and forward-looking statements and risk factors in our Form 10-K for the year ended December 31, 2015. We would like to highlight just a couple of developments and business trends before opening the call up to questions.
As discussed in our press release last night, the company recorded net income attributable to UHS per diluted share of $6.76 for the year and $1.74 for the quarter. After adjusting for the incentive income and expenses associated with the implementation of electronic health records applications at our acute care hospitals as well as the other items attributable to last year's fourth quarter as disclosed on the Supplemental Schedule included with last night's earnings release, adjusted net income attributable to UHS increased approximately 12% to $170.7 million or $1.71 per diluted share for the quarter ended December 31, 2015, as compared to $152 million or $1.51 per diluted share during the fourth quarter of 2014.
On a same-facility basis, revenues in our behavioral health division increased 3.6% during the fourth quarter of 2015. Adjusted admissions and adjusted patient days to our behavioral health facilities owned for more than a year increased 0.2% and 0.7%, respectively, during the fourth quarter of 2015. Revenue per adjusted patient day rose 2.5% during the fourth quarter of 2015 over the comparable prior year quarter. We define operating margins as operating income or net revenues, less salaries, wages and benefits, other operating expenses and supplies expense, divided by net revenues. Operating margins for our behavioral health hospitals owned for more than a year were 27.1% and 27.9% during the quarters ended December 31, 2015, and '14, respectively. 
On a same-facility basis in our acute care division, revenues increased 7.3% during the fourth quarter of 2015. Adjusted admissions increased 4.8% while revenue per adjusted admission increased 3.3%. On a same-facility basis, operating margins for our acute care hospitals increased to 17.2% during the fourth quarter of 2015 as compared to 16.8% during the fourth quarter of 2014. 
Our cash generated from operating activities was $1.021 billion during 2015 as compared to $1.036 billion during 2014. This small decrease is primarily attributable to $199 million unfavorable change in working capital accounts experienced during 2015 as compared to 2014, resulting mainly from the timing of disbursements. 
Our accounts receivable days outstanding decreased to 52 days during the fourth quarter of 2015 as compared to 54 days during the fourth quarter of 2014. At December 31, 2015, our ratio of debt-to-total capitalization was 45%. We spent $110 million on capital expenditures during the fourth quarter of 2015 and $379 million during the full year of 2015. During 2016, we expect to spend approximately $400 million to $425 million on capital expenditures which include expenditures for capital equipment, renovations, new projects at existing hospitals and construction of new facilities.
In conjunction with our share repurchase program that commenced during the third quarter of 2014, during the fourth quarter of 2015, we repurchased 478,000 shares of our stock at a cost of $58 million. Subsequent to December 31, 2015, we purchased an additional 887,000 shares at an aggregate cost of $99 million. $77 million remains on the previous authorization and yesterday, our Board of Directors approved an additional $400 million in share repurchases. Our estimated range of adjusted net income attributable to UHS for the year ended December 31, 2016, is $7.12 to $7.58 per diluted share. This guidance range excludes the unfavorable $0.17 per diluted share of EHR impact expected during 2016, as described in our press release. This guidance range represents an increase of approximately 4% to 10% over the adjusted net income attributable to UHS of $6.87 per diluted share for the year ended December 31, 2015, as calculated on the Supplemental Schedule included in last night's press release. During 2016, our net revenues are estimated to be approximately $9.75 billion to $9.85 billion, representing an increase of approximately 8% to 9% over 2015 net revenues. 
We are pleased to answer your questions at this time.

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 26, 2016

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Maybe just to drill down a little further on the components of the 2016 guidance, Steve. Possibly, can you give us any commentary around your thoughts on revenue or EBITDAR growth by segment? And are there any other items in there that impact the guidance
componenttext: Maybe just to drill down a little further on the components of the 2016 guidance, Steve. Possibly, can you give us any commentary around your thoughts on revenue or EBITDAR growth by segment? And are there any other items in there that impact the guidance like acquisitions, further share buybacks or new development that we should think about?

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, A.J. So I think we've been fairly transparent over the course of the last few months in talking about our outlook for next year. In terms of the 2 segments, I think on the acute side we see revenue growth of about 6% next year in the acute division
componenttext: Okay, A.J. So I think we've been fairly transparent over the course of the last few months in talking about our outlook for next year. In terms of the 2 segments, I think on the acute side we see revenue growth of about 6% next year in the acute division same-store. On the behavioral side, probably a little bit lower, maybe 5%. I think the acute care 6% is split fairly evenly between price and volume. And I think the behavioral 5% is probably weighted a little more towards volume rather than to price. And I think in both divisions, we expect margins to increase slightly if we can achieve those revenue growth levels. In terms of unusual items or other things that are sort of not included in what I just went through, we have talked for many quarters now that we will be opening a new sixth acute care hospital in Las Vegas. We estimate that to occur in the beginning of the fourth quarter of 2016. That's probably a $5 million to $10 million EBITDA drag on the back half of next year as we have preopening and then -- preopening costs and startup losses. And it's probably a bit more of a drag at the net income line as the depreciation and interest associated with that facility comes online. We'll probably lose a few million dollars next year on the foreign exchange impact in the U.K. We'll probably lose a few million dollars on a decline in what we call special Medicaid reimbursement monies, which would be UPL and disproportionate share on provider taxes. And I think the only other sort of probably noteworthy item about our guidance is that as -- it's always been our historical practice, we assume that our free cash flow is dedicated to the repayment of debt. And all -- the only sort of share repurchase or other deployment of capital that we built into our guidance and built into our model is that which has already occurred. And so I think it's a fairly conservative way of thinking about 2016 capital deployment because repayment of debt at the moment is the least accretive of all of our capital deployment options.

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: And on that last point, I would assume you're including the $99 million you've purchased to date? Or is that not included in guidance year-to-date this year?
componenttext: And on that last point, I would assume you're including the $99 million you've purchased to date? Or is that not included in guidance year-to-date this year?

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 26, 2016
