componenttext: So I'm not sure where the commentary on margin contraction comes from, Kevin. I mean, in my remarks, I pointed out that on a same-facility basis, acute care margins were 17.2% in the fourth quarter of '15 versus 16.8% in the fourth quarter of '14. So...

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. I'm sorry. Then I guess the issues that you talked about in Q3 then, have they been addressed into Q4?
componenttext: Okay. I'm sorry. Then I guess the issues that you talked about in Q3 then, have they been addressed into Q4?

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I think that we had clinical shortages, personnel shortages on the acute side in Q3, as did some of our peers. And what we said at the time was that we thought we could hire enough permanent nurses to generally overcome most of the problem. We though
componenttext: Yes. I think that we had clinical shortages, personnel shortages on the acute side in Q3, as did some of our peers. And what we said at the time was that we thought we could hire enough permanent nurses to generally overcome most of the problem. We thought that we would make progress in the fourth quarter and continue to make progress into the first part of 2016. And I think that's the way it's shaped up. We definitely made progress in Q4 and I think we'll make some further progress in the first half of '16.

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then I guess the bad debt spiked in Q3. I guess it was up year-over-year in Q4 but down sequentially from where you were. Can you talk a little bit about the trends there?
componenttext: And then I guess the bad debt spiked in Q3. I guess it was up year-over-year in Q4 but down sequentially from where you were. Can you talk a little bit about the trends there?

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I mean, so I think what -- when you're looking at the uncompensated care numbers, and they are certainly up in Q4, that's almost always going to be the case simply as a function of pricing because of the way we calculate that. Our uninsured admission
componenttext: Yes. I mean, so I think what -- when you're looking at the uncompensated care numbers, and they are certainly up in Q4, that's almost always going to be the case simply as a function of pricing because of the way we calculate that. Our uninsured admission growth in Q4 actually slowed a little bit. In Q3, our uninsured admission growth was tracking ahead of our overall admission growth. And that trend reversed itself in Q4 where our -- while our overall uninsured admissions were up, they were up slightly slower than our overall admissions. So I think our payer mix seems to be settling in to a bit more of the stable environment in Q4. And again, I think we're just pleased, extremely pleased, that the overall, even after uncompensated care is included, 7-plus percent growth in acute care revenues in Q4.

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: And do you expect the payer mix to be stable into 2016?
componenttext: And do you expect the payer mix to be stable into 2016?

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: I mean that's generally our expectation. To be fair, payer mix is probably the most difficult of sort of all the assumptions and all the metrics to predict. But our general sense is that the 2 items have -- that have affected payer mix over the last few y
componenttext: I mean that's generally our expectation. To be fair, payer mix is probably the most difficult of sort of all the assumptions and all the metrics to predict. But our general sense is that the 2 items have -- that have affected payer mix over the last few years have been the ACA and its favorable impact on improving payer mix. And we think that, that has been moderating over the last few years and will continue to moderate next year. And it's part of the reason why we think our acute care revenue growth moderates from the 8% or so in '15 to more like 6% in '16. And then the improving economies, I don't think we necessarily feel like our local market economies are improving as rapidly as they were in '14 and '15, but I think we feel like they certainly will remain stable in '16.

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 26, 2016

componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Josh Raskin with Barclays.

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Steve, I think you might have alluded to this a little bit, but just a question broadly on labor cost. I think you mentioned on the psych side, still seeing more, I guess, on the physician and I guess a little bit in nursing. But anything more broadly in
componenttext: Steve, I think you might have alluded to this a little bit, but just a question broadly on labor cost. I think you mentioned on the psych side, still seeing more, I guess, on the physician and I guess a little bit in nursing. But anything more broadly in terms of labor costs and more specifically on the acute care side?

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: I mean, I think what we said in Q3 vis-a-vis the acute care labor sort of situation was that we felt like our use of temporary nurses or registry nurses was greater than it should be. That's a function, I think, of a number of things including turnover ra
componenttext: I mean, I think what we said in Q3 vis-a-vis the acute care labor sort of situation was that we felt like our use of temporary nurses or registry nurses was greater than it should be. That's a function, I think, of a number of things including turnover rates that we'd like to drive somewhat lower, decisions that are made exactly when and how to hire permanent nurses, et cetera. And I think we generally attributed the increase in salary expense and the pressure on salary expense in Q3 to some inefficiencies in terms of not hiring as many permanent nurses as we needed to in Q3. And again, I think we felt like that was a transient problem that we could address. And as I was commenting to Kevin, I think we felt like we did address it in Q4. Clearly, the numbers got better. And I think our expectation is, frankly, they'll continue to improve into 2016.

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And you put contract labor in other expense, right? It's not in the SWB line, is that right?
componenttext: Okay. And you put contract labor in other expense, right? It's not in the SWB line, is that right?

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: So contract nurses are in the salary line. Contract physicians are in the other operating expense line.
componenttext: So contract nurses are in the salary line. Contract physicians are in the other operating expense line.

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then just a second question, just on the buybacks. You guys have been a little bit more active to start the year. Should we read into that in terms of anything around the M&A landscape or other uses? I mean you guys, obviously, don't have a leve
componenttext: Okay. And then just a second question, just on the buybacks. You guys have been a little bit more active to start the year. Should we read into that in terms of anything around the M&A landscape or other uses? I mean you guys, obviously, don't have a leverage issue in my opinion. So I'm sure you can do both. But I just want to make sure we shouldn't be reading into the environment or something like that.

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: So I think, Josh, we share your view that our leverage levels are such that we are flexible enough to do any number of things to respond to M&A opportunities as well as to be a share repurchaser of that if the market sort of dictates that. Our commentary
componenttext: So I think, Josh, we share your view that our leverage levels are such that we are flexible enough to do any number of things to respond to M&A opportunities as well as to be a share repurchaser of that if the market sort of dictates that. Our commentary in the last few quarters, and I would repeat it, I don't think it has changed in Q4, is that we think the M&A landscape is still active for us on both sides of the business. We completed 2 reasonably sized behavioral deals in the back half of last year and continue to look at others into '16. We've commented that the landscape and the market for acute care deals that are, I think, more suitable in our minds for what has been historically our market profile of kind of more suburban, midsized urban markets, larger hospitals, larger hospital systems, seems more active. It's always difficult to predict which of those deals or how many of those deals might ultimately prove to be actionable or executable, but we certainly feel like it is more active. But also, like many of you, I think we have viewed the decline in our stock over the last couple of quarters as really not something that has been justified by the underlying fundamentals of the business, which we don't feel have changed very much over the last 6 months. And as a consequence, we feel that their degree of confidence in our underlying business and feel like the current valuations of our stock are a compelling opportunity as well. And then that's why we've become a more active acquirer of shares as well. So I think as you suggested, I think we're going to -- given our balance sheet and our flexibility, we're going to pursue any and all of these opportunities that continue to make economic sense for us.

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Matthew Borsch with Goldman Sachs.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Matthew Borsch with Goldman Sachs.

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just first, soapbox comment, which I guess you've gotten before, that -- we appreciate the fact that you don't waste 20, 25 minutes of your time and our time reading through the press release and go right to questions. Let me ask about the bad debt trend,
componenttext: Just first, soapbox comment, which I guess you've gotten before, that -- we appreciate the fact that you don't waste 20, 25 minutes of your time and our time reading through the press release and go right to questions. Let me ask about the bad debt trend, recognizing that the strong acute revenue growth was more important than that. Can you give us any granularity? I know last quarter you talked about the South Texas market being an area where you saw an uptick in uncompensated care. Is that continuing? Or is there anything to spike out from there?

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: So Matt, I think from a geographic perspective, we have said, now frankly for several quarters, that if you look at our acute care results overall, the Las Vegas market, the Southern California market has generally been tracking sort of above the average
componenttext: So Matt, I think from a geographic perspective, we have said, now frankly for several quarters, that if you look at our acute care results overall, the Las Vegas market, the Southern California market has generally been tracking sort of above the average acute care result. And I think that's true sort of across-the-board in terms of volumes and revenue and payer mix and bad debt. And we've said that the Texas market and markets, because we have multiple markets in Texas, have generally been lagging the average. And I think that was true in Q4. I'm not exactly sure why that is. Obviously, there's a great deal of focus and speculation that, that's oil and gas-related and driven. We tend not to be in markets that are directly impacted by the oil and gas business. So I'm not certain that, that's the main driver or the only driver for sure. But certainly, our Texas markets for the last several quarters have been underperforming the acute care average.

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: And one more question, if I could, on a different topic. Amidst all the pressure on insurers, on the ACA exchange business, what are you generally seeing in terms of the dynamic for commercial rate negotiations, both as it relates to that business and gen
componenttext: And one more question, if I could, on a different topic. Amidst all the pressure on insurers, on the ACA exchange business, what are you generally seeing in terms of the dynamic for commercial rate negotiations, both as it relates to that business and generally the larger core group business as well?

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. So let me address that, I think, both in terms of volume and price. And I'll make the comment and I think we've been making this comment and expressing this view longer and probably more adamantly than some of our peers, and that is, we've always fou
componenttext: Yes. So let me address that, I think, both in terms of volume and price. And I'll make the comment and I think we've been making this comment and expressing this view longer and probably more adamantly than some of our peers, and that is, we've always found it difficult to precisely carve out our ACA experience and sort of separate out exactly what our ACA commercial experience and rates are versus our overall commercial experience. And I would say, we continue. And honestly, as the ACA has progressed and we're now well into our third year, I'd say into our fourth year of it, I think that we find that even more difficult. But -- so my commentary is probably more about commercial rates just generally than about ACA rates, specifically. And that is, we don't see tremendous changes either in our rate of increase. I think our commercial rates of increase still average in the 6%, 6.5% range, varies to some degree by contract, by market, but I think that's still our average. And I don't think we're really seeing significant changes in other terms, in benefit plan design. We're not seeing an emphasis on narrow networks that I think we actually expected we would see more of, et cetera. So I think as we enter '16 and as we think about creating our model for '16, it is more of the same as much as anything.

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Ralph Giacobbe with Citi.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Ralph Giacobbe with Citi.

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just want to go back to the staffing shortages and maybe more particularly, I think you mentioned psychiatrists. That doesn't sound overly transient, but maybe you could talk through the dynamics there, how you tend to sort of fix that and whether this is
componenttext: Just want to go back to the staffing shortages and maybe more particularly, I think you mentioned psychiatrists. That doesn't sound overly transient, but maybe you could talk through the dynamics there, how you tend to sort of fix that and whether this is also an area of sort of higher wage pressure that we should expect on the behavioral side of the business going forward.

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. So look, I think that your comment, Ralph, in the sense that I believe we're facing psychiatrist shortages in specific markets because I think, nationally, the data suggests that the number of new psychiatrists over the last decade have not kept up
componenttext: Sure. So look, I think that your comment, Ralph, in the sense that I believe we're facing psychiatrist shortages in specific markets because I think, nationally, the data suggests that the number of new psychiatrists over the last decade have not kept up or have lagged the overall number of new doctors, so the percentage of psychiatrists is actually declining. And I agree with you, that is a kind of more structural issue. I believe the market tends to correct for that, in that as the demand for psychiatrists increases, as psychiatrists' earnings increase, more and more people get attracted to the field. More and more practicing psychiatrists will choose to devote at least some of their hours to clinical activities rather than to academic or other activities. So I do think there is some market correction that goes on for all of this. In addition, I think -- and the trend -- what my commentary about as being a transient problem is really meant to imply that, I believe, we can pull levers in our markets to address the issue. We can more aggressively recruit for psychiatrists. We can bring psychiatrists into a market that has a shortage. Your comment that, that may cost us more money, and in fact, I think it does cost us more money if you look at one of the reasons I think that our behavioral margins have come under pressure is because the cost of acquiring psychiatrists has also gone up, in addition to there being some pressure on our volumes. And the other thing that I think we do in markets where the regulatory environment allows us to is we create physician extenders, nurses and other clinicians who can do some of the tasks that psychiatrists are sometimes asked to do. And that helps us as well in terms of not having enough psychiatrists. So we're doing all of those things and pulling all those levers and aggressively focused on the issue. And to some degree, I think our confidence that we're going to do those things better than some of our peers in our markets causes me to comment or to believe that this is a transient sort of issue that we can overcome.

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. But the behavioral revenue up 5%, we should think of an ability to still get to sort of EBITDA growth on a same-store basis of at least that 5% versus maybe a little bit below.
componenttext: Okay. But the behavioral revenue up 5%, we should think of an ability to still get to sort of EBITDA growth on a same-store basis of at least that 5% versus maybe a little bit below.

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: That's certainly what we have embedded in our guidance.
componenttext: That's certainly what we have embedded in our guidance.

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. All right. Fair enough. And then just quickly on the acute side. You've posted volume trends sort of well in excess of peers for several quarters now. I know you're in a sort of smaller subset of markets and have a little bit of smaller hospital bas
componenttext: Okay. All right. Fair enough. And then just quickly on the acute side. You've posted volume trends sort of well in excess of peers for several quarters now. I know you're in a sort of smaller subset of markets and have a little bit of smaller hospital base. But any sense of dynamics within your specific markets about whether you think all hospitals within your areas are seeing similar trends? Or do you think you're taking market share? Have you seen hospital closures? Just anything that stands out around the sort of disproportionately better volume trends you're seeing.

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think as your question suggests, Ralph, it's a combination of factors. We tended to be in markets that were disproportionately hurt by the recession and had higher unemployment rates. I think that a number of sell side folks did analyses during the rece
componenttext: I think as your question suggests, Ralph, it's a combination of factors. We tended to be in markets that were disproportionately hurt by the recession and had higher unemployment rates. I think that a number of sell side folks did analyses during the recession of where unemployment was the highest. And when they compared the public companies, I think we often fared the worst during the sort of height of the recession in places like Las Vegas and Southern California, South Florida, South Texas. But what we suggested at the time and we believed, was that when the economy recovered and when those local market economies recovered, we would benefit disproportionately from those recoveries. And I think that has certainly been an element of what has happened over the course of the last few years. As Las Vegas has come, I would suggest roaring back, we've really benefited from that, for example. But I think we also believe that in many of our markets, we are aggressively increasing our market share. Both Alan and I mentioned the fact that a big California market, which is Riverside County, we built a new hospital several years ago. In the Las Vegas market, we're building a new hospital to open later this year. We continue to take those very obvious actions and other not-so-obvious actions to cement, enhance and increase our market share in most of our acute care markets. And I think we have done that fairly successfully over the last few years as well. So I think both of those dynamics are at play when you see the really robust and industry-leading acute care revenue growth that we've been putting up.

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Gary Lieberman with Wells Fargo.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Gary Lieberman with Wells Fargo.

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is Ryan Halsted, on for Gary. I was hoping you could drill more into your behavioral revenue growth guidance. The 5% is towards the low end, I guess, of your past ranges and certainly below where you've grown in the recent past. So I thought -- I was
componenttext: This is Ryan Halsted, on for Gary. I was hoping you could drill more into your behavioral revenue growth guidance. The 5% is towards the low end, I guess, of your past ranges and certainly below where you've grown in the recent past. So I thought -- I was hoping maybe you could just provide a little more color on the reimbursement environment and what makes you sort of a little cautious on that outlook.

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure, Ryan. So actually, I think, as sort of the conversation and commentary has been so far in the call, the issue for us is not so much caution about the pricing environment which I think actually has been fairly healthy. And I think even if you look at
componenttext: Sure, Ryan. So actually, I think, as sort of the conversation and commentary has been so far in the call, the issue for us is not so much caution about the pricing environment which I think actually has been fairly healthy. And I think even if you look at Q4, the 2.5% pricing growth on our revenue per day in behavioral is, quite frankly, as good as -- and a little better than we expected. So that, I don't think is the concern going into -- or the caution -- I should say the caution going into 2016. I think what we -- the caution is some of the volume pressures that we've seen over the last few quarters. And I think those volume pressures are manifested in a few different areas. The area that we talked about the most historically and certainly over the last few quarters has been length-of-stay compression, that even when we were posing really strong admission growth, length-of-stay compression was muting or diminishing that growth to a degree. I think the length-of-stay pressure is starting to alleviate some and so we're hopeful that will continue, but the admissions softness that we've seen as a result of, again, 2 things. Very difficult comparisons in the beginning of '16. That, I think, clouds some of our guidance for the year and then some of the issues we've had over the clinician shortages that we've been talking about. And while, as I've said in my previous commentary, I think we can address those, it may take a quarter or 2. So I think that's really what has caused us to be a little more muted about our behavioral revenue growth. And obviously, in the long term, we think that the tailwinds for behavioral revenue growth have a lot of potential. We haven't really talked in this call about the potential for the IMD exclusion being partially or fully lifted, but we believe that will occur. And when it does, that will provide an opportunity for sort of another step-up in behavioral volumes that we're likely to see not so much in '16, but in '17 and thereafter.

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. That's very helpful. And then my second question. If you take a look at your segment EBITDAR on a same-store basis, I realize there was some margin pressure on the behavioral side. But just even on a year-over-year EBITDAR growth basis, it looked li
componenttext: Okay. That's very helpful. And then my second question. If you take a look at your segment EBITDAR on a same-store basis, I realize there was some margin pressure on the behavioral side. But just even on a year-over-year EBITDAR growth basis, it looked like, combined, the segments were up nicely. But then comparing that with the consolidated EBITDAR, the growth year-over-year wasn't as much. So I was just wondering if there's anything on a non-same-store basis or on a corporate overhead basis that I should be thinking about or am I not thinking about this correctly?

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: I mean there's nothing that really stands out, Ryan. I will make the comment that we did have a favorable malpractice adjustment last year. And I know just from talking to some analysts last night that not everybody was taking that into account. So I woul
componenttext: I mean there's nothing that really stands out, Ryan. I will make the comment that we did have a favorable malpractice adjustment last year. And I know just from talking to some analysts last night that not everybody was taking that into account. So I would just ask people to go back and make sure they've -- we, if you will, equalize that adjustment in our Supplemental Schedule. So I would just sort of ask everybody to focus on making sure they've done that. I think other than that, I can't think of any really significant changes other than, as we disclosed, last year we acquired an insurance company, insurance product in our acute care division last year. That's been a little bit of a drag, although I don't think it's a huge needle mover.

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Ana Gupte with Leerink.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Ana Gupte with Leerink.

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Again, coming back to bad debt, you have improved your bad debt pretty nicely, I think, sequentially. And in the third quarter, a lot of the companies had issues. For the most part, there's been some improvement into the fourth quarter. There was speculat
componenttext: Again, coming back to bad debt, you have improved your bad debt pretty nicely, I think, sequentially. And in the third quarter, a lot of the companies had issues. For the most part, there's been some improvement into the fourth quarter. There was speculation around exchanges. I think ACA talked about Medicaid application processing and communities taking that write-down on collectability of the consumer cost sharing piece of it. Was this just a spike in a blip in the third quarter? And do you feel like kind of out of the woods and so we should look at your bad debt flat now into 2016, taking the baseline from 4Q? Or are there any uncertainties as you look at your revenue cycle management and you're trying to drill down into what happened there?

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. So to be perfectly candid, I think we've struggled in Q3 with explaining the increase in uncompensated volumes. As you suggest, some of our peers offered explanations that included some level of disenrollment in the exchanges, as exchange participan
componenttext: Sure. So to be perfectly candid, I think we've struggled in Q3 with explaining the increase in uncompensated volumes. As you suggest, some of our peers offered explanations that included some level of disenrollment in the exchanges, as exchange participants found their premiums going up or they suggested that maybe some exchange participants have sort of gamed the system and enrolled to get certain care but then disenrolled when they got that care. Those explanations seemed reasonable and we could sort of find anecdotal examples within our own experience to support those explanations, but don't really have the sort of vast database to really be able to validate them in any sort of pervasive or comprehensive way. And I think our fourth quarter experience would suggest that even if those explanations were valid in Q3, they didn't necessarily extend into Q4. The other sort of question you asked about, which I think we certainly would concur with the experience, I mean we have seen that as the ACA has been implemented and as exchange plans have become more prevalent and many of them have sort of high deductible, high coinsurance components to them, that the level of -- or the amount of the bill due from the patient has gone up. And as a consequence, the level of bad debt on that portion of the bill has also gone up. We believe that our accounting for that change has been sort of real-time and current all along and has been reflected over the course of the last several years in our current results. So I don't feel like we feel like there's any sort of catch-up required in the way that we're recognizing that phenomena for financial statement purposes.

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. That's very helpful. And on the volumes, just coming back to the acute care volumes. I think it sounds like you're saying to an earlier question that it was more -- it's more secular growth than share shifting from other players in the markets that
componenttext: Okay. That's very helpful. And on the volumes, just coming back to the acute care volumes. I think it sounds like you're saying to an earlier question that it was more -- it's more secular growth than share shifting from other players in the markets that you're in. As you saw the 4Q trends on both volumes and on acuity and then coming into the first quarter, anything you're seeing in the first quarter relative to the fourth quarter from a seasonality perspective or the acuity or types of procedures and services that would tell us what the drivers of that volume growth is?

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. So just to go back, Ana, I would say that what my answer before was really meant to say that I think our acute care revenues, in general, are benefiting from both the improvement in our end-market economies as well as the ACA benefit. And honestly, I
componenttext: Yes. So just to go back, Ana, I would say that what my answer before was really meant to say that I think our acute care revenues, in general, are benefiting from both the improvement in our end-market economies as well as the ACA benefit. And honestly, I think sometimes it's difficult for us to distinguish precisely between the two and market share gains as well. So again, I think all those dynamics are contributing. In terms of, I think sort of forward-looking into just the early part of '16, I think -- and I think most of the surveys have sort of suggested this, that the end of '15 and the beginning of January were sort of slow from a volume perspective on the acute side. I think that may be attributable to the fact that it was a late starting and relatively slow flu season. But I would say over the course of the last 6 weeks from the middle of January to the end of February, acute care activity, at least at our hospitals, seems to be pretty robust and certainly doesn't give us any pause about being able to continue to achieve the numbers that we identified before.

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: And one final question on the IMD exclusion, there was a very recent news flow, I think last week, that CMS send this to the Office of Management and Budget. Were there any changes or markups from the behavioral hospital industry and/or managed Medicaid i
componenttext: And one final question on the IMD exclusion, there was a very recent news flow, I think last week, that CMS send this to the Office of Management and Budget. Were there any changes or markups from the behavioral hospital industry and/or managed Medicaid in the version that's gone there relative to what we saw last May?

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: We believe that the version, particularly in terms of the provisions that are most relevant to us, remains intact. And viewed the news item that you point out as a good one, and there were positive one in the sense that even though the process is moving,
componenttext: We believe that the version, particularly in terms of the provisions that are most relevant to us, remains intact. And viewed the news item that you point out as a good one, and there were positive one in the sense that even though the process is moving, albeit a little bit slower than we would like, it is moving. And as I was saying before, I think we expect the pending CMS rule to be issued sometime this year. And we would hope that the effective date would be no later than the beginning of next year. And that would provide a tailwind for our behavioral business and our behavioral volumes going into next year.

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Jason Gurda with KeyBanc.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Jason Gurda with KeyBanc.

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Steve, I apologize if I missed this, but did you provide an update on how your U.K. operations are performing?
componenttext: Steve, I apologize if I missed this, but did you provide an update on how your U.K. operations are performing?

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: We didn't. We didn't get that specific question. The U.K. commentary over the last few quarters has been that both our original Cygnet acquisition as well as our subsequent Alpha acquisition and our smaller one-offs and new beds are really generally doing
componenttext: We didn't. We didn't get that specific question. The U.K. commentary over the last few quarters has been that both our original Cygnet acquisition as well as our subsequent Alpha acquisition and our smaller one-offs and new beds are really generally doing quite well. Occupancy rates for our U.K. behavioral hospitals, on average, are in the low-90s. And we continue to look for further expansion opportunities and the ability to grow that platform in the U.K., which we're -- continue to remain very enthusiastic about.

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Do you think the review of the Priory transaction -- Acadia's transaction with the Priory Group, do you think that would provide some opportunities for a one-off facility pickups?
componenttext: Do you think the review of the Priory transaction -- Acadia's transaction with the Priory Group, do you think that would provide some opportunities for a one-off facility pickups?

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Obviously, hard for me to answer that question because I think it's a function of: A, what the Trade Commission in the U.K. decides to do, if anything, when they review the transaction; and obviously, B, what Acadia decides to do with their portfolio of h
componenttext: Obviously, hard for me to answer that question because I think it's a function of: A, what the Trade Commission in the U.K. decides to do, if anything, when they review the transaction; and obviously, B, what Acadia decides to do with their portfolio of hospitals, either in response to the Trade Commission action or in response to other priorities that they may have. Again, I think we're looking at all opportunities in the U.K. and will respond to any and all opportunities that arise, whether they're from that transaction or from, I think, a host of other sources that we're obviously exploring at the same time.

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And lastly, in April, the comprehensive joint replacement bundling initiative begins. Have you made -- I'm sure you've made arrangements to prepare for that, maybe if you could discuss that a little bit?
componenttext: Okay. And lastly, in April, the comprehensive joint replacement bundling initiative begins. Have you made -- I'm sure you've made arrangements to prepare for that, maybe if you could discuss that a little bit?

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. So all of our acute care hospitals have participated in Medicare's bundle payment demonstration projects so far. I think, and again, I don't believe our experience is in any way unique. I think we're finding the data that Medicare is providing, both
componenttext: Yes. So all of our acute care hospitals have participated in Medicare's bundle payment demonstration projects so far. I think, and again, I don't believe our experience is in any way unique. I think we're finding the data that Medicare is providing, both in terms of the amount and level and timeliness of that data to be somewhat insufficient for us to be able to really participate in this in sort of a meaningful way and make meaningful changes. So I think we're probably likely to actually step back our level of activity and step back in when I think the program is working sort of more efficiently and I think some of the kinks are worked out. But to your point, I mean, I think we've -- on sort of from an infrastructure perspective, prepared and feel very prepared for what we think is going to be the long term sort of trend in this industry which are more coordinated, more collaborative payments, more risk-based payments. We've done a lot of work over the last several years to be prepared for that and I think feel like we are.

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Frank Morgan with RBC Capital Markets.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Frank Morgan with RBC Capital Markets.

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just curious, any commentary on surgical volumes and ED volumes? What were they? And how does that compare to recent trends?
componenttext: Just curious, any commentary on surgical volumes and ED volumes? What were they? And how does that compare to recent trends?

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. So Frank, I think surgical volumes, as has been the trend for the last few years, continue to outpace even our admissions growth. And I think on the surgical side, surgical volumes are up overall in Q4. We've returned a little bit more to what we've
componenttext: Yes. So Frank, I think surgical volumes, as has been the trend for the last few years, continue to outpace even our admissions growth. And I think on the surgical side, surgical volumes are up overall in Q4. We've returned a little bit more to what we've been seeing the historical pattern where I think outpatient volumes are up like 4% and inpatient volumes are up 2%. We went through a few quarters where our inpatient was actually outpacing outpatient. Now it's really contributing to some very strong revenue and revenue acuity. This is a bit more normalized. But again, in the end, still helping us put up 7% acute care revenue growth, which we're quite pleased with.

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. Got you. And just curious, you announced an acquisition back in the fall. I haven't heard you really talk much about in the addiction treatment area, the Foundations acquisition. Just wondering if you could give us an update there on how that transa
componenttext: Okay. Got you. And just curious, you announced an acquisition back in the fall. I haven't heard you really talk much about in the addiction treatment area, the Foundations acquisition. Just wondering if you could give us an update there on how that transaction has been working. And from our perspective, we thought it had a chance of being relatively accretive and just any color there.

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: And I'm sorry, Frank. I think you faded in the very beginning, at least for me. Were you asking about Foundations?
componenttext: And I'm sorry, Frank. I think you faded in the very beginning, at least for me. Were you asking about Foundations?

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, yes.
componenttext: Yes, yes.

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, I'm sorry. I thought you were. Yes, so Foundations which was a behavioral acquisition that we did in October of last year, really from our perspective, was intended to enhance our presence in addiction recovery business. UHS has been in the addictio
componenttext: Okay, I'm sorry. I thought you were. Yes, so Foundations which was a behavioral acquisition that we did in October of last year, really from our perspective, was intended to enhance our presence in addiction recovery business. UHS has been in the addiction recovery business for as long as we've been in the behavioral business for 30-plus years. But the Foundations model, business model, is a bit different. It's a bit more of an out-of-network model, although it's a fairly balanced in and out of network sort of source of patients. And it's much more of a direct-to-consumer marketing sort of model than our traditional referral-based model. And what we thought is that the Foundations' approach and the Foundations' infrastructure and their very nuanced patient capture system and technology that they have, would be a nice complement both to our existing addiction treatment businesses as well as to other like-diagnosis businesses, things like autism and eating disorders. And I think that's really the way it's shaping up. So I think that the early results from Foundations are good and they're encouraging. But I think what we're really most excited about is really sort of taking the best of both of our models, if you will, and sort of combining them, not only in the addiction business, but in some of these other similar diagnoses and service line businesses. And we think the real payoff is further down the road.

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 26, 2016

componenttext: Okay. Just one final one, if I can, a clarification on your discussion around CapEx including construction of the hospital. I'm assuming that's just the one in the Vegas area or was there another one that you're contemplating that you're allocating some capital for?

componenttext: That's the only acute care hospital. We have a couple of de novo projects that are on the -- in some stage of development on the behavioral side as well. Obviously, those are smaller dollars.

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of John Ransom with Raymond James.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of John Ransom with Raymond James.

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Most of my stuff has been answered, but I'm curious about a couple of things. So you guys can put capital in kind of broadly 3 different buckets. You can continue to add on in the U.K., you can do American behavioral or American kind of addiction assets o
componenttext: Most of my stuff has been answered, but I'm curious about a couple of things. So you guys can put capital in kind of broadly 3 different buckets. You can continue to add on in the U.K., you can do American behavioral or American kind of addiction assets or you can look at large U.S. acute assets. Do you have any preference or is it all sort of case-by-case?

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: And John, I would add to that, which I know you didn't purposely leave out, the opportunity to repurchase our own shares which we've been doing as well. Look, I think we have always made the argument, and I think we make the argument because we really bel
componenttext: And John, I would add to that, which I know you didn't purposely leave out, the opportunity to repurchase our own shares which we've been doing as well. Look, I think we have always made the argument, and I think we make the argument because we really believe it, that we are relatively ambivalent about where we invest our next dollar of capital. And I say -- I used the term ambivalent to mean that we would like to invest our next dollar of capital wherever it is going to earn the best return or certainly, earn over our hurdle rate of return. And if there are opportunities in each of those buckets that you described, I think we feel like we have the opportunity or -- and the financial and capital flexibility to do that. On the other hand, I think one of the hallmarks of UHS as a disciplined investor over the years is that if those opportunities are not compelling and they don't meet our return hurdles, we're okay with waiting until we find some that do. And I think that's going to be our approach going forward. It's been our historical approach. And I think the only sort of comment that we've made in the last few quarters, is we think that pipeline is fairly active and we would hope that we'll be able to find some actionable deals out of that pipeline.

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And I guess as a follow-on to that. Did you guys look at any intensity at the Priory deal? And was there anything about that, that you didn't like either the price or the mix of assets or just doubling down in the U.K.?
componenttext: Okay. And I guess as a follow-on to that. Did you guys look at any intensity at the Priory deal? And was there anything about that, that you didn't like either the price or the mix of assets or just doubling down in the U.K.?

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: I mean, I'm not -- we're not going to comment on any specific transaction. But I think that most of the transactions that get announced in the public space are transactions that are made available to most of the public players. And on those transactions,
componenttext: I mean, I'm not -- we're not going to comment on any specific transaction. But I think that most of the transactions that get announced in the public space are transactions that are made available to most of the public players. And on those transactions, we certainly sort of do our due diligence and do our work. And I think we look at the opportunity just as I described, what's the historical growth rate of the assets that are being sold, what's the likely future growth rate, what's the price. And as a consequence, what's the likely return. And there are deals that we either choose not to participate in or somebody chooses to pay more for. And that's okay with us. I think we historically have gotten most of the deals that we thought really made compelling sense. You don't get them all, but I think we have found that our relatively judicious and deliberative approach to capital deployment has served us well over the years and continue to believe that's the case.

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: John, Steve has covered it very, very adequately. But as you pointed out, we have a number of areas that we can invest. I think we are a prudent investor. And it's a question of which appears to have growth possibilities, what's the price. And we're indif
componenttext: John, Steve has covered it very, very adequately. But as you pointed out, we have a number of areas that we can invest. I think we are a prudent investor. And it's a question of which appears to have growth possibilities, what's the price. And we're indifferent with regard to which area we put it into. But we are certainly concerned about the level of debt of the corporation and the equity and you know that.

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: So would you -- I mean, as the world moves more outpatient, you've got this impressive fleet of inpatient assets. But are you thinking -- is there any thought in the board level down the road that maybe we need to make a bigger step in an outpatient basis
componenttext: So would you -- I mean, as the world moves more outpatient, you've got this impressive fleet of inpatient assets. But are you thinking -- is there any thought in the board level down the road that maybe we need to make a bigger step in an outpatient basis? Or do you think you're adequately covered kind of just blocking and tackling market by market?

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: I mean, John, we don't talk about outpatient sort of as a discrete business strategy because I think we believe that there's an integrated outpatient strategy in every single one of our acute care markets. We certainly acknowledge the trend that everybody
componenttext: I mean, John, we don't talk about outpatient sort of as a discrete business strategy because I think we believe that there's an integrated outpatient strategy in every single one of our acute care markets. We certainly acknowledge the trend that everybody has seen over the last few years of a shift of traditionally inpatient procedures to outpatient. And I think in virtually all of our markets, we could discuss in some detail how we've tried to take advantage of that, the facilities that we've either built on our own or acquired, the specific marketing sorts of emphases that we've taken on. But again, I think we have not -- and we have not embarked on a sort of a discrete outpatient strategy, meaning that we have not necessarily been interested in obtaining or embarking on outpatient revenue growth outside of our markets, but are very aggressively pursuing this strategy within our existing markets.

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then just lastly, what is spurring -- I mean a couple of you, you and your peer group, there seems to be just a little bit more at the conversation level for acute care assets. And I'm talking about the type of acute care assets that would -- th
componenttext: Okay. And then just lastly, what is spurring -- I mean a couple of you, you and your peer group, there seems to be just a little bit more at the conversation level for acute care assets. And I'm talking about the type of acute care assets that would -- that you're screening not rural or small market. What do you think is driving that?

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think, John, that as acute care hospitals in general think about the changing health care landscape, they see, as the question before suggested, a move -- a long-term move from fee-for-service reimbursement to some sort of risk-based reimbursement wheth
componenttext: I think, John, that as acute care hospitals in general think about the changing health care landscape, they see, as the question before suggested, a move -- a long-term move from fee-for-service reimbursement to some sort of risk-based reimbursement whether that's bundled payments, as we were talking about before, or ACO-type payments or capitated payments. That's a huge change and a huge change in the requirements and the expertise of running acute care hospitals. And I think a lot of the hospitals that we talked to worry about their ability to compete in that sort of new landscape either from a physical facility perspective, an information technology perspective, a relationship with physician perspective. I think there are a whole host of changes that hospitals will have to make. And some hospitals, certainly not all, but some hospitals, I think, are deciding that they prefer to have help, either greater expertise or greater capital infusion or some combination of both as they embark on those challenges. And in my mind, that's probably what's driving this increased level of interest and activity.

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 26, 2016

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 26, 2016

componenttext: I just have one question on the acute care business. You mentioned the gain in market share as well as seeing benefits from end-market economies and the ACA. And just wondering on the market share side, if you can remind us what kind of investments you're making there to keep that edge and to grow your market share? And do you think that, that's a piece that could continue on into 2017 and beyond?

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. That's a difficult question to answer in a short way, Paula. Because, again, I think it is largely a market-by-market discussion because I think that the strategies in each market are not necessarily the same. But we certainly have talked over the ye
componenttext: Yes. That's a difficult question to answer in a short way, Paula. Because, again, I think it is largely a market-by-market discussion because I think that the strategies in each market are not necessarily the same. But we certainly have talked over the years about investing in physician ownership and physician practices. We've invested in information technology so that we have a more integrated approach with our physicians. We've invested in physical facilities and kind of continuing on to what I was saying to John and upgrading our outpatient capabilities in particular. We've acquired a number of outpatient facilities in our markets over the last few years. So again, in the context of having a few more minutes to sort of talk about it, I'd love to sort of talk about maybe some of the individual strategies and individual markets. But suffice it to say at this point, that I think it's a sort of multi-pronged approach in each of our markets.

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 26, 2016

componenttext: Okay. That's fair. And just maybe if I could follow-up. When you talk about sort of the secular improvement and -- how much room do you see for economic improvement in some of your markets? Are we sort of full here? Or do you think there's still some room like in areas like Texas and -- for example?

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Look, I'm not a macro economist by any means, Paula. So I answer questions like this with a lot of trepidation. But I will say that during the recession, we saw the negative impacts of this long and profound recession over the course, I would argue o
componenttext: Yes. Look, I'm not a macro economist by any means, Paula. So I answer questions like this with a lot of trepidation. But I will say that during the recession, we saw the negative impacts of this long and profound recession over the course, I would argue of, in some cases, 4 or 5 years in some of our markets, beginning as early as 2009 and continuing in many of these markets through 2013. And so it would not be surprising to me if the recovery in those same markets was over a similar period. And we're probably 3 years or so in most of these markets into the recovery. So while I think the impact is probably starting to diminish, I would still think we have another year or 2 of positive runway in a lot of these markets.

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good morning. My name is Jennifer, and I will be your  conference operator today. At this time, I would like to welcome everyone to the Universal Health Services First Quarter Earnings Call. [Operator Instructions] Thank you. And Mr. Steve Filton, you may
componenttext: Good morning. My name is Jennifer, and I will be your  conference operator today. At this time, I would like to welcome everyone to the Universal Health Services First Quarter Earnings Call. [Operator Instructions] Thank you. And Mr. Steve Filton, you may begin your conference.

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Jennifer. Good morning. Alan Miller, our CEO, is also joining us this morning. We welcome you to this review of Universal Health Services results for the first quarter ended March 31, 2016. During the conference call Alan and I will be using wo
componenttext:
Thank you, Jennifer. Good morning. Alan Miller, our CEO, is also joining us this morning. We welcome you to this review of Universal Health Services results for the first quarter ended March 31, 2016. During the conference call Alan and I will be using words such as believes, expects, anticipates, estimates and similar words that represent forecasts, projections and forward-looking statements. For anyone not familiar with the risks and uncertainties inherent in these forward-looking statements, I recommend a careful reading of the section on risk factors and forward-looking statements and risk factors in our Form 10-K for the year ended December 31, 2015.  
We'd like to highlight just a couple of developments and business trends before opening the call up to questions.
As discussed in our press release last night, the company reported net income attributable to UHS for diluted share of $1.93 for the quarter. After adjusting for the depreciation and amortization expense associated with the implementation of electronic health records applications at our acute care hospitals, our adjusted net income attributable to UHS per diluted share was $1.98 for the quarter ended March 31, 2016.
On the same facility basis in our acute division revenues increased 12% during the first quarter of 2016. The increase resulted primarily from a 7.8% increase in adjusted admissions and a 3% increase in revenue per adjusted admission.
On a same facility basis, operating margins for our acute care hospitals increased to 21.1% during the first quarter of 2016, from 20.5% during the first quarter of 2015. 
On a same facility basis, revenues in our behavioral health division increased 3.5% during the first quarter of 2016. Adjusted admissions to our behavioral health facilities owned for more than a year increased 1.4% and adjusted patient days increased 1.0% over the prior-year our first quarter. 
Revenue per adjusted patient day rose 2.2% during the first quarter of 2016 over the comparable prior year quarter. On a same facility basis, operating margins for our behavioral health division decreased to 27.8% during the quarter ended March 31, 2016, as compared to 28.4% during the comparable prior year period.
Our cash provided by operating activities increased 71% to approximately $464 million during the first quarter of 2016 as compared to $271 million in the first quarter of 2015. 
Our accounts receivable days outstanding declined to 51 days during the first quarter of 2016, and our ratio of debt-to-total capitalization decreased to 43.3% at March 31, 2016 as compared to 44.6% at March 31, 2015.
We spent $127 million on capital expenditures during the first quarter of 2016. Included in our capital expenditures were the construction cost related to the ongoing construction of a new 142-bed hospital in Henderson, Nevada, which is scheduled to open in the fourth quarter of this year. 
During the first quarter, we opened a total of 182 new behavioral health beds, including 57 [ph] beds opened at a new de novo hospital located in Oklahoma and 125 beds opened at some of our busiest facilities. Many behavioral health construction projects are underway, including 6 new de novo hospitals totaling 562 beds. 
In February of 2016, our Board of Directors authorized a $400 million increase to our stock repurchase program, which increased the aggregate authorization to $800 million. In conjunction with this program during the first quarter of 2016 we repurchased approximately 1.3 million shares of our stock at an aggregate cost of $152 million or approximately $113 per share. 
Since the inception of the program through March 31, 2016, we have repurchased approximately 3.2 million shares at an aggregate cost of $377 million or approximately $117 per share.
Alan and I will be pleased to answer questions at this time.

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016

componenttextpreview: This is [indiscernible] going on for Matt. Regarding behavioral, you had mentioned [indiscernible] of psychiatrists last quarter that led you to turn away patients. Can you provide an update on that as well as an increased expense to attract and retain th
componenttext: This is [indiscernible] going on for Matt. Regarding behavioral, you had mentioned [indiscernible] of psychiatrists last quarter that led you to turn away patients. Can you provide an update on that as well as an increased expense to attract and retain these doctors?

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. So if you look at the behavioral revenue growth for the quarter at about 3.5%, it's pretty consistent of what we were running in the back half of 2015. And I think many of the same dynamics are in place. We had a pretty tough comparison in the first
componenttext: Sure. So if you look at the behavioral revenue growth for the quarter at about 3.5%, it's pretty consistent of what we were running in the back half of 2015. And I think many of the same dynamics are in place. We had a pretty tough comparison in the first quarter of '16, so we were not really disappointed with those numbers. They met our expectations and our behavioral results in general were very much in line with our budget for the quarter. But we continue to face both psychiatrists, nursing and other clinician shortages in some of our markets. And in some cases, that is muting or depressing our -- what would otherwise we think be higher demand and higher volumes. We had a number of initiatives in place to try and rectify those dynamics in those situations. And we believe, as we said at the end of the year, that our behavioral revenue growth should increase as the year goes on as those comparisons become easier and some of those initiatives begin to get more traction.

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Chris Rigg with Susquehanna Financial.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Chris Rigg with Susquehanna Financial.

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is Frank Lee on for Chris. Seems like revenue in the acute care business was very strong in the quarter. Do you have a sense for how much of the growth was attributable to economic improvements in your market or increasing market share? And are you a
componenttext: This is Frank Lee on for Chris. Seems like revenue in the acute care business was very strong in the quarter. Do you have a sense for how much of the growth was attributable to economic improvements in your market or increasing market share? And are you able to size the impact of the leap year for the quarter?

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, look I think it's always difficult to precisely size the impact of leap year. I think on an admissions basis, extra day just mathematically gives you about 3% more admissions. But in terms of overall revenue, it's a little bit harder to do. Obviousl
componenttext: Well, look I think it's always difficult to precisely size the impact of leap year. I think on an admissions basis, extra day just mathematically gives you about 3% more admissions. But in terms of overall revenue, it's a little bit harder to do. Obviously however you slice it, the revenue growth in the acute care division for the quarter was extremely strong and well in excess of the 6% revenue growth that we anticipated in our guidance and in our budget for the year. Again, I think it's difficult to parse that growth out into individual pieces. We still continue to get some benefit from the ACA and expanded Medicaid enrollment and new commercial exchange enrollment, although certainly that benefit is diminishing. And now that we're into its third year, we continue to benefit as our markets improve economically and that certainly continues as well. But I think one of the most encouraging aspects of the quarter from our perspective is the single the biggest admission growth for us was in our Medicare payer class. And in theory, Medicare patients are probably largely unimpacted by both the ACA dynamics and by an improving economy. And so I think what that's reflective of is just general strength of the franchises that we're operating in our local markets and the initiatives that our operators have put in place for some time now to create more and more physician integration in our markets to focus on really important service lines to us, like orthopedics and cardiology, and to really just focus on business development. I think that we have had for 4 or 5 quarters among the industry-leading admissions from an acute care perspective. And while I know the other companies have yet to report, my guess is we'll certainly be in that position again this quarter.

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then the bad debt ratio was pretty flat year-over-year after a few quarters of volatility. Do you think that the bad debt has stabilized at this point, and do you have a view on where that will go for the rest of the year?
componenttext: Okay. And then the bad debt ratio was pretty flat year-over-year after a few quarters of volatility. Do you think that the bad debt has stabilized at this point, and do you have a view on where that will go for the rest of the year?

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Always difficult as Yogi Berra would say to predict the future. But for us, I think again very strong payer mix in the first quarter. Medicare admission growth growing faster than our overall admissions. Medicaid growing at about the same pace as our over
componenttext: Always difficult as Yogi Berra would say to predict the future. But for us, I think again very strong payer mix in the first quarter. Medicare admission growth growing faster than our overall admissions. Medicaid growing at about the same pace as our overall admissions. Commercial admissions growing slightly lower. But uninsured admissions, flat to actually slightly down. And obviously that is an extremely favorable payer mix. Again, hard to say exactly how sustainable that is. But I think we generally feel like the acute care business is running very strongly at the moment and certainly makes sense of what was possible in our guidance and in our budget, which is extremely achievable at this point.

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016

componenttext: This is [indiscernible] for Kevin today. Just going back to Peter's commentary on [indiscernible] volumes in the acute care business.
