componenttext: Steve, can you talk about surgery and any particular strength in any service lines in the quarter, maybe ER and if you can touch on behavioral and health you're acute side, RTC volumes that had been turned in?

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: So on the acute side with, generally I would say that decides that sort of payer mix commentary that I've offered before, we've seen extreme strength in our surgical volumes, I think in patient surgeries were up something like 4% in the quarter, outpatien
componenttext: So on the acute side with, generally I would say that decides that sort of payer mix commentary that I've offered before, we've seen extreme strength in our surgical volumes, I think in patient surgeries were up something like 4% in the quarter, outpatient surgeries were up like 7%, which is again some of the strongest surgical growth we've seen. Our Medicare case mix index was among the highest ever seen. I think that's reflective of surgical volume and continue the trend that we saw in Q4. So obviously, I think beyond the volume strength, which we've already commented on, we're seeing a lot of sort of high-quality revenue and high acuity revenue strength as well. On the behavioral side, I will say, I mean the one sort of issue between the acute and the residential business is, the residential business is not subject, I think, nearly as much to this whole psychiatry shortage issue. So the residential admissions have probably held in a little bit stronger than the acute admissions. And frankly I think at least from a cosmetic perspective, that tends to hurt us because at least the public companies we than to have a behavioral revenue sort of profile that is weighted more to the acute rather than to the residential.

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: And the ER trends in the quarter?
componenttext: And the ER trends in the quarter?

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think the ER trends are pretty consistent with the overall volume trends where we are in the markets. We're seeing admission growth. We're seeing some generally some fairly high ER growth. I will say that in a couple of markets where we are seeing more
componenttext: I think the ER trends are pretty consistent with the overall volume trends where we are in the markets. We're seeing admission growth. We're seeing some generally some fairly high ER growth. I will say that in a couple of markets where we are seeing more of a proliferation of urgent care and FED tech development, freestanding ED development. We've seen our ED business go down a little bit. But honestly our admissions in most of those markets are unimpacted as we continue to get those admissions to our hospitals.

componenttext: I think those trends have remained fairly constant.

componenttext: Got it. And my last question is just back on the IMD. And my understanding is that the rule is effective this July, allowing health plans to contract with providers. Is that your understanding as well. And from a practical standpoint, when do you think you can actually take admissions of this patient population?

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think your interpretation is correct, Whit, in the sense that what the rule provides for is that states have the option of listing the IMD exclusion and effectively allowing freestanding facilities to begin to take these patients as early as July. Again
componenttext: I think your interpretation is correct, Whit, in the sense that what the rule provides for is that states have the option of listing the IMD exclusion and effectively allowing freestanding facilities to begin to take these patients as early as July. Again it's at the state's option, and we're not sure exactly what each state will do. We are anticipating that at least in some geographies, we'll be able to begin to have access to those patients as early as July.

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: First of all, I guess I'll ask on the cost trends in the acute side. So I know sometimes when you have strong volume, you get the leverage of your existing SWB base as well as supplies, et cetera, flowing through the margin side. And sometimes the growth
componenttext: First of all, I guess I'll ask on the cost trends in the acute side. So I know sometimes when you have strong volume, you get the leverage of your existing SWB base as well as supplies, et cetera, flowing through the margin side. And sometimes the growth and volume is strong for an extended period you start to having to add staff or scrambling to get staff. Where are you at on that spectrum and how would you put that quarter in context for that maybe a little bit?

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: I mean in the back half of 2015, AJ, we talked about the idea that there was certainly some pressure on salary and wages within the acute division, not so much in terms of headcount or numbers of employees but in what we described as premium pay, which wo
componenttext: I mean in the back half of 2015, AJ, we talked about the idea that there was certainly some pressure on salary and wages within the acute division, not so much in terms of headcount or numbers of employees but in what we described as premium pay, which would include payments like use of temporary nurses in overtime for our own spend, et cetera. I think we've made some improvement in that regard, we continue with a revenue growth we saw in Q1 and with admission growth in demand. We continue to see pressure on those wage rates and on that premium pay. And as a consequence, I think we've been able to drill down and you can see it in our consolidated results that most of the leverage that we're getting on the strong revenue growth is on the supply and other operating expense line and less of it is on the salary wage line because we're still seeing a fair amount of pricing pressure if you will on that line.

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016

componenttext: Okay. All right. And then you guys -- the buyback authorization doubled it. componenttext: I think in some cases, we already have contracts in place. We have been taking adolescent Medicaid patients for many years. And so in a number of geographies and a number of instances, we already have existing managed care contracts for the adolescent Medicaid population. And we can either extend those contracts to the adult population or just modify them, et cetera It varies a little bit in every geography but I do not believe that contract increase of this whole line of exercise is the more difficult piece. I think and then is those conversations and hopefully those collaborative agreements with the acute care hospitals that are really at the crux of it.

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: My question was about just to go a little deeper in the exposures and the drivers of this Medicare-based volume that you're seeing on the acute side. I'm trying to understand if you can see, from your payer mix or any anecdotal evidence, that this is just
componenttext: My question was about just to go a little deeper in the exposures and the drivers of this Medicare-based volume that you're seeing on the acute side. I'm trying to understand if you can see, from your payer mix or any anecdotal evidence, that this is just new members that are aging into Medicare that perhaps were underinsured or uninsured during their pre-medicare days? Or is it existing patients in your marketing more aggressively as the hospital change? Or is it any difference fee-for-service Medicare and Medicare Advantage?

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: So on a, I mean a few different comments on that. We continue to see over time a shift out of traditional Medicare into Medicare Advantage. And that continues and I expect it will continue for some time. What I was trying to allude to the board and maybe
componenttext: So on a, I mean a few different comments on that. We continue to see over time a shift out of traditional Medicare into Medicare Advantage. And that continues and I expect it will continue for some time. What I was trying to allude to the board and maybe to [ph] nuance it, I think the idea that our Medicare population and admission is growing as quickly as it is, almost by definition that we're taking market share. Because while the overall Medicare population could be expanding somewhat, it is certainly not expanding at the pace our admissions are expanding. So I think almost by definition, the fact that our Medicare population is growing as much as it did is suggesting that in many of our markets, we are taking market share from our competitors. And I think its because of all the focus, et cetera that our operators are bringing to service lines and to physician relationships. And I think all of that is paying dividends.

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. So it's about market share. Is the 2 [ph] changes take forever sometimes. We had the 2-midnight rule lap. And then recently, I think CMS is backing off of that rule altogether. Simultaneously they'll be value-based of solely 25,000 [ph] primary care
componenttext: Okay. So it's about market share. Is the 2 [ph] changes take forever sometimes. We had the 2-midnight rule lap. And then recently, I think CMS is backing off of that rule altogether. Simultaneously they'll be value-based of solely 25,000 [ph] primary care physician pilots they put in place. So once positive end of tailwind feels like a bit of a headwind but maybe more long term  I mean how is this going to play out through '15 [ph] and then '17 in terms of the timing, positive or negative on a net basis?

componenttext: Look, I think Ana, as your question suggests, I think its difficult to predict for some of these things how they're going to affect macro trends. And I think to the degree that they affect macro trends, it will be over a longer period of time. So I think from our perspective, it is not likely to have significant short or even intermediate term impacts. Over the longer-term we'll see.

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Ana, we've conceded on several occasions that the increase in uncompensated volumes back in the third quarter of '15 which we experienced quite frankly many of our peers seem to experience as well was something that we really couldn't explain with great c
componenttext: Ana, we've conceded on several occasions that the increase in uncompensated volumes back in the third quarter of '15 which we experienced quite frankly many of our peers seem to experience as well was something that we really couldn't explain with great confidence. People suggest that at the time, that maybe it was some level of disenrollment in commercial exchanges as premiums were  going up or people has gotten the care that they were seeking. We can never sort of prove that in any kind of pervasive way. But I think what our experience in Q4 and Q1 would suggest it was, was that it was a bit of an anomaly and a bit of a blip in that the uncompensated trends, which have been more stable in the last couple of quarters seem to be more reflective of the environment that we're really in.

componenttext: Maybe some comments for your priorities to reduce capital at this point. It seems like the average repurchase price for your shares is a little bit where the stock is now which I guess is a good thing. headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Gary, I think we always say, and we say it because I think we mean it, that we are relatively agnostic about where we deploy our capital meaning that we will likely deploy our capital wherever we think we kind of earn the best returns. And I think that we
componenttext: Gary, I think we always say, and we say it because I think we mean it, that we are relatively agnostic about where we deploy our capital meaning that we will likely deploy our capital wherever we think we kind of earn the best returns. And I think that we were an active share purchaser in the first quarter and continued to some degree into the second quarter because we thought our shares have, particularly given the strength of our business were an attractive investment. I think we'll continue to consider that as we move forward. I think we've also said that we see a number of compelling M&A opportunities in both the behavioral and acute space. And we have the financial flexibility to pursue those and we will. I think we have long-standing and well earned reputation. However, as a judicious acquired and a judicious evaluator of these opportunities and judicious steward of capital I think we'll continue to [indiscernible] that in the future opportunities. We never really prioritize because in our minds the priorities are as we see these specific opportunities and as we evaluate these specific opportunities.

componenttext: I think we are. And I think as we said before we continue to be actively involved in a number of conversations in that regard. We just find that those processes in those conversations tend to be a bit elongated and they take some time. But we believe, as I said before, that with some high degree of confidence that we will deploy capital into the acute care business in 2016 at levels that we probably have not in a while.

componenttext: Can you talk about the growth that you're seeing so far this year in [indiscernible] the business? In the past you've talked about occupancy rates in the 90% range. So maybe you could update us on any near-term plans to add to that market?

componenttextpreview: Sure. So I think everything you said remains true. We are running occupancy rates in the U.K. both in -- it's still a relatively new business for us. But in the Cygnet business that we bought 1.5 years ago and the Alpha business that we bought maybe 6 mon
componenttext: Sure. So I think everything you said remains true. We are running occupancy rates in the U.K. both in -- it's still a relatively new business for us. But in the Cygnet business that we bought 1.5 years ago and the Alpha business that we bought maybe 6 months ago, we're seeing those very high occupancy rates. And as a result, we're really taking all the actions in the U.K. that we've been taking in the U.S. for many years and that is we're adding this to existing facilities where the demand justifies that. We are building some de novo facilities in the U.K. where the demand justifies that. We've done some tuck-in acquisitions in the U.K. We did a larger acquisition with the Alpha deal 6 months ago as I've said. And we continue to look at all those kinds of opportunities, future opportunities in the U.K. as well with all the same set of caveats and dynamics that I described here in the U.S. So we'll deploy capital in the U.K. behavioral space if it makes compelling sense to us and we're looking aggressively to do that.

componenttext: Got it. And could you slice for us how many beds that you know that you're adding so far just with a growth with existing facilities and the de novo startup plans for this year? What is the overall bed growth for the U.K. going to look like?

componenttextpreview: I will do that. And then my last one, just going through the concept of the new IMD regulation. Do you have a sense of where your presumably newly-negotiated Medicaid per diem might shake out versus general acute care hospitals or maybe where your current
componenttext: I will do that. And then my last one, just going through the concept of the new IMD regulation. Do you have a sense of where your presumably newly-negotiated Medicaid per diem might shake out versus general acute care hospitals or maybe where your current child and adolescent Medicaid per diems kind of shake out versus hospital. I guess what I'm trying to get at is do we think given presumably a lower cost structure in freestanding, that from a rate perspective, we might get to the point where Medicaid HMOs have a compelling financial incentive to attempt to steer volume in your direction as opposed to just picking up, initially, probably the ER-diverted patient that they can't find a bed for?

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Look, it's really I think thoughtful question, Gary. And again, we're set of approaching this in kind of 2 phase process. I mean the one as I stress is we would like to reach collaborative agreements with many of the acute care hospitals in our marke
componenttext: Yes. Look, it's really I think thoughtful question, Gary. And again, we're set of approaching this in kind of 2 phase process. I mean the one as I stress is we would like to reach collaborative agreements with many of the acute care hospitals in our markets that are providing inpatient behavioral services. We think, generally, and this is certainly not true of any single acute care hospital. But we think generally, acute care hospital are not very good providers. They're not efficient providers of behavioral services. They have so many other things that they're doing that it's just not a top priority of theirs. And we generally feel we can do it better, we can with higher quality conflict with better efficiency and we're trying to make that argument acute care colleagues and markets around the country. I think in our minds, that's sort of the first step in getting access to these adult Medicaid patients. The second is more I think along the lines of what you're suggesting which is as a freestanding industry and certainly UHS I think has the ability to be able to provide these services more efficiently, and at both high-quality and lower costs, then we're certainly prepared to make those arguments into our managed care payer. But quite frankly, I think as you are aware of that dynamic as we are with the rest of their patient population. So that is a secondary argument. We'd like to get the acute hospitals to sort of partner with us first and then we'll kind of make our pitch to the MCOs.

componenttext: Good morning. My name is Jennifer, and I will be your conference operator today. At this time, I would like to welcome everyone to the Universal Health Services First Quarter Earnings Call. [Operator Instructions] Thank you, and Mr. Steve Filton, you may begin your conference.

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Jennifer. Good morning. Alan Miller, our CEO, is also joining us this morning. We welcome you to this review of Universal Health Services results for the first quarter ended March 31, 2016. During the conference call, Alan and I will be using w
componenttext:
Thank you, Jennifer. Good morning. Alan Miller, our CEO, is also joining us this morning. We welcome you to this review of Universal Health Services results for the first quarter ended March 31, 2016. During the conference call, Alan and I will be using words such as believes, expects, anticipates, estimates and similar words that represent forecasts, projections and forward-looking statements. For anyone not familiar with the risks and uncertainties inherent in these forward-looking statements, I recommend a careful reading of the section on risk factors and forward-looking statements and risk factors in our Form 10-K for the year ended December 31, 2015. We'd like to highlight just a couple of developments and business trends before opening the call up to questions.
As discussed in our press release last night, the company reported net income attributable to UHS per diluted share of $1.93 for the quarter. After adjusting for the depreciation and amortization expense associated with the implementation of electronic health records applications at our acute care hospitals, our adjusted net income attributable to UHS per diluted share was $1.98 for the quarter ended March 31, 2016. On the same facility basis in our acute division revenues, increased 12% during the first quarter of 2016. The increase resulted primarily from a 7.8% increase in adjusted admissions and a 3% increase in revenue per adjusted admission. On a same facility basis, operating margins for our acute care hospitals increased to 21.1% during the first quarter of 2016 from 20.5% during the first quarter of 2015. On a same facility basis, revenues in our behavioral health division increased 3.5% during the first quarter of 2016. Adjusted admissions to our behavioral health facilities owned for more than a year increased 1.4%, and adjusted patient days increased 1.0% over the prior-year first quarter. 
Revenue per adjusted patient day rose 2.2% during the first quarter of 2016 over the comparable prior year quarter. On a same facility basis, operating margins for our behavioral health division decreased to 27.8% during the quarter, ended March 31, 2016, as compared to 28.4% during the comparable prior year period. Our cash provided by operating activities increased 71% to approximately $464 million during the first quarter of 2016, as compared to $271 million in the first quarter of 2015. Our accounts receivable days outstanding declined to 51 days during the first quarter of 2016, and our ratio of debt-to-total capitalization decreased to 43.3% at March 31, 2016 as compared to 44.6% at March 31, 2015. We spent $127 million on capital expenditures during the first quarter of 2016. Included in our capital expenditures were the construction cost related to the ongoing construction of a new 142-bed hospital in Henderson, Nevada, which is scheduled to open in the fourth quarter of this year. 
During the first quarter, we opened a total of 182 new behavioral health beds, including 57 beds opened at a new de novo hospital located in Oklahoma and 125 beds opened at some of our busiest facilities. Many behavioral health construction projects are underway, including 6 new de novo hospitals totaling 562 beds. In February of 2016, our Board of Directors authorized a $400 million increase to our stock repurchase program, which increased the aggregate authorization to $800 million. In conjunction with this program during the first quarter of 2016, we repurchased approximately 1.3 million shares of our stock at an aggregate cost of $152 million or approximately $113 per share. 
Since the inception of the program through March 31, 2016, we have repurchased approximately 3.2 million shares at an aggregate cost of $377 million or approximately $117 per share.
Alan and I will be pleased to answer questions at this time.

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016

componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Our first question comes from the line of Matthew Borsch with Goldman Sachs.

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is Tejus Ujjani, on for Matt. Regarding behavioral, you had mentioned a shortage of psychiatrists last quarter that led you to turn away patients. Can you provide any update on that as well as any increase in expense to attract and retain these docto
componenttext: This is Tejus Ujjani, on for Matt. Regarding behavioral, you had mentioned a shortage of psychiatrists last quarter that led you to turn away patients. Can you provide any update on that as well as any increase in expense to attract and retain these doctors?

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. So if you look at the behavioral revenue growth for the quarter of about 3.5%, it's pretty consistent of what we were running in the back half of 2015, and I think many of the same dynamics are in place. We had a pretty tough comparison in the first
componenttext: Sure. So if you look at the behavioral revenue growth for the quarter of about 3.5%, it's pretty consistent of what we were running in the back half of 2015, and I think many of the same dynamics are in place. We had a pretty tough comparison in the first quarter of '16, so we were not really disappointed with those numbers. They met our expectations and our behavioral results in general were very much in line with our budget for the quarter, but we continue to face both psychiatrist, nursing and other clinician shortages in some of our markets. And in some cases, that is muting or depressing our -- what would otherwise we think be higher demand and higher volumes. We had a number of initiatives in place to try and rectify those dynamics in those situations. And we believe, as we said at the end of the year, that our behavioral revenue growth should increase as the year goes on, as those comparisons become easier and as some of those initiatives begin to get more traction.

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Chris Rigg with Susquehanna Financial.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Chris Rigg with Susquehanna Financial.

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is Frank Lee, on for Chris. Same store revenue in the acute care business was very strong in the quarter. Do you have a sense for how much of the growth was attributable to economic improvements in your market or increasing market share, and are you
componenttext: This is Frank Lee, on for Chris. Same store revenue in the acute care business was very strong in the quarter. Do you have a sense for how much of the growth was attributable to economic improvements in your market or increasing market share, and are you able to size the impact of the leap year for the quarter?

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, look, I think it's always difficult to precisely size the impact of leap year. I think on an admissions basis, the extra day just mathematically gives you about 3% more admissions. But in terms of overall revenue, it's a little bit harder to do. Obvi
componenttext: Yes, look, I think it's always difficult to precisely size the impact of leap year. I think on an admissions basis, the extra day just mathematically gives you about 3% more admissions. But in terms of overall revenue, it's a little bit harder to do. Obviously, however you slice it, the revenue growth in the acute care division for the quarter was extremely strong and well in excess of the 6% revenue growth that we anticipated in our guidance and in our budget for the year. Again, I think it's difficult to parse that growth out into individual pieces. We still continue to get some benefit from the ACA and expanded Medicaid enrollment and new commercial exchange enrollment, although, certainly, that benefit is diminishing. And now that we're into its third year, we continue to benefit, as our markets improve economically, and that certainly continues as well. But I think one of the most encouraging aspects of the quarter from our perspective is the single biggest admission growth for us was in our Medicare payer class. And in theory, Medicare patients are probably largely un-impacted by both the ACA dynamics and by an improving economy. And so I think what that's reflective of is just general strength of the franchises that we're operating in our local markets and the initiatives that our operators have put in place for some time now to create more and more physician integration in our markets to focus on really important service lines to us, like orthopedics and cardiology, and to really just focus on business development. I think that we have had for 4 or 5 quarters among the industry-leading admissions from an acute care perspective, and while I know the other companies have yet to report, my guess is we'll certainly be in that position again this quarter.

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then the bad debt ratio was pretty flat year-over-year after a few quarters of volatility. Do you think that the bad debt has stabilized at this point, and do you have a view on where that will go for the rest of the year?
componenttext: Okay. And then the bad debt ratio was pretty flat year-over-year after a few quarters of volatility. Do you think that the bad debt has stabilized at this point, and do you have a view on where that will go for the rest of the year?

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Always difficult, as Yogi Berra would say, to predict the future. But for us, I think, again, very strong payer mix in the first quarter, Medicare admission growth growing faster than our overall admissions. Medicaid growing in about the same pace as our
componenttext: Always difficult, as Yogi Berra would say, to predict the future. But for us, I think, again, very strong payer mix in the first quarter, Medicare admission growth growing faster than our overall admissions. Medicaid growing in about the same pace as our overall admissions, commercial admissions growing slightly lower. But uninsured admissions, flat to actually slightly down, and obviously, that is an extremely favorable payer mix. Again, hard to say exactly how sustainable that is. But I think we generally feel like the acute care business is running very strongly at the moment, and certainly makes our sense of what was possible in our guidance and in our budget seem extremely achievable at this point.

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Kevin Fischbeck with Bank of America Merrill Lynch.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Kevin Fischbeck with Bank of America Merrill Lynch.

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is Joanna Gajuk, filling in for Kevin today. So just going back to Peter's commentary around trends in the volumes in acute care business, so that was helpful. But also, can you talk about the markets because, I guess, it seems like Vegas, I guess, w
componenttext: This is Joanna Gajuk, filling in for Kevin today. So just going back to Peter's commentary around trends in the volumes in acute care business, so that was helpful. But also, can you talk about the markets because, I guess, it seems like Vegas, I guess, was indicating that things are going well there. So anything that changed maybe in other markets or should we just think about some of the trends also in 2015 in terms of strong -- Nevada and California and Texas, not that strong. Any color in terms of the market performance on that exercise?

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure, Joanna. I mean, I think that the practical reality is when you post revenue numbers as strong as we did in Q1. The strength, by definition, has to be pretty pervasive. It's almost impossible for a single market to drive those kinds of overall strong
componenttext: Sure, Joanna. I mean, I think that the practical reality is when you post revenue numbers as strong as we did in Q1. The strength, by definition, has to be pretty pervasive. It's almost impossible for a single market to drive those kinds of overall strong numbers. Generally, however, I would just sort of comment that many of the trends that we've remarked on in recent quarters have remained in place. You alluded to the fact that our Vegas market has been performing quite well and that continued into Q1. Our Southern California market also performed very well. Our Temecula Hospital, which is now in its third year of operation is performing particularly well, and that's driving some very strong numbers out of Riverside County, California. Washington, DC has been a strong market for us and wasn't in Q1. We see some weakness in the South Texas markets, which we remarked on previously, although even their volume numbers were certainly improved in Q1 as well.

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great. And then changing the topics a little bit on the behavior side. I guess in terms of the recent regulation, rather, the final [indiscernible] from CMS around managed Medicaid and around management -- plans to pay for adult behavior help the increase
componenttext: Great. And then changing the topics a little bit on the behavior side. I guess in terms of the recent regulation, rather, the final [indiscernible] from CMS around managed Medicaid and around management -- plans to pay for adult behavior help the increase in facilities. So when we think about it, how are you going to think about taking -- these changes taking effects in reality for you specifically? How long, I guess, it would take for the full patterns really to change? Should we think about this would take 1 year or longer in terms of how it would actually be reflected in your operations?

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, again, I think, Joanna, our commentary on the lifting of the IMD exclusion has been, I think, reasonably consistent over time. And that is, we, I think like the others in the freestanding behavioral industry view the lifting of the IMD exclusion cer
componenttext: Well, again, I think, Joanna, our commentary on the lifting of the IMD exclusion has been, I think, reasonably consistent over time. And that is, we, I think like the others in the freestanding behavioral industry view the lifting of the IMD exclusion certainly as a positive development, albeit one that will show its impact or reflect its impact gradually over time. It will require some effort to get access to this patient population. And I think we've always said it's difficult to quantify what the potential benefit will be at the outset. But we, I think, share what is generally a consensus view that the benefit and the potential benefit is significant. I'll also make the point and I know we've talked about this a number of times previously that we view the lifting of the IMD exclusion and our ability to take these patients that have previously been seen in acute care hospitals with behavioral units in a broader context of trying to integrate with the behavioral units in acute care hospitals in our markets for all their patients. We have opened, over the course of the last few years, a number of leased units that we are -- leased behavioral units that we are leasing from some big, not-for-profit acute care hospital systems around the country. We have a number of other similar conversations underway to accomplish the same thing. And while the lifting of the IMD exclusion might help accelerate and expedite those conversations, because now we can treat adult Medicaid patients as well, most of those conversations are even broader than that and include Medicare patients. They include commercial patients. And frankly, we view that overall as one of the most significant business development opportunities for our behavioral hospitals over the course of the next few years. So it's an important development, but I think one that fits into really kind of an overall strategy that we're extremely enthusiastic about.

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: [indiscernible] but those changes will take time, currently very positive. But then, I guess, on the flip side, the commentary around the continued shortage of clinicians on the behavioral side. I guess with those changes and potential, I guess, for addit
componenttext: [indiscernible] but those changes will take time, currently very positive. But then, I guess, on the flip side, the commentary around the continued shortage of clinicians on the behavioral side. I guess with those changes and potential, I guess, for additional volumes coming your way, would, I guess, the shortage make things, I guess, more difficult when this is really happening where you have the IMD exclusion, but then this would actually create more pressure on labor. So is that the way you think about it or you kind of think that there's some spike in terms of the shortages will kind of moderate or rather be able to offset that?

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'm going to answer the question quickly because I want to give others on the call a chance to ask their questions as well. But I think the issue to keep in mind is that this adult Medicaid population that's affected by the IMD, for the most part is curre
componenttext: I'm going to answer the question quickly because I want to give others on the call a chance to ask their questions as well. But I think the issue to keep in mind is that this adult Medicaid population that's affected by the IMD, for the most part is currently being treated. They're being treated in acute care hospitals with behavioral units and there is staff. There are nurses. There are psychiatrists in place today treating those patients. So if we can reach agreement with acute care hospitals in our markets to get access to those patients, whether we lease the beds or manage the units or joint venture the units, where they close their units. The presumption, I think, on our part and what has played out at least in our initial conversation is we will have access not only to the patients, but also to the clinicians who are treating those patients. So it's not as if we will have an incremental need to hire staff to treat those patients. So can we move on to the next...

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: The next question comes from the line of Paula Torch with Avondale Partners.
componenttext: The next question comes from the line of Paula Torch with Avondale Partners.

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'd like to start my first question on the strong acute care metric. So I wonder, Steve, can you talk about the pace of volume throughout the quarter, and maybe if we saw a pick up through to March and has that momentum continued into 2Q?
componenttext: I'd like to start my first question on the strong acute care metric. So I wonder, Steve, can you talk about the pace of volume throughout the quarter, and maybe if we saw a pick up through to March and has that momentum continued into 2Q?

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think, Paula, our experience, what seems to me was the share sort industry experience based on commentary I've heard from others and some of the surveys that I saw during the quarter, the quarter got off to a relatively slow start, I think, probabl
componenttext: Yes, I think, Paula, our experience, what seems to me was the share sort industry experience based on commentary I've heard from others and some of the surveys that I saw during the quarter, the quarter got off to a relatively slow start, I think, probably as a result of a very late flu season. Volumes picked up in February -- maybe later January, and then February. And then at least for us, March was a very strong month. Again we do get the benefit of the leap year day and some of the calendar timing with Easter and Good Friday, et cetera. But also, I think it's early in the second quarter, but most of the trends seem to be holding up reasonably well. Again, I'm not about to predict that we can sustain that sort of really remarkable acute care growth we saw in Q1, but we feel just good generally about how things are going in our markets and how strong the underlying business is.

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, great. And then on behavioral, certainly, a nice uptick year-over-year in the net revenue per patient or adjusted admission, but maybe not as much as we were expecting given these year compares. So maybe can you give us some color on what drove that
componenttext: Okay, great. And then on behavioral, certainly, a nice uptick year-over-year in the net revenue per patient or adjusted admission, but maybe not as much as we were expecting given these year compares. So maybe can you give us some color on what drove that? It seems like the results metric expectations, but just wondering what gives you the confidence to be able to reach sort of your 5% same-store revenue growth in 2016, which would certainly apply a ramp-up from here.

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. So you're absolutely right, Paula. It implies a ramp and for those who remember, I think we specifically talked about that in our year-end call, saying that we believe that the 5% behavioral growth was achievable, but would likely be somewhat lower
componenttext: Sure. So you're absolutely right, Paula. It implies a ramp and for those who remember, I think we specifically talked about that in our year-end call, saying that we believe that the 5% behavioral growth was achievable, but would likely be somewhat lower in the first half of the year when comparisons were more difficult than while we were implementing and trying to gain tractions on some of our recruitment strategies and strategies to fill those nurse and psychiatrist vacancies. And then the second half of the year would become easier to achieve the 5%, and probably exceed it as the comparisons became easier and those initiatives got traction. So again, from our own perspective, the Q1 behavioral performance was almost precisely in line, and obviously, that provides us with a challenge to improve as the year goes on. But that's the way -- that was our expectation of the way the year would play out.

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. Can I squeeze one more in? If not, I'll move on.
componenttext: Okay. Can I squeeze one more in? If not, I'll move on.

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Quickly, quickly.
componenttext: Quickly, quickly.

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, sure. So just your occupancy and behavioral, I think it was about 76%. So it still shows some room there with the beds you currently have, and you're adding another 500 beds throughout the rest of the year. So I'm wondering how we should think about
componenttext: Okay, sure. So just your occupancy and behavioral, I think it was about 76%. So it still shows some room there with the beds you currently have, and you're adding another 500 beds throughout the rest of the year. So I'm wondering how we should think about filling those beds. Is that potential to fill them with Medicaid advantage lives? Or is the mix going to be more towards doing some of these JV partnerships with non-for-profits? Just wondering how you can leverage your current bed occupancy versus just having to add new beds for this new volume that's going to be coming into the system?

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. So I mean. If you go back and look, you will see that our occupancy percentage in the behavioral business in that sort of high 70, 76%, 77% range, has really been very consistent, I would say, for the last 7 or 8 years. And what that means is that du
componenttext: Yes. So I mean. If you go back and look, you will see that our occupancy percentage in the behavioral business in that sort of high 70, 76%, 77% range, has really been very consistent, I would say, for the last 7 or 8 years. And what that means is that during that period, we've been adding beds fairly aggressively, and obviously, the implication is we are filling those beds as quickly as we're adding them and maintaining our occupancy percentage. The reason we're adding beds with the 76% occupancy level is because in markets and in situations, we're clearly turning away patients because of volume constraints. And the economics of it are such that after you turned away more than just a handful of patients, it almost always make sense to add beds, and so we continue to do that. Now I will say that in my remarks where I talked about, for instance, the de novo development projects, those projects were undertaken really without regard to the IMD exclusion. Obviously, these been under development for some time. And so those projects are all in our minds justified by the demand in those markets, regardless of whether or not there is sort of incremental demand associated with the IMD. So as I said, I mean, in some ways, I think those are sort of of discrete kind of activities. I think we think that the overall demand for behaviorial has been strong, continues to be strong. We're going to add that to meet that. And at the same time, we're going to continue these conversations with acute care hospitals in our markets to get access to their behavioral patients and all their behavioral patients, not just their adult Medicaid patients, but their commercial and their Medicare and any other patients as well.

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Ralph Giacobbe with Citigroup.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Ralph Giacobbe with Citigroup.

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Steve, is it your sense that market growth within your geographic regions are just experiencing sort of similar levels of growth? Or can you share any sort of market dynamics you can point to on why you maybe growing disproportionately faster than others,
componenttext: Steve, is it your sense that market growth within your geographic regions are just experiencing sort of similar levels of growth? Or can you share any sort of market dynamics you can point to on why you maybe growing disproportionately faster than others, whether it be struggles of other maybe non-for-profits, maybe hospital closures, anything along those lines that you can kind of point to above and beyond, obviously, your own initiatives?

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure, Ralph. I think it's a combination of both. I mean, we've talked about this certainly before that. Obviously, we are in some markets that were hit fairly hard during the recession 3 or 4 years ago. Las Vegas, Southern California, South Florida had di
componenttext: Sure, Ralph. I think it's a combination of both. I mean, we've talked about this certainly before that. Obviously, we are in some markets that were hit fairly hard during the recession 3 or 4 years ago. Las Vegas, Southern California, South Florida had disproportionately higher unemployment rates in those markets than national averages, et cetera. So as those markets have recovered, I think we have benefited economically, disproportionately, perhaps, than some of our peers. But I think at the same time, and I think the strong start to 2016 really belies this idea, that as the ACA benefit has really sort of largely anniversary-ed itself as the economic improvement has largely anniversary-ed itself, I think what you're seeing in the beginning of 2016 is the strengthening of our franchise is in those now very healthy markets, et cetera. We've been working a lot over the last few years to shore up our physician relationships and our physician integration arrangements, acquiring practices and integrating in other ways, focusing on certain service lines, and I think that's all really starting to pay dividends. And again, I'll highlight what I did earlier in an earlier response, which is when that growth is in Medicare, I think it's a reflection of the fact that we're probably gaining market share. Since that, that's not a patient population that is inherently growing or seeing more demand, et cetera. So we have not historically sort of really tried to parse out market by market share data, but I think we generally feel that in most of these markets that are performing well, not only are the market's doing well, but that we're gaining market share in those markets as well.

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. All right. That's fair. And then I mean, I guess, that brings up sort of the -- what you see on sort of the acquisition opportunity side, I mean, to the extent that you are seeing struggles, yet you haven't done an acute care acquisition in a while.
componenttext: Okay. All right. That's fair. And then I mean, I guess, that brings up sort of the -- what you see on sort of the acquisition opportunity side, I mean, to the extent that you are seeing struggles, yet you haven't done an acute care acquisition in a while. I mean, do you think those opportunities are going to present or do you think that maybe people aren't growing as much as you may or others maybe not be growing as you much as you are now, but they're still showing healthy growth, and so you think there's still a reluctance to have sort of willing sellers out there?

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Look, I think we have said and you have heard me say for the last several quarters that the pace of activity, particularly in the acute care M&A side has picked up. Now that means conversations and processes, et cetera. And our experiences on the acute si
componenttext: Look, I think we have said and you have heard me say for the last several quarters that the pace of activity, particularly in the acute care M&A side has picked up. Now that means conversations and processes, et cetera. And our experiences on the acute side, that takes some time. These are largely not for profits that are being sold and their decision-making process tends to be somewhat elongated. But we've said for sometime, we're confident that there will be opportunities. There'll be compelling opportunities. And as I sit here today, I'll say with even greater confidence that I think we will definitely have opportunities in 2016 to deploy capital in the acute care space that we will find compelling, and I believe others will as well.

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, that's helpful. Last quick one, just to clarify. I think did you mention -- did you say that you thought the leap day impact was a 3% benefit to volume or was there other factors that maybe drove 3% growth?
componenttext: Okay, that's helpful. Last quick one, just to clarify. I think did you mention -- did you say that you thought the leap day impact was a 3% benefit to volume or was there other factors that maybe drove 3% growth?

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, so I mean basically, all I'm saying is if you have 90 days in the quarter and there's an extra day, it's a little over 3% just natural admission growth that you're likely to see. But it's also a little bit hard to then sort of parse that into a reven
componenttext: Yes, so I mean basically, all I'm saying is if you have 90 days in the quarter and there's an extra day, it's a little over 3% just natural admission growth that you're likely to see. But it's also a little bit hard to then sort of parse that into a revenue piece, because, obviously, not all of our revenue reimbursement is on a per day basis. So the comment that I was making before was mostly about admission growth in the metrics, the cosmetics of those metrics.

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Maybe we can follow up offline. I just -- I mean, I think we typically think of it as just over 1 over 90 sort of just 1%, maybe 2%. That just seems a little high, but we can maybe follow-up offline.
componenttext: Maybe we can follow up offline. I just -- I mean, I think we typically think of it as just over 1 over 90 sort of just 1%, maybe 2%. That just seems a little high, but we can maybe follow-up offline.

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Whit Mayo with Robert Baird.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Whit Mayo with Robert Baird.

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Steve, can you talk a little about surgery and any particular strength in any service lines in the quarter, including ER, and then maybe just touch on behavioral and health. Your acute site versus RT volumes -- RTC volumes have been turned in.
componenttext: Steve, can you talk a little about surgery and any particular strength in any service lines in the quarter, including ER, and then maybe just touch on behavioral and health. Your acute site versus RT volumes -- RTC volumes have been turned in.

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, so on the acute side with -- generally, I would say that besides decides that sort of payer mix commentary that I've offered before, we've seen extreme strength in our surgical volumes. I think that inpatient surgeries were up something like 4% in th
componenttext: Yes, so on the acute side with -- generally, I would say that besides decides that sort of payer mix commentary that I've offered before, we've seen extreme strength in our surgical volumes. I think that inpatient surgeries were up something like 4% in the quarter. Outpatient surgeries were up like 7%, which is, again, some of the strongest surgical growth we've seen. Our Medicare case mix index was among the highest we've ever seen. I think that's reflective, obviously, of the surgical volume and continue the trend that we saw in Q4. So obviously, I think beyond the volume strength, which we've already commented on, we're seeing a lot of sort of high-quality revenue and high acuity revenue strength as well. On the behavioral side, I will say, I mean, the one sort of issue between the acute and the residential business is the residential business is not subject, I think, nearly as much to this whole psychiatry shortage issue. So the residential admissions have probably held in a little bit stronger than the acute admissions. And frankly, I think at least from a cosmetic perspective, that tends to hurt us because, at least, at the public companies, we tend to have a behavioral revenue sort of profile that is weighted more to the acute rather than to the residential business.

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: And so ER trends in the quarter?
componenttext: And so ER trends in the quarter?

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think ER trends, I'm sorry, Whit, are pretty consistent with the overall volume trends where we -- in the markets where we're seeing significant admission growth. We're seeing some generally some fairly high ER growth. I will say that in a couple o
componenttext: Yes, I think ER trends, I'm sorry, Whit, are pretty consistent with the overall volume trends where we -- in the markets where we're seeing significant admission growth. We're seeing some generally some fairly high ER growth. I will say that in a couple of markets where we are seeing more of a proliferation of urgent care and FED type development, freestanding ED development, we've seen our ED business go down a little bit. But honestly, our admissions in most of those markets are un-impacted as we continue to get those admissions to our hospitals.

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: And maybe just on medical admission, short stay observational, any change in the trend line there?
componenttext: And maybe just on medical admission, short stay observational, any change in the trend line there?

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016

componenttext: Got it. And my last question is just back on the IMD. And my understanding is that the rule is effective this July, allowing health plans to contract with providers. Is that your understanding as well? And from a practical standpoint, when do you think you can actually take admissions of this patient population?

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think your interpretation is correct, Whit, in the sense that, I believe, what the rule provides for is that states have the option of lifting the IMD exclusion and effectively allowing freestanding facilities to begin to take these patients as early as
componenttext: I think your interpretation is correct, Whit, in the sense that, I believe, what the rule provides for is that states have the option of lifting the IMD exclusion and effectively allowing freestanding facilities to begin to take these patients as early as July. Again, it's at the state's option, and we're not sure exactly what each state will do. But we are anticipating that at least in some geographies, we'll be able to begin to have access to those patients as early as July.

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: First of all, I guess I'll ask on the cost trends in the acute side. So I know, sometimes, when you have strong volume, you get the leverage of your existing SWB base, as well as supplies, et cetera, flowing through the margin side. And then sometimes, th
componenttext: First of all, I guess I'll ask on the cost trends in the acute side. So I know, sometimes, when you have strong volume, you get the leverage of your existing SWB base, as well as supplies, et cetera, flowing through the margin side. And then sometimes, the growth and volume is strong for extended period. You're start to having to add staff or scrambling even to get staff. Where are you at on that spectrum, and how would you put that other quarter in context for that maybe a little bit?

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: I mean, in the back half of 2015, AJ, we talked about the idea that there was certainly some pressure on salary and wages within the acute division, not so much in terms of headcount or numbers of employees, but in what we described as premium pay, which
componenttext: I mean, in the back half of 2015, AJ, we talked about the idea that there was certainly some pressure on salary and wages within the acute division, not so much in terms of headcount or numbers of employees, but in what we described as premium pay, which would include payments like use of temporary nurses and overtime for our own staff, et cetera. I think while we've made some improvement in that regard, we continue with the revenue growth that we saw in Q1 and with the admission growth in demand. We continued to see pressure on those wage rates and on that premium pay. And as a consequence, I think that when we file with you and you'll be able to drill down and you can see it in our consolidated results that most of the leverage we're getting on the strong revenue growth is on the supply and other operating expense line, and less of it is on the salary wage line because that -- we're still seeing a fair amount of pricing pressure, if you will, on that line.

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016

componenttext: Okay. All right. And then you guys nicely -- great at -- the buyback authorization doubled it. I know -- if I remember right, and maybe my memory is not serving me well, but typically, UHS waits til you're closer to running through your prioritization to adding another one of your magnitude. Is there any -- are you indicating anything there about maybe being more active on the buyback front? You've been pretty steady the last year. Give us some thoughts on that.

componenttext: Well, just to be clear, I mean, we -- the board increased the authorization back in February, and in large part, did so because we were on the verge of exhausting our previous authorization. componenttext: Okay, all right. I'm sorry about that. Maybe one last question on the IMD. You haven't been asked yet. Do you have contracts in place with the managed care guys or is that something that will take some time to put in place or how quick can you put those in place?

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think, in some cases, we already have contracts in place. We have been taking adolescent Medicaid patients for many years. And so in a number of geographies, in a number of instances, we already have existing managed care contracts for the adolescent Me
componenttext: I think, in some cases, we already have contracts in place. We have been taking adolescent Medicaid patients for many years. And so in a number of geographies, in a number of instances, we already have existing managed care contracts for the adolescent Medicaid population. And we can either extend those contracts to the adult population or just modify them, et cetera. It varies a little bit, I think, in every geography. But I actually do not believe that the contracting piece of this whole IMD exercise is really the more difficult piece. I think, again, it's those conversations, and hopefully, those collaborative agreements with the acute care hospitals that are really at the crux of it.

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: My question was about just to go a little deeper into the source and the drivers of this Medicare-based volume that you're seeing on the acute side. I'm trying to understand if you can see from your payer mix or any anecdotal evidence that this is just ne
componenttext: My question was about just to go a little deeper into the source and the drivers of this Medicare-based volume that you're seeing on the acute side. I'm trying to understand if you can see from your payer mix or any anecdotal evidence that this is just new members that are aging into Medicare that, perhaps, were underinsured or uninsured during their pre-Medicare days? Or is it existing patients and you're marketing more aggressively to them as a hospital chain or -- and is it any different between fee-for-service Medicare and Medicare Advantage?

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: So on a -- I mean, a few different comments I'll make. I mean, we continue to see over time a shift out of traditional Medicare into Medicare Advantage, and that continues, and I expect will continue for some time. What I was trying to allude to the board
componenttext: So on a -- I mean, a few different comments I'll make. I mean, we continue to see over time a shift out of traditional Medicare into Medicare Advantage, and that continues, and I expect will continue for some time. What I was trying to allude to the board, maybe [indiscernible] I think the idea that our Medicare population and admission is growing as quickly as it is, almost by definition, has to mean that we're taking market share. Because while I think the overall Medicare population could be expanding somewhat, it is certainly not expanding at the pace that our admissions are expanding. So I think almost by definition, the fact that our Medicare population is growing as much as it did is suggesting that in many of our markets, we are taking market share from our competitors. And I think it's because of all the real -- the focus, et cetera that our operators are bringing to service lines and to physician relationships, and I think all of that is paying dividends.

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. So it's about market share. Then the 2 changes that -- and these things take forever sometimes. We had the 2-midnight rule lap. And then, recently, I think CMS is backing off of that rule altogether. And simultaneously, they would be value-based to
componenttext: Okay. So it's about market share. Then the 2 changes that -- and these things take forever sometimes. We had the 2-midnight rule lap. And then, recently, I think CMS is backing off of that rule altogether. And simultaneously, they would be value-based to solely 25,000 primary care pilots that they have -- physician pilots that they've put in place. So one, sort of a positive, and the tailwind, it feels like once a bit of a headwind, but maybe more long term. I mean, how is this going to play out through '15 and then '17 in terms of the timing that you anticipate, either a positive or a negative, on a net basis?

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, look, I think Ana, as your question suggests, I think it's difficult to predict for some of these things how they're going to affect macro trends. And I think to the degree that they affect macro trends, it will be over a longer period of time. So I
componenttext: Yes, look, I think Ana, as your question suggests, I think it's difficult to predict for some of these things how they're going to affect macro trends. And I think to the degree that they affect macro trends, it will be over a longer period of time. So I think from our perspective, it is not likely to have significant short or even intermediate term impacts. Over the longer-term, we'll see.

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, not even on the 2-midnight rule? [indiscernible]
componenttext: Okay, not even on the 2-midnight rule? [indiscernible]

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think the effect of the 2-midnight rule probably lapped or anniversary-ed several quarters ago. So I don't think that's having a big impact. My response to Whit's question earlier about changes and sort of observation days or short stays, et cetera
componenttext: Yes, I think the effect of the 2-midnight rule probably lapped or anniversary-ed several quarters ago. So I don't think that's having a big impact. My response to Whit's question earlier about changes and sort of observation days or short stays, et cetera, was that we're really not seeing big changes in those dynamics. I think, again, that, that impact was probably several quarters ago.

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. Then a separate question on the bad debt, which continues to trend favorably, and now you're back to what you had about a year ago, at least, in the second quarter, was this an idiosyncratic lift-off in the third quarter, as you continue to see more
componenttext: Okay. Then a separate question on the bad debt, which continues to trend favorably, and now you're back to what you had about a year ago, at least, in the second quarter, was this an idiosyncratic lift-off in the third quarter, as you continue to see more data with your revenue cycle management practices, and any more color there from the drivers?

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, Ana, we've conceded on several occasions that the increase in uncompensated volumes back in the third quarter of '15 which we experienced, and quite frankly, many of our peers seem to experience as well was something that we really couldn't explain
componenttext: Well, Ana, we've conceded on several occasions that the increase in uncompensated volumes back in the third quarter of '15 which we experienced, and quite frankly, many of our peers seem to experience as well was something that we really couldn't explain with any great confidence. People suggest that at the time, that maybe it was some level of dis-enrollment in commercial exchanges as premiums were going up or as people had gotten the care that they were seeking. We could never sort of prove that in any kind of pervasive way. But I think what our experience in Q4 and Q1 would suggest to us is that it was a bit of an anomaly and a bit of a blip in that the uncompensated trends, which have been more stable in the last couple of quarters seem to be more reflective of the environment that we're really in.

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Maybe some comments on your priorities for use of capital at this point. It seems like the average repurchase price for your shares is a little bit south of where the stock is now, which I guess, is a good thing. And then how do you feel about the opportu
componenttext: Maybe some comments on your priorities for use of capital at this point. It seems like the average repurchase price for your shares is a little bit south of where the stock is now, which I guess, is a good thing. And then how do you feel about the opportunities on behavioral in the U.K. at this point?

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Gary, I think we always say, and we say it because I think we mean it, that we are relatively agnostic about where we deploy our capital, meaning, that we will likely deploy our capital wherever we think we can earn the best returns. And I think that we w
componenttext: Gary, I think we always say, and we say it because I think we mean it, that we are relatively agnostic about where we deploy our capital, meaning, that we will likely deploy our capital wherever we think we can earn the best returns. And I think that we were an active share re-purchaser in the first quarter and continued to some degree into the second quarter because we thought our shares, particularly given the strength of our business, were an attractive investment. I think we'll continue to consider that as we move forward. I think we've also said that we see a number of compelling M&A opportunities in both the behavioral and acute space. And we have the financial flexibility to pursue those and we will. I think we have long-standing and well earned reputation. However, as a judicious acquirer and a judicious evaluator of these opportunities and a judicious steward of capital, and I think we'll continue to [indiscernible] that reputation in the future. So we're going to look at all these opportunities. We never really prioritize because in our minds, the priorities are as we see these specific opportunities and as we evaluate these specific opportunities.

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016

componenttext: I think we are. And I think I said before we continue to be actively involved in a number of conversations in that regard. We just find that those processes and those conversations tend to be a bit elongated and they take some time. But we believe, as I said before that, with some high degree of confidence that we will deploy capital into the acute care business in 2016 at levels that we probably have not in a while.

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Can you talk about the growth that you're seeing so far this year on the U.K. behaviorial health business? And in the past, you've talked about occupancy rates in the 90% range. So maybe you could update us on any near-term plans to add beds in that marke
componenttext: Can you talk about the growth that you're seeing so far this year on the U.K. behaviorial health business? And in the past, you've talked about occupancy rates in the 90% range. So maybe you could update us on any near-term plans to add beds in that market?

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. So I think everything you said remains true. We are running occupancy rates in the U.K. both in -- it's still a relatively new business for us. But in the Cygnet business that we bought, at this point, 1.5 years ago and the Alpha business that we bo
componenttext: Sure. So I think everything you said remains true. We are running occupancy rates in the U.K. both in -- it's still a relatively new business for us. But in the Cygnet business that we bought, at this point, 1.5 years ago and the Alpha business that we bought maybe 6 months ago, we're seeing those very high occupancy rates. And as a result, we're really taking all the actions in the U.K. that we've been taking in the U.S. for many years and that is we're adding this to existing facilities where the demand justifies that. We are building some de novo facilities in the U.K. where the demand justifies that. We've done some tuck-in acquisitions in the U.K. We did a larger acquisition with the Alpha deal 6 months ago as I said. And we continue to look at all those kinds of opportunities, future opportunities in the U.K. as well with all the same set of caveats and dynamics that I described here in the U.S. So we'll deploy capital in the U.K. behavioral space if it makes compelling sense to us and we're looking aggressively to do that.

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got it. And could you slice for us how many beds that you know that you're adding so far just with the growth within existing facilities and the de novo startup plans for this year? What is the overall bed growth in the U.K. going to look like?
componenttext: Got it. And could you slice for us how many beds that you know that you're adding so far just with the growth within existing facilities and the de novo startup plans for this year? What is the overall bed growth in the U.K. going to look like?

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: I mean, actually, I do not have the U.K. numbers in front of me. I mean, we have talked broadly about 600 to 800 bed, new beds in our behavioral division overall, and those would include new U.K. beds.
componenttext: I mean, actually, I do not have the U.K. numbers in front of me. I mean, we have talked broadly about 600 to 800 bed, new beds in our behavioral division overall, and those would include new U.K. beds.

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, let me do that. And then my last one, on the -- just going through the concept of the new IMD regulation, do you have a sense of where your presumably newly negotiated Medicaid adult per diem might shake out versus general acute care hospitals or ma
componenttext: Okay, let me do that. And then my last one, on the -- just going through the concept of the new IMD regulation, do you have a sense of where your presumably newly negotiated Medicaid adult per diem might shake out versus general acute care hospitals or maybe where your current child and adolescent Medicaid per diem kind of shake out versus hospital. And I guess what I'm trying to get at is do we think given presumably a lower cost structure in freestanding that from a rate perspective, we might get to the point where Medicaid HMOs have a compelling financial incentive to attempt to steer volume in your direction as opposed to just picking up, initially, probably the ER-diverted patient that they can't find a bed for?

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Look, it's really, I think, a thoughtful question, Gary. I mean, -- and again, I think we're sort of of approaching this in kind of a 2 phase sort of process. I mean the one, as I stressed, is we would like to reach collaborative agreements with many
componenttext: Yes. Look, it's really, I think, a thoughtful question, Gary. I mean, -- and again, I think we're sort of of approaching this in kind of a 2 phase sort of process. I mean the one, as I stressed, is we would like to reach collaborative agreements with many of the acute care hospitals in our markets that are providing inpatient behavioral services. We think, generally, and this is certainly not true of every single acute care hospital, but we think, generally, acute care hospitals are not very good providers. They're not efficient providers of behavioral services. They have so many other things that they're doing that it's just not a top priority of theirs, and we generally feel we can do it better. We can do it higher quality. We can do it with better efficiency, and we're trying to make that argument to our acute care colleagues, if you will, in our markets around the country. And I think, in our minds, that's sort of the first step in getting access to these adult Medicaid patients. The second is more, I think, along the lines of what you're suggesting which is as a freestanding industry, and certainly, UHS, I think, has a reputation of being able to provide these services more efficiently, and at both high-quality and lower cost, then we're certainly prepared to make those arguments into our managed care payers. But quite frankly, I think, are as aware of that dynamic as we are with the rest of their patient population. So that to us, I think, is more of a secondary argument. We'd like to get the acute hospitals sort of to partner with us first, and then we'll kind of make our pitch to the MCOs.
