componenttext: Good morning. My name is Jennifer, and I will be your  conference operator today. At this time, I would like to welcome everyone to the Universal Health Services Second Quarter Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] Thank you, and Mr. Steve Filton, you may begin your conference.

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good morning. Alan Miller, our CEO,  is also joining us this morning. Welcome to this review of Universal Health Services results for the second quarter ended June 30, 2016. During this conference call, Alan and I will be using words such as believes, e
componenttext:
Good morning. Alan Miller, our CEO,  is also joining us this morning. Welcome to this review of Universal Health Services results for the second quarter ended June 30, 2016. 
During this conference call, Alan and I will be using words such as believes, expects, anticipates, estimates and similar words that represent forecasts, projections and forward-looking statements. For anyone not familiar with the risks and uncertainties inherent in these forward-looking statements, I recommend a careful reading of the section on risk factors and forward-looking statements and risk factors in our Form 10-K for the year ended December 31, 2015 and our Form 10-Q for the quarter ended March 31, 2016. 
We would like to highlight just a couple of developments and business trends before opening the call up to your questions. As discussed in our press release last night, the company recorded net income attributable to UHS per diluted share of $1.89 for the quarter. After adjusting each quarter's reported results for the incentive income and expenses recorded in connection with the implementation of electronic health records applications in our acute care hospitals as disclosed on the Supplemental Schedule included with last night's earnings release, adjusted net income attributable to UHS increased to $191.1 million or $1.94 per diluted share during the second quarter of 2016 as compared to $186.6 million or $1.85 per diluted share during the second quarter of last year.
On a same-facility basis in our acute care division, revenues during the second quarter of 2016 increased 7.4% over last year's comparable quarter. The increase resulted primarily from a 3.9% increase in adjusted admissions to our hospitals owned for more than a year and a 1.3% increase in revenue per adjusted admission. On a same facility basis, operating margins for our acute care division decreased to 17.7% during the second quarter of 2016 from 19.1% during the second quarter of 2015. 
On a same facility basis, net revenues on our behavioral health division increased 2.0% during the second quarter of 2016 as compared to the second quarter of 2015. During this year's second quarter as compared to last year's, adjusted admissions to our behavioral health facilities owned for more than a year decreased 0.3% and adjusted patient days increased 0.2%. Revenue per adjusted admission and adjusted patient day rose 2.4% and 1.9% respectively during the second quarter of 2016 over the comparable prior year quarter.
On a same facility basis, operating margins for our behavioral health division were 28.1% and 28.7% during the quarters ended June 30, 2016, and 2015, respectively.
For the  6 months ended June 30, 2016, our cash provided by operating activities increased to approximately 50% to $801 million over the $532 million generated during the comparable 6-month period of 2015. Our accounts receivable days outstanding decreased slightly to 50 days during the second quarter of 2016 as compared to 54 days during the second quarter of 2015. 
At June 30, 2016, our ratio of debt-to-total capitalization increased to 45.5% as compared to 42.6% at June 30, 2015. 
We spent $120 million on capital expenditures during the second quarter of 2016 and $248 million during the first 6 months of 2016. Included in our capital expenditures were the construction costs related to the ongoing construction of a new 142-bed hospital in Henderson, Nevada, which is scheduled to open in the fourth quarter of this year. Also included were the construction costs related to a new four-story patient tower at Spring Valley Hospital in Las Vegas, Nevada, which was recently completed and open. 
In addition, early in the second quarter we opened Skywood Recovery, a new 100-bed substance abuse treatment center located in August, Michigan. Skywood is part of our expanding foundations recovery network and provides integrated treatment for substance abuse and co-occurring mental health disorders.
Last month, we completed the refinancing of certain components of our debt, including: One, the issuance of $400 million of our 4.75% senior secured notes due in 2022, which were issued at a yield of 4.35%; two, the issuance of $400 million or 5.0% senior secured notes due in 2026; and three, a $200 million increase in borrowings pursuant to the term loan A facility of our credit agreement. These financings generated aggregate debt proceeds of approximately $1 billion of which $400 million was utilized to repay the 7 and a quarter -- 7 [ph] and 8 [ph] percent senior secured notes that matured in June 30, '16. $445 million was spent in connection with our previously disclosed may 2016 purchase of third-party minority ownership interest in our 6 acute care hospitals located in Las Vegas, Nevada and the remainder was utilized to repay other floating rate debt. 
In conjunction with our $800 million stock repurchase program during the second quarter of 2016, we purchased approximately 235,000 shares of our stock at an aggregate cost of $59 [ph] million or approximately $123 million per share. Since inception, the program -- since inception of the program through June 30, '16, we purchased approximately 3.5 million shares at an aggregate cost of $406 million or approximately $117 per share. 
Alan and I are pleased to answer your questions at this time.

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] And our first question comes from the line of Paula Torch of Avondale Partners.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] And our first question comes from the line of Paula Torch of Avondale Partners.

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: So Steve, I wanted to start off maybe in asking about the behavioral volumes. They were a little bit weaker than we were expecting and wondering if you could just give us a little bit more color around the drivers of that weakness? I realize that compares
componenttext: So Steve, I wanted to start off maybe in asking about the behavioral volumes. They were a little bit weaker than we were expecting and wondering if you could just give us a little bit more color around the drivers of that weakness? I realize that compares were more difficult last year and that you're still working through some of the labor shortages. But how is that going forward? And what are you thinking about those volumes in the second half of the year?

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure, Paula. So I think as you suggest, we really, I think, been talking about the pressures on our behavioral volumes for almost a year now. I think beginning in third quarter of last year, we began to clearly see the shortage of clinicians, psychiatrist
componenttext: Sure, Paula. So I think as you suggest, we really, I think, been talking about the pressures on our behavioral volumes for almost a year now. I think beginning in third quarter of last year, we began to clearly see the shortage of clinicians, psychiatrists and nurses and to a lesser degree, other mental health technicians as hampering our ability in certain facilities in a relatively small number of markets and a small number of facilities, hampering our ability in some cases to admit all the patients who were being presented to us for admission. I think those dynamics when we said this when we gave our guidance for 2016, we thought that those dynamics would persist through the second quarter of this year. We also suggested that they would improve in the back half of this year, in large part because: Number one, the comparisons would become easier as they will; and also because the number of initiatives that we've been working on and putting in place to mitigate this problem would also begin to gain some traction. So I think that the softer volumes in Q2 were somewhat disappointing to us as well, but largely expected. And I think our sense continues to be that they will improve in the back half of this year.

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Is it possible to parse out how much of the softer volumes were because of this, this dynamic with the labor versus just overall weakness in general?
componenttext: Is it possible to parse out how much of the softer volumes were because of this, this dynamic with the labor versus just overall weakness in general?

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. So our general sense, Paula, is that our original guidance for the year contemplated about a 5% increase in behavioral same-store revenue. And that was really broken down into a 3% to 4% anticipated increase in volumes in patient days and a 1% to 2%
componenttext: Sure. So our general sense, Paula, is that our original guidance for the year contemplated about a 5% increase in behavioral same-store revenue. And that was really broken down into a 3% to 4% anticipated increase in volumes in patient days and a 1% to 2% increase in price. On the pricing side, I think we're absolutely where we expected to be. And so we're basically showing flattish volumes as compared to about 3% or 4% increase that we were anticipating. And I think we believe that, that entire GAAP and that entire difference can be attributed to the shortage of clinicians, in that if we're able to solve and resolve that problem, we should be able to get back to that sort of 5% overall revenue growth level and that 3% to 4% volume growth level that we anticipated originally.

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And maybe just a follow-up to that. I'm curious if you could share with us some of the initiatives that you have in place to mitigate this? Is it on paying out higher wages, training programs, maybe more effective recruiting? I mean anything that yo
componenttext: Okay. And maybe just a follow-up to that. I'm curious if you could share with us some of the initiatives that you have in place to mitigate this? Is it on paying out higher wages, training programs, maybe more effective recruiting? I mean anything that you can kind of tell us there that you've been doing that you feel will really drive this home in the second half?

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure, well I think frankly, Paula, it's all those things and more. Obviously, in a tight labor market, wage rates matter. And so in markets in which we are experiencing shortages, we conducted extensive compensation surveys and have modified our wage rate
componenttext: Sure, well I think frankly, Paula, it's all those things and more. Obviously, in a tight labor market, wage rates matter. And so in markets in which we are experiencing shortages, we conducted extensive compensation surveys and have modified our wage rates to make sure that we're competitive in the marketplace and every marketplace is different. We have also hired more people and dedicated more people to both the physician and nursing recruiting processes. And finally, I think we're very focused on the retention aspect and not just the recruiting aspect because for 2 reasons. I mean obviously because of the degree that we're able to retain our nurses, we don't have to by definition recruit for their replacements; and two, the degree that we recruit replacements, we want to make sure that they stay with us as long as they possibly can. And so our Chief Nursing Officer in the behavioral division has focus a lot of her attention on a new and sort of reinvigorated onboarding process, in which we're making sure that nurses are properly trained and have a clear career path and have the appropriate sort of mentoring resources dedicated to them, et cetera. So as I said, in every market, the approach is somewhat different. It's tailored to the market. But it is by far sort of the #1 focus of the operators in the behavioral division at this point.

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from Chris Rigg from Susquehanna Financial.
componenttext: Your next question comes from Chris Rigg from Susquehanna Financial.

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is Frank Lee on for Chris. The acute care business remains high in the quarter relative to the first -- relative to the full year outlook. Could you just provide a sense for how much of volume growth was attributable to economic improvements in your
componenttext: This is Frank Lee on for Chris. The acute care business remains high in the quarter relative to the first -- relative to the full year outlook. Could you just provide a sense for how much of volume growth was attributable to economic improvements in your markets versus increasing market share or if there's any other unusual activity to call out there?

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure, Frank. I think we have said, quite frankly for the last few [ph] years, that it's difficult to parse out acute care revenue improvement. Obviously a couple of years ago the real focus was on parsing out the ACA impact versus the economy. And I think
componenttext: Sure, Frank. I think we have said, quite frankly for the last few [ph] years, that it's difficult to parse out acute care revenue improvement. Obviously a couple of years ago the real focus was on parsing out the ACA impact versus the economy. And I think clearly the ACA impact has shown diminishing returns for the last few years. We're still posting strong acute care volume numbers, obviously because we're the first to report this quarter. I don't know how we compare with others but my sense is these are still going to be fairly robust volumes. And I think what we said all along is I think we largely feel it's a function of the, just strong local franchises that we have in markets like Las Vegas, Southern California, South Florida. And the economic improvement in those markets but also our market position and our ability to take market share in those markets, I think it's very difficult to sort of parse, the 4% improvement in same-store adjusted admissions among those various factors. Suffice it to say that we still think that's a pretty good number and well within our expectation.

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then the same-store operating margin in the acute care business was down year-over-year by a decent amount. Is that primarily related to some of the staffing shortage issues that you had discussed on the acute care side? And then can you talk ab
componenttext: Okay. And then the same-store operating margin in the acute care business was down year-over-year by a decent amount. Is that primarily related to some of the staffing shortage issues that you had discussed on the acute care side? And then can you talk about the progress that you made on the initiatives that you put in place to rectify those shortages?

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think, and we talked about this certainly last quarter and I think for several quarters, really again beginning in the second half of last year. Look, I think as a result of the improving U.S. economy and improving economy in our local market, we have s
componenttext: I think, and we talked about this certainly last quarter and I think for several quarters, really again beginning in the second half of last year. Look, I think as a result of the improving U.S. economy and improving economy in our local market, we have seen a tightening of available labor force in all -- in all or most of our markets. That tightening, I think, is manifested somewhat differently in the 2 divisions that we have. We just talked about on the behavioral side. Quite frankly, we're just not able in some markets to find sufficient nurses and physicians, and as a consequence we are forced to turn patients away. On the acute side, I think it's manifested more prevalently in higher use of what we describe as premium pay, which would be over time or shift differential payments that we make to our current employees or the use of temporary or agency nurses, where current employees are not available. And certainly that use of premium pay on the acute side has contributed to the margin pressure in Q2 as it did back in Q3 of last year. But I think we continue to sort of focus on that, and it got better in Q4 and Q1 of this year. And I think our senses it we'll continue to focus on it and it is a solvable problem on the acute side. One other comment to  make on the acute side, vis--vis margins, is while I think the volumes on the acute side were well within our expectations, revenue per admission, growth of 1.3%, probably 50, 75 basis points short of where we thought we'd be. I think that's a bit of a weaker patient mix, and that's mostly maybe a growth in uncompensated patients in the quarter, not by a material amount. But I think mostly the big change from Q1 is in Q1 our other noncompensated volumes which were just so strong, particularly our Medicare volumes were so strong that they offset a bit of the uncompensated pickup in volumes in Q2 as Medicare and other commercial volumes moderated some of the uncompensated rise had a bit more of an effect. I think the staffing pressure or the premium pay pressure along with slight payer mix, the duration, probably explain the bulk of the pressure on acute care margins.

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from Matthew Borsch with Goldman Sachs.
componenttext: Your next question comes from Matthew Borsch with Goldman Sachs.

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is Tejus on for Matt. Just to follow-up on the acute care volumes, we were expecting them to moderate in Q2. But is this in-line with your expectations? Any additional weakness to call out? And also, anything you can talk about in terms of regional d
componenttext: This is Tejus on for Matt. Just to follow-up on the acute care volumes, we were expecting them to moderate in Q2. But is this in-line with your expectations? Any additional weakness to call out? And also, anything you can talk about in terms of regional differences between call it Nevada, and then more of Texas, Florida, California markets would be helpful.

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure, Tejus. So our original guidance for the year was something like 6% acute care revenue from same-store revenue growth and we broke that into components, pretty evenly broke that into pricing and volume. So the 4% volume, same-store adjusted admission
componenttext: Sure, Tejus. So our original guidance for the year was something like 6% acute care revenue from same-store revenue growth and we broke that into components, pretty evenly broke that into pricing and volume. So the 4% volume, same-store adjusted admission volume growth we saw in Q2 was well within and frankly ahead of our expectations while the pricing was slightly lower. But overall, acure care revenues were pretty close to what we expected. In terms of regional differences, I think most of the -- we clearly saw an overall moderation in acute care revenues in Q2 from the really extraordinary levels of Q1. We absolutely has said all along, that's what we expect would happen. And obviously, the Q2 performance is much closer to our original guidance. I think the regional commentary that we've given for probably a year now still holds in Q2 of this year, which is markets like Vegas and California and Florida have been sort of over performers. And the Texas market, namely the South Texas markets and Amarillo, probably had been the weaker performers.

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great. And can you touch on the other operating expenses that looked like it increased this quarter?
componenttext: Great. And can you touch on the other operating expenses that looked like it increased this quarter?

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think those other operating expenses are distorted a little bit by the impact of our insurance company. We had about a $25 million to $30 million increase in both premium revenue and in claims expense in the insurance company this quarter. We record tha
componenttext: I think those other operating expenses are distorted a little bit by the impact of our insurance company. We had about a $25 million to $30 million increase in both premium revenue and in claims expense in the insurance company this quarter. We record that in our acute care division and we record the expenses specifically in other operating expenses. So I think if you adjust that $25 million to $30 million that was out of both revenue and other operating expenses, those numbers, at least for us, will certainly look like much more in line with expectations.

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from Kevin Fischbeck with BOA.
componenttext: Your next question comes from Kevin Fischbeck with BOA.

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is Joanne Gajuk filling in for Kevin. I just want to come back to the discussion of acute care volumes, which to your point it wasn't probably a deceleration but actually deceleration from very elevated numbers in Q1, was the deceleration might have
componenttext: This is Joanne Gajuk filling in for Kevin. I just want to come back to the discussion of acute care volumes, which to your point it wasn't probably a deceleration but actually deceleration from very elevated numbers in Q1, was the deceleration might have been pricing to some. Can you parse it out a little bit more in terms of the different sort of business and specifically talk about the surgery performance in Q2. Because I think we should inform some of the medical device companies that the volumes decelerated in terms of surgeries, but the deceleration was not as dramatic. So just can you touch base, can you just talk a little bit about the surgeries in outpatient performance in the quarter?

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure, Joanna. So our inpatient surgeries increased by about 2% in Q2 versus a 4% increase in Q1. And again, I think we thought that 4% increase for inpatient surgeries were above what we thought we could sustain. The outpatient surgeries rose by about 7%
componenttext: Sure, Joanna. So our inpatient surgeries increased by about 2% in Q2 versus a 4% increase in Q1. And again, I think we thought that 4% increase for inpatient surgeries were above what we thought we could sustain. The outpatient surgeries rose by about 7% in Q2 and that was pretty similar to the Q1 performance. So again, from my perspective, our surgical volumes in Q2 were very much in line with our expectations.

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016

componenttext: Great. And just touching base on the [indiscernible] minority interest purchase and the impact for the company. So can we maybe talk about maybe the audible impact of $60 million? So is it fair to assume that maybe $36 million impact for your minority interest sits after tax? Is that roughly in the ballpark number annually?

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016

componenttext: Yes. So let me just remind everyone that first of all, the transaction was not completed until the beginning of May. So we only had 2 months of the transactions impact in the quarter. And we've estimated that the positive impact for us would be somewhere between $0.015 [ph] and $0.02 a month. And so we've got $0.03 to $0.04 in Q2 and $0.12 to $0.16 or so for the year, for the 8 months that should be our favorable impact for the year.

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016

componenttext: So that's net of the interest, the high interest expense? Because that is also refi-ed debt but you raised an additional debt to fund the purchase of $400 million plus purchase. So is that the $0.01 to $0.02 per month, is that net of debt, high interest expense or...

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016

componenttext: Yes. So if the reduction in, or the increase in earnings as a result of having the full impact of the Vegas earnings, less the interest expense on the $445 million to fund that buy out, and obviously also less the tax impact of additional earnings.

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great, that's helpful. And on the last topic, in terms of the U.K. business and the Brexit and your outlook there going forward for that part of the segment in terms of current existing so impact on the actual business in terms of maybe upward pressure on
componenttext: Great, that's helpful. And on the last topic, in terms of the U.K. business and the Brexit and your outlook there going forward for that part of the segment in terms of current existing so impact on the actual business in terms of maybe upward pressure on staffing there or the government funding? So any color you may have on the U.K. business maybe helpful.

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. So yes, first of all, let me just kind of set the relative importance of the U.K. to our consolidated results as opposed to some of our peers. It's a relatively small footprint in the U.K. About 2% to 3% of our consolidated revenues this year will co
componenttext: Yes. So yes, first of all, let me just kind of set the relative importance of the U.K. to our consolidated results as opposed to some of our peers. It's a relatively small footprint in the U.K. About 2% to 3% of our consolidated revenues this year will come from the U.K. We have said from the outset that our original investment in the U.K., which is equal to roughly about $500 million or so has been hedged. So from a currency risk perspective, we are protected on currency fluctuations. Finally, I think while obviously Brexit made a lot of headlines, I think in terms of its impact on the fundamentals of the behavioral business in the U.K., it's had virtually none in the short run. In the longer term, we'll see. I think obviously, as you know, many, many details of the Brexit process have to be worked out, involving labor -- folks in the labor force, et cetera. So we'll see how that all plays out. But again, at the moment, no impact. And I think just keep in mind that it is a relatively immaterial part of our business.

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: We've done very well with regard to our acquisition. We paid reasonable prices for the acquisition, both in Cygnet and Alpha, and we're very pleased with them. But it relates to how much you pay and how good is the management. And we've been pleased with
componenttext: We've done very well with regard to our acquisition. We paid reasonable prices for the acquisition, both in Cygnet and Alpha, and we're very pleased with them. But it relates to how much you pay and how good is the management. And we've been pleased with what we have.

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016

componenttext: Great. And just quickly on that point, it sounds like there could be some assets for sale in the U.K. So would you still be interested to grow that business given that maybe potential uncertainty around Brexit and whatnot that might happen?

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think its pretty premature to speculate obviously. We don't know what assets might be for sale. I think it's always sort of a given that when assets are for sale, whether in the U.K. or in the U.S., they're of a high-quality, we're certainly interested
componenttext: I think its pretty premature to speculate obviously. We don't know what assets might be for sale. I think it's always sort of a given that when assets are for sale, whether in the U.K. or in the U.S., they're of a high-quality, we're certainly interested in taking a look. But we don't even know what the specifics maybe in the U.K. So it's probably too early to comment.

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from Gary Lieberman with Wells Fargo.
componenttext: Your next question comes from Gary Lieberman with Wells Fargo.

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: You mentioned weaker payer mix on the acute care side. Are there any numbers you can share with us, Steve?
componenttext: You mentioned weaker payer mix on the acute care side. Are there any numbers you can share with us, Steve?

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: I mean uncompensated volumes were up probably kind of 2%, 2.5% in the quarter. Honestly, I think they were up by a similar amount in Q1 as I think I said earlier. I think the difference was in Q1. Other volumes were just so strong that they tend to really
componenttext: I mean uncompensated volumes were up probably kind of 2%, 2.5% in the quarter. Honestly, I think they were up by a similar amount in Q1 as I think I said earlier. I think the difference was in Q1. Other volumes were just so strong that they tend to really offset any impact of that increase. I think the other sort of commentary I make about uncompensated care in general is we take our total uncompensated care all of which we disclose in the press release, the bad debt, the uninsured discount. We take that total number and compare it to our gross revenue, which I know is generally not a metric most people use very much. But I think from our perspective, it takes into account the pricing, the gross pricing impact that runs through those numbers. And while our second quarter uncompensated care experience was measurably higher than last year's second quarter, it's still lower than it was in the back half of last year. And so I think our general notion is that we're seeing a kind of slight uptick in uncompensated care. But it is -- it's reasonably steady over the last 3 or 4 quarters.

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Any reason to think the trend in the second half of the year will be different, like you're seeing pressure earlier this year and is it going to continue, or is it just sort of an anomaly?
componenttext: Any reason to think the trend in the second half of the year will be different, like you're seeing pressure earlier this year and is it going to continue, or is it just sort of an anomaly?

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, look, Yogi Berra says it's hard to predict the future. But look, I think our general sense is that we may see a continued uptick incrementally in uncompensated care. It doesn't have a feel to us of a big measurable change. But payer mix is probably t
componenttext: Yes, look, Yogi Berra says it's hard to predict the future. But look, I think our general sense is that we may see a continued uptick incrementally in uncompensated care. It doesn't have a feel to us of a big measurable change. But payer mix is probably the element of our business that's most difficult to project. So I don't want to make too many really definitive statements than I already have.

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And just to follow-up on the IMD exclusion, are you seeing anything yet? I realize it's still pretty early. and then maybe just comment on that in light of the comments of the issues with hiring psychiatrists. Do you think that is going to prevent y
componenttext: Okay. And just to follow-up on the IMD exclusion, are you seeing anything yet? I realize it's still pretty early. and then maybe just comment on that in light of the comments of the issues with hiring psychiatrists. Do you think that is going to prevent you from seeing any benefit with regards to that?

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think we've consistently said, Gary, that we view of the IMD benefit as a meaningful one, but also one that will be impactful and have an impact on us over time, and also will be part of kind of a broader efforts to penetrate the acute care hospital seg
componenttext: I think we've consistently said, Gary, that we view of the IMD benefit as a meaningful one, but also one that will be impactful and have an impact on us over time, and also will be part of kind of a broader efforts to penetrate the acute care hospital segment of the behavioral industry, that is acute care hospitales will have their own behavioral units. I think your first comment is absolutely right. I mean we're sort of 2 or 3 weeks of the effective date of the new IMD managed Medicaid rule. Any commentary or any reaction we have at this point will be purely anecdotal. I think honestly, we've always have a view that probably the biggest impact doesn't start to occur even until the beginning of next year when managed-care plans have all their new plans in place and start to direct and redirect business in different ways. But I think finally, the other comment we've made on previous calls and I think we're still very much believers in is, we believe that the IMD or we view the IMD, the listing on the IMD exclusion in the broader context of our very pervasive and very aggressive program to try and collaborate with acute care hospitals around the country and to help gain access to their behavioral units. And obviously the lifting of the IMD exclusions removes one of the hurdles and I think has always prevented that from happening in the pervasive way. But again, that whole process is one that will continue to take place and will continue to have an impact for many years to come.

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016

componenttext: So I did comment on the surgery trends. You can just go back and look at that. And outpatient visits, we're up in sort of the 5% to 7% range. Again, that's fairly consistent with our first quarter results.

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: The opening ceremony is October 6, and we'll be taking patients shortly thereafter. We are very excited about it. We've been very good in that area. One of the good area is Temecula, which we opened a couple of years ago, has just been exceeded all of our
componenttext: The opening ceremony is October 6, and we'll be taking patients shortly thereafter. We are very excited about it. We've been very good in that area. One of the good area is Temecula, which we opened a couple of years ago, has just been exceeded all of our expectations. Henderson completes our coverage of the market. We're very excited about that. And we opened the Spring Valley Tower, and that's now in operations. So we're really looking forward to success in Las Vegas in addition to what we have currently.

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: And to answer your specific preopening question. So as part of our '16 guidance, we said that there would be a $10 million EBITDA drag from Henderson in the back half of the year, both in Q3 preopening cost and then in Q4 opening losses. That number, fran
componenttext: And to answer your specific preopening question. So as part of our '16 guidance, we said that there would be a $10 million EBITDA drag from Henderson in the back half of the year, both in Q3 preopening cost and then in Q4 opening losses. That number, frankly, just mechanically, will be a little bit larger because it doesn't -- it didn't originally contemplate the fact that we buy at the community interest. So it's probably $2 million or $3 million higher than that. But that hasn't changed and that was in our original data.

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And just last one. I know you don't provide quarterly guidance but the Street has had a historical tendency to get ahead of your internal budgets in the second half in prior years. So just any comments or observations will be helpful.
componenttext: Okay. And just last one. I know you don't provide quarterly guidance but the Street has had a historical tendency to get ahead of your internal budgets in the second half in prior years. So just any comments or observations will be helpful.

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Look, I'll just talk about the trajectory of the year from our perspective. We talked in the first quarter about the fact that we were ahead of our own internal budget. But I think we also conceded that the results in Q1 were further ahead of consensus th
componenttext: Look, I'll just talk about the trajectory of the year from our perspective. We talked in the first quarter about the fact that we were ahead of our own internal budget. But I think we also conceded that the results in Q1 were further ahead of consensus than they were of our own internal budget. I think in Q2, we were pretty close to the Street consensus. So I think our view is if we continue to meet our own internal modeling and expectations in the back half of the year, with the benefit of the community buyout impact which was not contemplated in our original guidance, we should still be very comfortably in our guidance range, probably a little close to the upper half of that guidance.

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from Joshua Raskin with Barclays.
componenttext: Your next question comes from Joshua Raskin with Barclays.

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Maybe just taking a step back on the site business. The trends have looked relatively similar to acute the last several quarters. And I think the historical perspective is the site business has been a better growth business and more opportunity. And I'm c
componenttext: Maybe just taking a step back on the site business. The trends have looked relatively similar to acute the last several quarters. And I think the historical perspective is the site business has been a better growth business and more opportunity. And I'm curious if you feel like we've seen sort of more of the maturation of that business? And I guess just think about your evaluations when you're looking at assets, what do you think in terms of valuations for psych assets versus acute care assets? And do you still think that growth dynamics in psych are noticeably different than acute care going forward?

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'll answer the question, Josh, in a couple of different ways. I mean, one is in terms of the growth prospects of this business, the behavioral business that is, we remain fairly bullish, and that is because as I indicated in my earlier remarks, we believ
componenttext: I'll answer the question, Josh, in a couple of different ways. I mean, one is in terms of the growth prospects of this business, the behavioral business that is, we remain fairly bullish, and that is because as I indicated in my earlier remarks, we believe that there's demonstrated demand for this business. And quite frankly, I think there are a number of dynamics that would suggest that, that demand does nothing but increase. We can have a whole long conversation about that. But things like the incidence of addiction illness and the need for addiction treatment and the opioid epidemic in the U.S., and the continued incidence of mental health issues in the elderly population, and then just a whole host of reasons to believe that, I think, the demand for mental health services is going to increase. And in fact, we believe we demonstrate that in our hospitals. We've been unable to demonstrate it in our financial results because of this clinician shortage. I think we have the view that in the short run, we will make inroads and significant inroads in that clinician shortage in the short run. And in the long-run, the market itself will correct for this as it has when the acute business has suffered through in nursing shortage some 10 years ago. And just nurse salaries went up and more people enrolled in nursing schools and the supply and demand balance sort of was restored. And I think the same thing will happen here, both with psychiatrists and nurses on the behavioral side. In terms of commenting on valuation of the 2 businesses, I think it's difficult for us to do. We clearly look at individual acquisition opportunities on a standalone discreet basis. And the growth potential in an individual behavioral facility or individual behavioral company versus an acute is really dependent on the markets they're in, what their specific market position is, what the strategies are for growth, et cetera. So we certainly don't go into any acquisition, either acute or behavioral with a notion of kind of there's a sort of evaluation to make sense. I do think UHS has a reputation for being fairly judicious in its acquisitions and its deployment of capital. I don't see that judicious changing but it's a market-by-market issue.

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay that's very helpful. Steve, one of the health clients yesterday made a comment about higher-than-expected cost in substance abuse. They were talking about, I think mostly exchange patients than individual patients. There was a lot more focus on the W
componenttext: Okay that's very helpful. Steve, one of the health clients yesterday made a comment about higher-than-expected cost in substance abuse. They were talking about, I think mostly exchange patients than individual patients. There was a lot more focus on the West Coast with some of that. Are you guys seeing anything in terms of substance abuse upticks or anything in the exchange membership where you guys think you're seeing a little bit better volumes?

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: I mean as I said, Josh, I think that there's all sorts of data out there that suggests that both the incidence of addiction illness and obviously of the corresponding demand for addiction treatment is growing. I think when that happens, when there's a gro
componenttext: I mean as I said, Josh, I think that there's all sorts of data out there that suggests that both the incidence of addiction illness and obviously of the corresponding demand for addiction treatment is growing. I think when that happens, when there's a growing demand for a particular service, the payers start to focus on it more. I think one way that we're seeing that manifest is I think the payers are more focused on this whole out-of-network segment of the addiction treatment business. I think a bunch of companies have grown up around that model. We were very targeted or we made a very targeted decision when we bought foundations that they were a company that had both out-of-network and in-network business put pretty evenly. And that they, in our minds, and I think we've seen them in the short time we've owned them, navigate very freely between sort of the two sides. So if this business shifts still more of an in network model, we think we'll be prepared to make that transition more easily than a number of these other companies that are focused on most exclusively on that out-of-network model.

componenttext: Yes, so two things. I mean, one as I suggested in the comments earlier, we really don't look at bad debt on its own. I think you have to look at it in combination with charity care on an insurance discount. And again, I think the way that I sort of think about it, John, is I'm back to -- we talked about acute care revenue growth. And that revenue growth, which is after bad debt and after charity care in uninsured just at about 3% for the year. And I think that's what I would guide people to think about for the back half of the year, that would take into account the growth in uncompensated volumes.

So I think we're going to return at least in the short run a more of a normalized CapEx been in that market. But yes, we'll have 100% of it.

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016

componenttext: First of all, maybe just quickly -- on your cash flow number was good, your debt-to-EBITDA is down at 2.2x, which I think is sort of below the low end of your target. Any thoughts on capital deployment from here? I know you got asked about the potential divestitures. But more broadly, acquisition pipeline versus opportunities for share repurchase given where you're at in the capital base?

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure, AJ. I mean look you heard me say this before and I'll repeat it because it's true, and that is acquisition spending is probably the most difficult aspect of our business to predict. So as we sort of try and measure what sort of opportunities we have
componenttext: Sure, AJ. I mean look you heard me say this before and I'll repeat it because it's true, and that is acquisition spending is probably the most difficult aspect of our business to predict. So as we sort of try and measure what sort of opportunities we have, that's sometimes difficult to do. But we've been an aggressive acquirer of our shares over the last, I would say, 6 or 9 months. We try to be an opportunistic acquirer and I think we'll continue to do that in the future and take advantages when we think the stock is particularly, in a particularly valuable level. So as you suggest, we certainly have the financial flexibility to do all that, to respond to opportunities as they arise but also to be -- to continue to be an aggressive acquirer on our shares.

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. I thought I'd just ask, maybe on the payer side, both from the managed care and government side. On the managed care side, do you have any update on how contracting is going for 2017 at this point? I know it's early, but particularly you have a fair
componenttext: Okay. I thought I'd just ask, maybe on the payer side, both from the managed care and government side. On the managed care side, do you have any update on how contracting is going for 2017 at this point? I know it's early, but particularly you have a fair of number of contracts rework. Any change in approach you're seeing from pricing or terms that they're asking for? And then I would probably also ask on the Medicare side, there seems to be this push toward bundled payments. Do you -- have you had any experience so far? I know they rolled out the joint replacement bundle payment in April. So it's still fairly early. But just any early experience on that?

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: So I think we feel, AJ, that we're prepared for the -- what I think we view as sort of the inexorable move to more shifting that would include more bundled methodology payment. We were volunteers in some of the early Medicare demonstration programs. We ca
componenttext: So I think we feel, AJ, that we're prepared for the -- what I think we view as sort of the inexorable move to more shifting that would include more bundled methodology payment. We were volunteers in some of the early Medicare demonstration programs. We can remain in some of those. We've exit some. I think it's a developing and a continually evolving area. But I think we have worked now for probably the last 2 or 3 years to make sure that we're prepared for it. So I think we remain prepared. Obviously, Medicare announced just in the last couple of days an expansion of their bundle payment program. But the number of the details, I think, are still somewhat fuzzy. So it's difficult to, again, make any precise predictions. As far as managed care contracting, I think we're probably still 45, 60 days away from the real sort of the height of the 2017 renegotiation process. But I would suggest that we're not seeing huge changes, either in our rates or in the structure of those contracts from what we've been experiencing over the last few years.

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016

componenttext: The question I had and I wonder if anybody explored this, just that late into the call, is just on connecting the dots between your deterioration in bad debt from 1Q [ph] to 2Q, and again the same thing on your acute volumes. Does that give you pause around what the driver of your volumes is? Or are you still thinking this is economically bound, rather than exchanges which seems like the more obvious thing the tick up in membership in the first quarter and consistent with what the management companies are complaining about in the claims processing for?

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Ana, I think we have touched on it. I'll just iterate a little bit what I said before. I think we're running about 2% to 2.5% increase in uninsured volumes. I think that's consistent with what our original guidance and original model was. So no, I me
componenttext: Yes, Ana, I think we have touched on it. I'll just iterate a little bit what I said before. I think we're running about 2% to 2.5% increase in uninsured volumes. I think that's consistent with what our original guidance and original model was. So no, I mean I think and we talked at great length in Q1 where we really had extraordinary acute care volumes, that those were largely driven by Medicare volumes. And I think that was reflected in our very strong pricing. The moderation in our Medicare volumes in Q2 has caused the pricing to against that, back some. But we're largely in-line in Q2 with what we expected to be our overall same-store acute care pricing. So from my perspective, I'm not sure that there were any sort of sinister dots to connect, but we'll certainly see as it continues to play out.

componenttext: Did you see anything specific in terms of geographies? You had pretty solid year-over-year growth and I'm just trying compare to the baseline in '15 in 1Q relative to 2Q. So was it just about comps? Or was it something else, I guess that is absolutely actual?

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: I just remind people that in the first quarter our acute care same-store revenue grew by 12%. That's about as an extraordinary number as you're going to find. And I think anybody who had the expectation that we could sustain a number like that was hitting
componenttext: I just remind people that in the first quarter our acute care same-store revenue grew by 12%. That's about as an extraordinary number as you're going to find. And I think anybody who had the expectation that we could sustain a number like that was hitting themselves and we certainly encourage people to think that way. So when we moderate to something closer to 7% in Q2, again, I think that's going to wind up being a number that's going to be pretty competitive amongst our peers, we'll see. But it doesn't reflect any significant or uninspected changes in payer mix.

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then on the outpatient side, our final question on this. It seems again it's always been some insurers to mixed shifting into outpatient. It feels like those accelerated mixed shift to outpatients surgery or even ambulatory surgery, ortho procedures a
componenttext: And then on the outpatient side, our final question on this. It seems again it's always been some insurers to mixed shifting into outpatient. It feels like those accelerated mixed shift to outpatients surgery or even ambulatory surgery, ortho procedures and cardiologists seeing more convenience in and out of [indiscernible] setting. Are you seeing something that points to something structural in this arena and going forward that might actually really put pressure on the inpatient side? And then connecting it to the value based care question earlier, that the incentives will be far more to try to mitigate cost while sharing the reimbursement over time in the Q?

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: We certainly have seen the continued shift to outpatient that, as you suggest, I think virtually every provider in America has recognized. Again, I'm just going to go back and say that even with that continued shift, which has been underway for years now,
componenttext: We certainly have seen the continued shift to outpatient that, as you suggest, I think virtually every provider in America has recognized. Again, I'm just going to go back and say that even with that continued shift, which has been underway for years now, the 4% same-store adjusted admission growth in Q2 is certainly well within our expectations, and I think is a reflection of even with that shift to outpatients, that we're still seeing growth on the inpatient side for all the reasons I described before, strong franchises, taking market share from competitors, recovering economies, et cetera. So yes, we see that same dynamic that everybody else sees, but we're still posting pretty good inpatient numbers at the same time.

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Steve, on bad debt, is it all uninsured or are you seeing any sort of bad debt creep in the uncollectable amount of pocket that might be having an impact on the uninsured? And any changes to your collection percentages that you see?
componenttext: Steve, on bad debt, is it all uninsured or are you seeing any sort of bad debt creep in the uncollectable amount of pocket that might be having an impact on the uninsured? And any changes to your collection percentages that you see?

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure, Ralph. And again this is a trend that I think is now underway for a while now. There's no question that over the last few years, the amount of the hospital bill that is due from the patient because of co-pays and deductibles has grown. And as a cons
componenttext: Sure, Ralph. And again this is a trend that I think is now underway for a while now. There's no question that over the last few years, the amount of the hospital bill that is due from the patient because of co-pays and deductibles has grown. And as a consequence, the amount we collect on that portion of the bill has declined. So 10 years ago, we collected 55% to 60% of the patient portion of the bill. And today, that number has probably dropped to 45%. That's been a gradual change. We've accounted for it. It has contributed to some degree to the rise in uncompensated care. But I think we've also always said that 2/3 of our overall uncompensated care numbers are the result of those who purely have no insurance and I think that remains largely the case.

componenttext: We didn't, and I don't think we ever had in large part because in contrast with some of our peers. I think we have always viewed it as a relatively difficult thing to do with precision to identify patients who have exchanged -- or those who have exchange coverage versus those might just have regular commercial coverage.

componenttext: Yes, so we acquired a health plan, a provider base health plan in the Reno market just about 2 years ago at this point. I did comment before that we had about $25 million to $30 million increase in the quarter in both premium revenues and other operating expenses. The real, the rationale for acquiring that business, which we have talked about on previous calls, more so at the time when we made the acquisition, is really to prepare for this risk shifting with several of the last questions we focused on. But it's more of the risk shift to the provider, we will have to shift our focus to more sort of an underwriting exercise. And we think having that insurance infrastructure and insurance expertise is helpful when you're doing that sort of analysis and that continues to be our belief.

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
