componenttext: Yes. So just I think in terms of the most critical metrics in the quarter on the acute side, emergency room visits were up 4% to 5%. Inpatient surgeries were up 3% or so. Outpatient were up 4%. All those, I think, relatively strong metrics were consistent with the overall admission strength and revenue strength in the acute business for the quarter.

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: The next question will come from Justin Lake with Wolfe Research.
componenttext: The next question will come from Justin Lake with Wolfe Research.

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: A couple questions on behavioral. I guess, first, just the -- can you give us your view kind of on the third quarter in terms of the trajectory here? Volumes improved a little bit. Obviously you're spending to staff these -- to staff the hospitals. But ma
componenttext: A couple questions on behavioral. I guess, first, just the -- can you give us your view kind of on the third quarter in terms of the trajectory here? Volumes improved a little bit. Obviously you're spending to staff these -- to staff the hospitals. But maybe spike out the 10% of facilities and what you're seeing there. I mean, it seems like they were down 20%, 30% previously. Are you seeing some improvement there? And what's going on with the rest of the core business, the other 90%?

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. So I think from the beginning, Justin, and the beginning I think in my mind was just the third quarter of last year, so we've been talking about muted volumes in the behavioral business for about a year now, largely driven by staffing shortages, sho
componenttext:
Sure. So I think from the beginning, Justin, and the beginning I think in my mind was just the third quarter of last year, so we've been talking about muted volumes in the behavioral business for about a year now, largely driven by staffing shortages, shortages of psychiatrists and nurses. I think it started out as more of a psychiatrist kind of centered problem and has evolved into more of a nursing shortage problem. 
But I think what we have highlighted, and there's no sort of perfect way to kind of parse this issue, but we identified 4 or 5 or 6 markets that were most problematic in terms of having vacancies for these clinical positions and having to turn away patients and as a consequence have significantly and measurably muted volumes in those markets because we simply didn't have enough qualified clinical professionals to treat those patients. 
Over the course of the year, I think the markets have largely remained the same. We think those markets probably encompass, depending on how you count them, some 20-odd facilities. And again, during the 12 months, maybe a facility sort of entered the list or came off the list, but I think for the most part the list remained the same. 
I think we've seen some improvement in those markets. Sort of by definition, I think our overall volumes are increasing a little bit. I think we see pockets of weakness in some of the other markets. But I think, for the most part, we continue to believe that if we focus on the 4 or 5 most problematic markets, as we have been, that we'll continue to make progress. 
I think, and you alluded to this a little bit, I think, in your question, I think the third quarter was a bit of a -- kind of a whipsaw for us in the sense that as we are hiring new nurses, as we're paying sign-on bonuses, as we're investing in the sort of recruitment and retention of nurses, our labor costs are going up. We clearly saw that in Q3. And honestly, our volumes are going up a little bit but they're not responding as quickly. Part of this is just a mechanical sort of a process. As we hire nurses, they have to give notice at their old jobs if they're coming from another employer. Then they join us, and they go through an orientation or a training, and so we're paying them and we're incurring costs, but we're not necessarily able to increase volumes immediately. And I think what you saw in Q3 was a little bit of that sort of dynamic of increased cost without the complete benefit of the commensurate increase in volumes. We think that's a relatively temporary situation that should continue to improve pretty measurably over the next quarter or 2.

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: So that was my second question, Steve, is just the trajectory here, it sounds like you think it's going to improve and it should improve, given the spending you're making here. Can you talk about the pace of improvement and how you think it gets -- when y
componenttext: So that was my second question, Steve, is just the trajectory here, it sounds like you think it's going to improve and it should improve, given the spending you're making here. Can you talk about the pace of improvement and how you think it gets -- when you think it gets back to that target 5% -- 4% to 5%, 6% same-store revenue growth range? And then, given the level of spending, can you walk us through what you would think would be a reasonable equation, let's just say for 2017, in terms of the -- if same-store growth is 4%, 5%, what does that equate to in terms of EBITDA growth if you get there?

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: So our original guidance for 2016 for our behavioral business, same-store behavioral business was 5% revenue growth, which was -- sort of the implied metrics for that was 3% to 4% volume growth and 1% to 2% pricing. I think, for the most part, we've been
componenttext:
So our original guidance for 2016 for our behavioral business, same-store behavioral business was 5% revenue growth, which was -- sort of the implied metrics for that was 3% to 4% volume growth and 1% to 2% pricing. I think, for the most part, we've been hitting those pricing targets, so this really is a volume issue. And so when you parse those numbers, we are somewhere 200, 250 basis points short of volumes from where we thought we would be. 
We also thought that if we could get to that 5% volume growth we would get to something like a 6% or 7% expansion of EBITDA, or growth in EBITDA. And I think that those -- that assumption and that EBITDA growth already presumed, because when we gave our guidance for the year we were certainly well aware of the labor shortage already at that time, so I think it presumed that we would be raising salaries, we would be spending and investing more money in recruitment and retention. And so that EBITDA growth, in comparison to the revenue growth, was already sort of factoring in some amount of labor pressure. 
So really, I think the question you're asking, which is a perfectly reasonable one, is when do we get this additional 200, 250 basis points in volume. I think we feel like we're doing most of the right things. I think we feel like we're making progress. I think we feel like at some point next year, in 2017, we will get there. Exactly how quickly we get there, exactly when that improvement comes and how quickly that improvement comes is difficult to say. Obviously, the next time we speak to this group will be in late February when we give our 2017 guidance. I think we'll be in a much better position to be more precise at that time. But I think we certainly feel that the metrics that we laid out for this year are well within reach and certainly achievable at some point during 2017.

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: The next question will come from Ralph Giacobbe with Citi.
componenttext: The next question will come from Ralph Giacobbe with Citi.

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just wanted to stick to the labor side. Can you give us a sense, Steve, at this point what the average weight rating -- wage rate increases are today versus, say, a year or 2 years ago, maybe both across acute and psych and how you think about that sort o
componenttext:
Just wanted to stick to the labor side. Can you give us a sense, Steve, at this point what the average weight rating -- wage rate increases are today versus, say, a year or 2 years ago, maybe both across acute and psych and how you think about that sort of on a go-forward basis, even if you do get volume back from sort of the ability to grow EBITDA or the level of EBITDA growth? 
And then if you can also comment on what was contract labor in the quarter and maybe versus a year ago, just to give us just some sense of what the magnitude there is of that correction.

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: So I think that the challenge in both of these businesses has not really been underlying wage rates. I think on the acute side, I think the challenge has mostly been the use of what we describe as premium pay. And that is paying either our own nurses over
componenttext:
So I think that the challenge in both of these businesses has not really been underlying wage rates. I think on the acute side, I think the challenge has mostly been the use of what we describe as premium pay. And that is paying either our own nurses overtime or shift differentials or whatever to work additional or incremental shifts or paying temporary or registry nurses generally a fairly significant premium over what would be our normal rate of pay. And that's really what's driving up our average wage rates. I don't think our underlying, sort of, I'll call them normalized wage rates, I would say, in the acute division are going up much more than sort of 3%, 3.5%. Maybe that's 50 basis points higher than what we might have thought a year ago but not a huge needle mover. 
Just I think as sort of to put it in context, I think in normal -- in sort of a normal environment, we would expect the use of temporary nurses to represent something in any given quarter around 2% of our overall labor force. I think in this quarter, that number was between 2 and 3x that. And even though that doesn't seem -- it seems like it's relatively small numbers, but because you're paying those temporary nurses in many cases twice what you're paying a regular nurse, the impact starts to add up relatively quickly. 
Same thing I think is true on the behavioral side. The real issue -- and if you've looked at our segment data for the last 4 quarters or so, you don't see a lot of pressure on our wage line in behavioral. And that's because, quite frankly, we've just been unable to find sufficient number of nurses. It's really not been a question of willingness to pay them or to use temporary nurses or whatever. It's just been an absolute inability to find them at all, especially in these markets that I alluded to before. 
So I'm going to say the same thing. I mean, I think wage rates in the -- underlying wage rates in the behavioral division are maybe going up at this point 2.5% or 3%. And maybe that's 50 basis points higher than what we thought. But I don't think it's driving the numbers measurably, other than what I said before. I think already our EBITDA growth targets that we already had talked about for 2016 for both divisions I think already incorporated some amount of this labor pressure that we've been talking about.

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, that's helpful. And then can you give us a sense of payer mix in the quarter?
componenttext: Okay, that's helpful. And then can you give us a sense of payer mix in the quarter?

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I mean, the payer mix, which I think is largely reflected in -- I mean, I'm talking in the acute business, in the 3% revenue per day increase roughly, I think reflects our government business, Medicare-Medicaid being up. Our adjusted admissions for t
componenttext:
Yes, I mean, the payer mix, which I think is largely reflected in -- I mean, I'm talking in the acute business, in the 3% revenue per day increase roughly, I think reflects our government business, Medicare-Medicaid being up. Our adjusted admissions for the quarter were up about 4.5%. I think our government admissions were up in that neighborhood. Commercial admissions, while up, were up slightly less than that, maybe 1%, 1.5%. And then I think on insured admissions were up a little bit more than the average, probably in the 6%, 7% range. And again, these are all trends that I think we've talked about for, I would say, since the middle of last year. As the benefits of the ACA have started to anniversary, we're not continuing to get that benefit of increased Medicaid -- from increased Medicaid expansion. Continued commercial enrollment, as a matter of fact, I think we're seeing some level of disenrollment as premiums rise and other factors occur. 
So I think all that payer mix sort of trending has been ongoing for about a year now. We see some volatility between quarters. But if you look at the 4- or 5-month trend, I think you'll see that we've been hitting that sort of 3% revenue per admission growth rate pretty consistently over that period of time.

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, that's helpful. If I could squeeze one more in, Steve. Can you give us a sense of some of the progress of some of these JVs and partnerships that you've talked about or any other arrangements you have with hospitals around sort of trying to ultimate
componenttext: Okay, that's helpful. If I could squeeze one more in, Steve. Can you give us a sense of some of the progress of some of these JVs and partnerships that you've talked about or any other arrangements you have with hospitals around sort of trying to ultimately capture, I guess, the IMD benefit as we think about next year? When will this sort of get turned on, if you will, and kind of run through the P&L? Can you give us a sense of whether the magnitude of some of these relationships have the ability to sort of move the needle? Or are you in the process of still signing these up, where it's just not anything we should be expecting to come through the P&L anytime soon?

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: So I think it's worth noting that these conversations with acute care hospitals on the behavioral side of the business have been ongoing now for probably a couple years. And a number of these arrangements have already been entered into and some of them ar
componenttext:
So I think it's worth noting that these conversations with acute care hospitals on the behavioral side of the business have been ongoing now for probably a couple years. And a number of these arrangements have already been entered into and some of them are already in operation. I think that the first few of the arrangements that we entered into were just these sort of lease arrangements, where we would joint venture with large not-for-profit health care systems. I mentioned in my opening remarks a deal to build a new hospital with Providence in the Washington state market. But we already have 2 other arrangements where we just occupied existing units which we lease from Providence and run behavioral units there. And both of them are ongoing for some time and have been incorporated in our results for some time. 
Overall, it is a significant focus, probably from a business development perspective the single biggest focus in the behavioral division. This is what we describe as acute care integration efforts. And so I think that they will continue and will continue to enter into new ones. Exactly how significant they'll be I think remains to be seen. And some of them will take some time to develop. I mentioned the Lancaster General joint venture in my remarks. But that hospital, new hospital will not open until 2018. 
I think when we give our guidance for 2017, we will probably sort of frame it as here's our same-store expectations in terms of volume and revenue growth, and then we will probably separately spike out what the impact of these new ventures will be. And I think we'll probably do that, frankly, on a continuing basis after that.

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: The next question will come from Paula Torch with Avondale Partners.
componenttext: The next question will come from Paula Torch with Avondale Partners.

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Steve, I guess I wanted to start off with the behavioral business. I had a question on the list of the 20-or-so facilities, and maybe you could share with us what the occupancy looks like in those markets currently and maybe how quickly you can ramp up th
componenttext: Steve, I guess I wanted to start off with the behavioral business. I had a question on the list of the 20-or-so facilities, and maybe you could share with us what the occupancy looks like in those markets currently and maybe how quickly you can ramp up those facilities when you do add on those nurses or potentially a psychiatrist in order -- I mean, I realize that you talked about getting that volume and that we're not really sure how much longer it's going to take. But I'm just curious from that standpoint in terms of occupancy, what do you see when you add a nurse? And how does that impact your effective beds?

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: So I think -- and I probably could have been clearer about this. I mean, when we identified those 4, 5, 6 markets and the 20-or-so hospitals, the way that we identified them or the criteria we used was that in those hospitals we had actually closed a unit
componenttext:
So I think -- and I probably could have been clearer about this. I mean, when we identified those 4, 5, 6 markets and the 20-or-so hospitals, the way that we identified them or the criteria we used was that in those hospitals we had actually closed a unit or closed a number of beds or we capped our census so that in an 80-bed hospital we were capping or limiting our census to, let's say, 40 patients, or whatever the amount of sort of qualified nurses we had would limit us to. 
Certainly, elsewhere in the portfolio we were facing some pressures of turning away a patient on this day or not having enough nurses on a particular day. But these were hospitals where, again, we had closed a unit or we had capped our census for an extended period of time. And that's how we were categorizing them. I think at those hospitals -- and I don't have the occupancy data in front of me, Paula, but I will say that at those hospitals on average, I think their patient days or their volumes were down during this period, I would say 10% to 15%. And again, I think that the bulk of the effort to get the division back to the 200, 250 basis point shortage in volumes that we're really facing from our original guidance is getting those hospitals back to kind of the 3% or 4% volume growth that we think most of the rest of the portfolio is posting. 
Obviously, if we can't get those hospitals back to that level and we can get the remaining 180 hospitals or whatever the exact number is to increase their volumes by 25 or 50 basis points, I mean, that will get us to the same place. But I think we just tried to frame it that way because I think, frankly, it helped us as we tried to focus on addressing this problem and we thought it would help people understand that, as with many things, this was really kind of an 80-20 issue and the bulk of our focus was on a relatively small number of markets and facilities that were facing the most dramatic shortages.

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And so maybe just as a follow-up, does this -- trying to improve these -- the 20% of these hospitals, let's just say, does that impact your ability or your thoughts about growth for next year? I mean, you opened, I think you said, 373 beds in the fi
componenttext: Okay. And so maybe just as a follow-up, does this -- trying to improve these -- the 20% of these hospitals, let's just say, does that impact your ability or your thoughts about growth for next year? I mean, you opened, I think you said, 373 beds in the first 9 months. I would assume that you're going to close the year with more than that. So does that impact how you're thinking about bed growth and bed expansions? Or do you feel like the 80% of the market that's left still has a lot of room to grow? And have you really seen any changes or shifts in the demand for your services in the U.S.? I mean, from everything that we read, there continues to be a supply-demand disconnect. And I would like to know if you would continue to agree with that.

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, I think, Paula, we share that view. And I think we have said again for the last year that this is not a problem of diminishing demand in sort of the underlying fundamentals of this business. As a matter of fact I think, if anything, we believe that, a
componenttext:
No, I think, Paula, we share that view. And I think we have said again for the last year that this is not a problem of diminishing demand in sort of the underlying fundamentals of this business. As a matter of fact I think, if anything, we believe that, again, the underlying demand has done nothing but increase and continues to increase. And our view of both the intermediate and long-term prospects from a demand perspective in this business remain extremely robust and we're very enthusiastic about it. And instead, we're focused on what we believe is a much more near-term issue of making sure that we have, again, enough qualified staff in all of our facilities to satisfy that demand. 
I think that obviously, and as you pointed out, I mean, the fact that we're adding beds -- and obviously, we're adding beds in markets where we do have enough qualified staff and we can accommodate those patients. And we're not necessarily adding beds in those markets where we don't have enough staff. Now at some point, we may add beds in those markets as we resolve the problem. But I mean, our continued investment in capacity in the business I think is a reflection of the fact that we expect it to grow at fairly robust rates. I mean, I'm not going to tell you we're not prepared to give 2017 guidance today. But I think when we give our guidance in 2017, it will reflect the fact that we believe, a, the business is going to continue to grow, and b, that we'll continue to find new ways to enter markets, particularly the acute care hospital market, and help to penetrate their behavioral services, which will also help the business grow.

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016

componenttext:
The next question will come from Kevin Fischbeck with BoA. 
Okay, he has withdrawn his question. The next question will come from Gary Lieberman with Wells Fargo.

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Steve, can you talk a little bit about the IMD exclusion benefit? Is the expectation that it's still going to take place primarily in 2017 as you enter networks where it's available? And are you on track to achieve that?
componenttext: Steve, can you talk a little bit about the IMD exclusion benefit? Is the expectation that it's still going to take place primarily in 2017 as you enter networks where it's available? And are you on track to achieve that?

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. So the IMD, the lifting of the IMD exclusion for the managed Medicaid population could occur as early as July of '16 (sic) [ '17 ] if the states approved that. And I think some of our states have done so. I think we always had the view that the immed
componenttext:
Yes. So the IMD, the lifting of the IMD exclusion for the managed Medicaid population could occur as early as July of '16 (sic) [ '17 ] if the states approved that. And I think some of our states have done so. I think we always had the view that the immediate impact of the lifting of the IMD exclusion, particularly in sort of a midyear cycle, was going to be fairly minimal because networks were already established, a benefit plan design was already established, and to have effectively new hospitals join the network midyear and to really redirect a substantial number of patients was not a terribly practical matter in the middle of the year. So I think in that sense, we always had the view that beginning with a new plan year in January of '17 we would get more of a measurable impact. 
And the reality is some states will not approve the lifting until July of '17, so some of this may be delayed even until '18. 
I think, however, our view of this has also evolved to, and this really encompasses my previous remarks, to believe that really the greatest opportunity we have here to take advantage of that adult Medicaid population are these arrangements that we will reach collaboratively with acute care hospitals to joint venture with them, to lease beds from them, to help them manage units because that -- those opportunities will give us access, not only to their adult Medicaid patient population but also to their commercial population, to their Medicare population. And so in some respects, the opportunity that we're pursuing through that avenue is even greater than the IMD opportunity. Although in fairness, it will take some time to realize as we have to negotiate these arrangements and implement them and in some cases build new capacity or in some cases renovate existing capacity. So there's some time lags in all this. But ultimately, given the fact that half of all the behavioral beds in the U.S. reside in acute care hospitals, we think that this opportunity to penetrate those beds is a tremendous and, as I remarked before, probably the single biggest business development opportunity we have domestically over the next 5 years or so.

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great, that's very helpful. And then if -- you're talking about -- there's been a fair amount in the news over the past week or so about premium increases on exchange products and different players potentially leaving markets and decreasing choice. Can yo
componenttext: Great, that's very helpful. And then if -- you're talking about -- there's been a fair amount in the news over the past week or so about premium increases on exchange products and different players potentially leaving markets and decreasing choice. Can you talk about maybe what you expect to see in your markets next year and what impact, if any, that might have on the acute care business?

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. So look, I think the reality is I don't know that we have kind of a terribly sort of insightful view of how this is all going to play out. I will make just some preliminary comments that we have said from the very beginning of the Affordable Care Act
componenttext:
Yes. So look, I think the reality is I don't know that we have kind of a terribly sort of insightful view of how this is all going to play out. I will make just some preliminary comments that we have said from the very beginning of the Affordable Care Act that the bulk of the benefit that we've realized from the Affordable Care Act tended to be on the Medicaid expansion side of the ACA. I think on a percentage basis, we had more hospital beds in expansion states than any of our peers, mostly because of our significant oversized presence in Nevada. But obviously, we benefited in California, we benefited in the District of Columbia. The amount of benefit that we got from commercial exchange enrollment was always more limited. And so to the degree that there is some level of disenrollment, which I think there is and probably will continue to be, I think will impact us but will not impact us in a terribly material and measurable way. 
And I think it's also worth noting that we've said from the outset that I think the ACA has had a relatively minor impact on the behavioral business. And so again, I think to the degree that there is disruption in the markets, that there is disenrollment, that there's a limiting number of payers remaining, I don't think that's going to have a measurable impact on us. I will say that in most of our markets there still are multiple exchange providers in business. And a Blue Cross plan almost inevitably is one of them. But even though we've seen some players leave the market, I think in most of our markets there remains some level of choice and competition. So I think that is helpful.

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: The next question will come from A.J. Rice with UBS.
componenttext: The next question will come from A.J. Rice with UBS.

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: A couple of quick ones, hopefully. Just to think about the margin trend on the acute side with those volumes that were, frankly, stronger than we thought they'd be, I know you're pointing to overtime usage and contract labor, but is the right way to think
componenttext: A couple of quick ones, hopefully. Just to think about the margin trend on the acute side with those volumes that were, frankly, stronger than we thought they'd be, I know you're pointing to overtime usage and contract labor, but is the right way to think about it is that's sort of the way it's going to be now, that even if you have strong volumes you're not going to be able to get the margin leverage? Or can we assume that somehow the volumes came in stronger than you were expecting and you were scrambling somewhat to keep staffing in line and that if those volumes continue to be strong you will get margin leverage?

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: So, A.J., I'm going to go back again. I talked about sort of our original presumptions for behavioral margins for the year and behavioral business. I'm going to do it on the acute as well. Our 2016 acute care guidance presumed 6% revenue growth and 7% or
componenttext:
So, A.J., I'm going to go back again. I talked about sort of our original presumptions for behavioral margins for the year and behavioral business. I'm going to do it on the acute as well. Our 2016 acute care guidance presumed 6% revenue growth and 7% or 8% EBITDA growth. And again, I think those projections and that EBITDA growth already presume that there would be some level of labor inflation because of pressure on wage rates and pressure on increased use of premium pay, et cetera. 
The acute results have been choppier and a little bit more volatile than the behavioral results, I think. And I've encouraged people not to look at a particular quarter as sort of reflective or emblematic of the trajectory but to look at the last 4 or 5 quarters combined. And I think if you look at the business that way, we have been pretty routinely hitting at least that 6% revenue growth target. And I think during that period we do also have margin expansion. Again, I don't think we're going to have it every single quarter. I think there will be some quarters that will be tighter than others. But I think over time, those metrics that I laid out are still very sustainable from our point of view.

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. You mentioned these, the 2 deals that you're working on, on the behavioral side in collaboration. Are those traditional joint ventures? Can you give us a little bit more flavor? Are you taking on the bulk of the capital commitment there or is that -
componenttext: Okay. You mentioned these, the 2 deals that you're working on, on the behavioral side in collaboration. Are those traditional joint ventures? Can you give us a little bit more flavor? Are you taking on the bulk of the capital commitment there or is that -- are they participating, your partners participating with you on that?

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: So I think it's difficult to describe kind of the model deal here. Everyone is different. I described a number of arrangements we have where we simply lease beds from an acute care hospital and run a behavioral unit effectively in their building or on the
componenttext:
So I think it's difficult to describe kind of the model deal here. Everyone is different. I described a number of arrangements we have where we simply lease beds from an acute care hospital and run a behavioral unit effectively in their building or on their campus. And in those cases, we take on all the economics other than paying them a lease payment. In the deals that I described in my remarks, we're building new facilities. And in each of those cases, I think the acute care partner will contribute their percentage of the capital investment. And the partnership percentages vary. Some of these are 50-50 deals. Some of them are 80-20 deals where we're the 80% partner. Again, I think one of the things that we're willing to do is to provide these acute care hospitals with a lot of optionality as to how we can proceed. And we'd love to have all the economics where -- but if we have an acute care partner who wants to retain a significant amount of economics and we can reach an agreement on that, I think we're happy to do that. 
So I think you're going to see these deals take a lot of different forms. In the end, I think they all provide us an opportunity to broach a patient population that we've just never been able to really penetrate before in a meaningful way.

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: A.J., our moderate position with regards to that on the corporate level is attractive because people that are dealing with us realize if it works out properly we have the capital to invest. So it makes us more attractive than others who are overleveraged.
componenttext: A.J., our moderate position with regards to that on the corporate level is attractive because people that are dealing with us realize if it works out properly we have the capital to invest. So it makes us more attractive than others who are overleveraged.

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I understand that. I was just -- that was my last question, on the capital deployment from here. I know you were active on the buyback front in the quarter. I know you have said there are deals out there you're talking to, both on the behavioral and
componenttext: Yes, I understand that. I was just -- that was my last question, on the capital deployment from here. I know you were active on the buyback front in the quarter. I know you have said there are deals out there you're talking to, both on the behavioral and acute side. Any update on where you think the capital is going? Is it -- are these projects going to take on more capital, you think? Or is it more of those other 2?

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Look, I think, A.J., we always describe ourselves as opportunistic. And that's not a throwaway kind of term from our perspective. I think we believe that we're going to try and respond to opportunities on both the acute and behavioral side that make econo
componenttext:
Look, I think, A.J., we always describe ourselves as opportunistic. And that's not a throwaway kind of term from our perspective. I think we believe that we're going to try and respond to opportunities on both the acute and behavioral side that make economic sense and that earn a reasonable return, whether those opportunities are organic and building new facilities, as we've done in Las Vegas, or inorganic through acquisitions on the behavioral side or inorganic through these investments in new partnerships with acute hospitals. 
And as you point out, we've also been an active acquirer of our own shares. We're bullish on the intermediate and long-term prospects of both of our business segments and feel like our current valuations are reasonable. And investing in our own EBITDA stream is a good investment as well. So I think you're going to continue to see us do all these things, continue to invest capital in our existing franchises that are growing and are strengthening or being strengthened in these new arrangements with acute hospitals on the behavioral side. And we're going to continue to look at M&A on both sides of the business as well and be an active acquirer of our own shares.

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question will come from Frank Morgan with RBC Capital Markets.
componenttext: Your next question will come from Frank Morgan with RBC Capital Markets.

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Steve, I was hoping you could give us a little color on the sequential -- or I'm sorry, the progression through the months of the quarter maybe on the 2 lines of business. And then secondly, looking at your updated guidance, it sort of implies at the midp
componenttext: Steve, I was hoping you could give us a little color on the sequential -- or I'm sorry, the progression through the months of the quarter maybe on the 2 lines of business. And then secondly, looking at your updated guidance, it sort of implies at the midpoint that your adjustment is really less than the amount of the shortfall of this quarter. So I'm curious, what do you see so far, maybe in October, that gives us confidence over the -- for the balance of the year?

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. So, I mean, I'll just remind people everything -- a week in health care seems like a lifetime. But back in July, there were a number of these sell-side surveys that were suggesting volumes were very weak, and there was a lot of concern and I guess ev
componenttext:
Yes. So, I mean, I'll just remind people everything -- a week in health care seems like a lifetime. But back in July, there were a number of these sell-side surveys that were suggesting volumes were very weak, and there was a lot of concern and I guess even panic over that. I think providers pointed out the fact that the calendar was sort of working against us and that August would look better. And in fact, I think we said at our September conferences that July and August volumes combined looked kind of where we expected they'd be. So I think other than that sort of dynamic, there was nothing about the sort of progression or trajectory of the quarter that was terribly noteworthy. 
Look, I think the take on our guidance from my perspective was we were a little bit short of our own internal projections for the quarter. I think the midpoint of the revised guidance presumes that the trends for Q3 sort of just continue into Q4 and we'd probably be a little bit short again in Q4. If things improve and we're able to make some improvements, some more immediate improvements in both of the businesses, we should be able to gravitate towards the higher end of the range. And if things worsen, which is not really our expectation at this point, but if they did, we would gravitate more to the lower end of the range.

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: But just one follow-up to be clear. Between the 2 lines, both behavioral and acute, the trends were similar for both? Or did you see any differences across the quarter in the 2 businesses?
componenttext: But just one follow-up to be clear. Between the 2 lines, both behavioral and acute, the trends were similar for both? Or did you see any differences across the quarter in the 2 businesses?

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, I don't think we saw any significant differences between the 2 businesses.
componenttext: No, I don't think we saw any significant differences between the 2 businesses.

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: The next question will come from Josh Raskin with Barclays.
componenttext: The next question will come from Josh Raskin with Barclays.

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: First question, just on behavioral, and I heard some of the comments, Steve, and I apologize if I missed others, on the underlying demand for behavioral health services. But do you think there's any potential that we're seeing in the marketplace, just bet
componenttext: First question, just on behavioral, and I heard some of the comments, Steve, and I apologize if I missed others, on the underlying demand for behavioral health services. But do you think there's any potential that we're seeing in the marketplace, just better treatment options, better pharmaceuticals, et cetera? Is that -- is it possible that, that's sort of cycling through and that maybe we're seeing a temporary reduction in demand for those services?

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: So look, I think that there's no question there has been an effort. And look, this is not exclusive to the behavioral business, but certainly in the behavioral business, on the part of payers to move patients to lower-cost settings of care. And so we've b
componenttext:
So look, I think that there's no question there has been an effort. And look, this is not exclusive to the behavioral business, but certainly in the behavioral business, on the part of payers to move patients to lower-cost settings of care. And so we've been under pressure, and none of this is new, to discharge patients as soon as is clinically appropriate, and I think we would argue in some cases even before it's clinically appropriate, to move patients into outpatient settings or group homes or whatever it may be. 
But again, when I say that the underlying demand remains strong, Josh, I think we measure it by -- we've talked a little bit about this concept, I think, on previous calls. We measure something we call deflections, which is when a patient is presented to us and they meet clinical criteria and they have some appropriate level of payment and effectively are eligible for admissions and we're unable to admit them, either because -- historically the main reason we couldn't admit them is we didn't have a bed available in certain markets and certain hospitals and more recently, in the last year or so, because we didn't have sufficient number of staff. But the number of deflections remain high. The number of patients who are being presented to us and meet the criteria to be admitted remains quite high. And those patients are being, again, deflected or turned away. And I think in a lot of these markets where a labor shortage is the issue, we think they're being turned away from multiple facilities. In other words, they're not finding treatment anywhere. 
And so again, I think that the scenario that you present is perfectly legitimate and it's been occurring and, frankly, it's been occurring for a long time. I don't think it's necessarily accelerated or is terribly new in its form. But I think that the underlying -- my view would be the underlying demand remains quite strong despite those efforts.

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, that makes sense. And then just a quick follow-up on CapEx. I know you guys had some big projects come online in Vegas, et cetera. And I know you've got a moderated view of CapEx for next year. But are there any big projects you guys are contemplati
componenttext: Okay, that makes sense. And then just a quick follow-up on CapEx. I know you guys had some big projects come online in Vegas, et cetera. And I know you've got a moderated view of CapEx for next year. But are there any big projects you guys are contemplating where CapEx could be similar to 2016? Or would that be highly unlikely at this point in the planning?

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: So there are certainly no whole hospital acute care build projects that I think are on the drawing board for 2017, which I think is why we expect some moderation in the overall level of CapEx spend in 2017. But as I was sort of responding to A.J.'s questi
componenttext: So there are certainly no whole hospital acute care build projects that I think are on the drawing board for 2017, which I think is why we expect some moderation in the overall level of CapEx spend in 2017. But as I was sort of responding to A.J.'s question before, I do think we see lots of other opportunities to expand services, to build new behavioral beds, et cetera. So again, I think we believe that CapEx will moderate some in 2017. But we're not going to see a dramatic decline because I think we think that there are still a lot of good opportunities out there to build revenue and EBITDA-producing capacity. Obviously, again, when we give our guidance in February, we'll have a much more precise number to provide to everybody. But I think at least order of magnitude, that sort of shows you where we're headed.

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: The next question will come from Ana Gupte with Leerink.
componenttext: The next question will come from Ana Gupte with Leerink.

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: So the first question I had, and I just got in a bit late, but on the acute side, how confident are you that the strength that you're seeing will continue? And is this still more Medicare? That was what you had alluded to in previous quarters.
componenttext: So the first question I had, and I just got in a bit late, but on the acute side, how confident are you that the strength that you're seeing will continue? And is this still more Medicare? That was what you had alluded to in previous quarters.

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Look, Ana, I never like to boldly say we're 100% confident of anything. But if you look, as I've suggested before, at the last 4 or 5 acute care quarters, even in what I sort of think about, is I sort of think about like the third quarter of 2015 rea
componenttext:
Yes. Look, Ana, I never like to boldly say we're 100% confident of anything. But if you look, as I've suggested before, at the last 4 or 5 acute care quarters, even in what I sort of think about, is I sort of think about like the third quarter of 2015 really being the beginning of, I'll call it, the post-ACA era, where the bulk of the ACA impact had already been realized, et cetera, I mean, if you look at our acute care revenue growth in those 4 or 5 quarters subsequent to that, we've been pretty consistently posting again at least that sort of 6% revenue growth, which has kind of been split pretty evenly between volume and price. And in fact, in many quarters, including this most recent quarter, we've been exceeding that. 
So yes. I mean, I think our confidence level that we can continue -- that, that level of growth for our facilities in our markets is sustainable is a reasonable one. It's not sort of pie in the sky. We've been posting those numbers. And we don't see anything on the horizon that really threatens that. 
The comments I was making about payer mix was that the government payer mix seems to be sort of moving in sort of lockstep with our overall growth. Commercial growth has slowed some. Uninsured growth has increased some. I think that's a reflection of some of the premium increases and exchange disenrollment that others have mentioned and that people have been talking about. I think that's been factored into our numbers. And again, I think that's already reflected in the growth that we've been able to achieve. So again, I wouldn't say we have 100% confidence level, but we're pretty confident in the sustainable level of our acute care revenue growth.

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then on the pricing side, so the volumes were strong. You alluded to the 6%. With the mix shifting, it seems like a little bit at least from commercial to Medicare and the shift in the commercial itself to lower-priced sites of service. Is that kind o
componenttext: And then on the pricing side, so the volumes were strong. You alluded to the 6%. With the mix shifting, it seems like a little bit at least from commercial to Medicare and the shift in the commercial itself to lower-priced sites of service. Is that kind of pricing growth as well sustainable? And what is the outlook finally on your managed care contracts and all of that put together on pricing?

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Right. So just to be clear, the 6% was overall revenue growth. And that was split pretty evenly between volume and price. And if you look at it, revenue per admission in the third quarter for adjusted admission increased by 3%. Yes, look, I think that is
componenttext: Right. So just to be clear, the 6% was overall revenue growth. And that was split pretty evenly between volume and price. And if you look at it, revenue per admission in the third quarter for adjusted admission increased by 3%. Yes, look, I think that is based on acute care commercial pricing growth in the 4% to 6% range. And I think we've been hitting those numbers pretty comfortably and don't see that changing dramatically anytime soon.

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then finally, since acute is doing so well at this point, you had said, I think, at some point that you were at the table on discussions of smaller hospital chains and so on going -- coming up for sale. Are you making more aggressive attempts to grow
componenttext: And then finally, since acute is doing so well at this point, you had said, I think, at some point that you were at the table on discussions of smaller hospital chains and so on going -- coming up for sale. Are you making more aggressive attempts to grow in the acute side, given your strength?

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think our development folks would say that they're already making a lot of aggressive attempts. I think we would -- we've been anxious and have been looking for opportunities to grow the acute care business and find well-positioned, not-for-profit hospi
componenttext:
I think our development folks would say that they're already making a lot of aggressive attempts. I think we would -- we've been anxious and have been looking for opportunities to grow the acute care business and find well-positioned, not-for-profit hospitals particularly that are for sale. And again, I mentioned in my remarks it was a relatively small acquisition, but we did the Desert View acquisition in the greater Las Vegas market this quarter. And even though it's small, I think we feel like it was an important sort of component of our overall strategy in Las Vegas and we continue to look for those opportunities. 
So yes, I mean, we remain bullish on both of these businesses and their long-term prospects. And as I was saying again, I think in my remarks to A.J. about capital deployment, we'll continue to deploy capital in both businesses where it makes sense and where we can convince ourselves that an adequate return can be earned.

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: The next question will come from Whit Mayo with Robert Baird.
componenttext: The next question will come from Whit Mayo with Robert Baird.

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Steve, if memory serves me, you have a behavioral contract management business buried inside...
componenttext: Steve, if memory serves me, you have a behavioral contract management business buried inside...

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Can you speak up?
componenttext: Can you speak up?

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sorry. Steve, I was just asking about Horizon Health, the behavioral contract management business that you have. That was an organization that had a lot of pricing pressure over the years. And so just wondering if you're trying to leverage the infrastruct
componenttext: Sorry. Steve, I was just asking about Horizon Health, the behavioral contract management business that you have. That was an organization that had a lot of pricing pressure over the years. And so just wondering if you're trying to leverage the infrastructure with Horizon as you pursue joint ventures and other transactions with hospitals and what the pricing has been within that industry and is that business really helpful as you pursue these conversations?

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. So just a tiny bit of context here. I mean, Horizon was a stand-alone public company that was in the business of managing behavioral units for acute care hospitals. They were acquired a number of years ago by PSI. And then obviously we acquired Hori
componenttext:
Sure. So just a tiny bit of context here. I mean, Horizon was a stand-alone public company that was in the business of managing behavioral units for acute care hospitals. They were acquired a number of years ago by PSI. And then obviously we acquired Horizon as part of the PSI acquisition. And we continue to run that Horizon business and they continue to have, I'm doing this off the top of my head, but something like 100 of these contracts around the country where they're managing behavioral units for acute care hospitals. 
The upside of that business is somewhat limited because basically, for the most part, they're just earning a management fee and they're really not able to generally share in the economics of the units that they're running. But we certainly are using that Horizon sort of foundation, if you will, as a base to talk to both their existing clients as well as their prospects. They certainly have had a robust business development sort of function for years that is very helpful because they really -- what they have focused on are these acute care hospital behavioral units. And so as we can -- our focus expands to those businesses, the Horizon knowledge and database is quite useful. 
So yes, I mean, we're leveraging that platform to effectively, I think, create a newer business model that allows us to participate in more of the economics of those acute care behavioral businesses. But yes, having Horizon is certainly a helpful dynamic.

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got it. And maybe one last one, just remind us of the start-up cost that you anticipate with the opening of Henderson and the time frame to break even?
componenttext: Got it. And maybe one last one, just remind us of the start-up cost that you anticipate with the opening of Henderson and the time frame to break even?

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. I mean, we talked about at the beginning of the year and embedded in our guidance was the fact that we would -- there would probably be about a $10 million EBITDA drag in the back half of the year from both a preopening and a start-up loss perspecti
componenttext: Sure. I mean, we talked about at the beginning of the year and embedded in our guidance was the fact that we would -- there would probably be about a $10 million EBITDA drag in the back half of the year from both a preopening and a start-up loss perspective at Henderson. We had a $2 million or $3 million drag in the third quarter, which sort of implies a $7 million or $8 million drag in the fourth quarter. And I think those numbers are still largely good. Again, I mean, we'll be more precise when we give our 2017 guidance. But we certainly think that Henderson will become EBITDA-positive for the full year of 2017. But we'll give more details of that at the end of the fourth quarter.

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: The next question will come from Kevin Fischbeck with Bank of America.
componenttext: The next question will come from Kevin Fischbeck with Bank of America.

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: So I guess going back to another question, I guess you said you feel comfortable about the growth rate being sustainable on the acute care side of the business. How do you feel about margins? I was a little bit surprised by the margin pressure that we've
componenttext: So I guess going back to another question, I guess you said you feel comfortable about the growth rate being sustainable on the acute care side of the business. How do you feel about margins? I was a little bit surprised by the margin pressure that we've seen. Is this the right way to think about margins over the long term? Or do you see upside or downside to that to get -- what's the normal margin to think about over time?

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: So I think, Kevin, what I said was that our original guidance for 2016 was that acute care revenue would grow by about 6% same-store and that margins or EBITDA would grow by 7% to 8%, which means that margins would expand at least somewhat. And I think if
componenttext: So I think, Kevin, what I said was that our original guidance for 2016 was that acute care revenue would grow by about 6% same-store and that margins or EBITDA would grow by 7% to 8%, which means that margins would expand at least somewhat. And I think if you go back and you look not just at this quarter but at the last 4 or 5 quarters, you will see that we're doing both of those things. We're growing revenue by at least 6% and we are expanding margins. It is, and I can see this, it is somewhat choppy, it's somewhat volatile. There are some quarters where there's margin contraction, et cetera. But I think over that period of time we've been able to achieve those metrics. And I think our point of view is that going forward we'll continue to be able to achieve those metrics.

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. So you think that over the next several years margins should be, on average, higher than where they are today in the acute care business?
componenttext: Okay. So you think that over the next several years margins should be, on average, higher than where they are today in the acute care business?

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Certainly as long as revenue growth continues at a level of 6% or so, I think we believe that over time margins will continue to expand.
componenttext: Certainly as long as revenue growth continues at a level of 6% or so, I think we believe that over time margins will continue to expand.

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then moving to the IMD. I guess when we think about the opportunity, obviously there's an opportunity to talk to the 1,200 hospitals. Well, I guess, when you talk about JVs, are you talking about doing a JV with 1 of the 1,200 hospitals that has
componenttext: Okay. And then moving to the IMD. I guess when we think about the opportunity, obviously there's an opportunity to talk to the 1,200 hospitals. Well, I guess, when you talk about JVs, are you talking about doing a JV with 1 of the 1,200 hospitals that has a unit already and moving it out? Or are you talking to the 3,800 hospitals that don't even have a capability and building something from scratch? Because it seems like the 3,800 is the bigger opportunity of trying to collect that volume. How do you think about that?

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I think the way to think about it is the 3,800 acute care hospitals that don't have a behavioral unit have some sort of relationship today where they're sending their adult Medicaid patients and, quite frankly, any of their psych patients generally
componenttext: Well, I think the way to think about it is the 3,800 acute care hospitals that don't have a behavioral unit have some sort of relationship today where they're sending their adult Medicaid patients and, quite frankly, any of their psych patients generally to another acute care hospital, certainly the adult Medicaid patients. We may be getting some of their other patients. And so I think, yes, I think our point of view is that the way to penetrate that adult Medicaid business is to go where those patients are being treated today, and that is in the 1,200 or so acute hospitals that have a behavioral unit. We certainly are having conversations with those other hospitals. And honestly, I think we've been having conversations with them all along about referring patients from their EDs to our behavioral units, where we live in a market with them.

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: And so I guess when you -- do you see any potential threat to your ED, acute care ED volume that comes with psych if those patients now can go to a freestanding facility? Do you think that your acute care hospital volumes could be redirected to a freestan
componenttext: And so I guess when you -- do you see any potential threat to your ED, acute care ED volume that comes with psych if those patients now can go to a freestanding facility? Do you think that your acute care hospital volumes could be redirected to a freestanding facility now? Is that an offset? Or how do you think about that as a potential offset to IMD?

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, I mean, look, I think, first of all, we only have a relatively small number of our acute hospitals that have an existing behavioral unit. And I think for the most part, again, acute care hospitals control where their patients go. And so I don't think
componenttext: No, I mean, look, I think, first of all, we only have a relatively small number of our acute hospitals that have an existing behavioral unit. And I think for the most part, again, acute care hospitals control where their patients go. And so I don't think freestanding hospitals can just sort of snap their fingers and redirect patients. I think the acute hospital is still in the position of being able to control their own patients, which is why I think we're most focused on this collaborative effort to work with acute care hospitals to penetrate that behavioral business. So no, I don't think we see an offset from the loss of IMD business on our acute side of the business.

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. Because it just seemed to me that they can steer where those volumes go. They might not want to send it to a competitor in the acute care business. They had to before because they had no other option, but now they might say, "Okay, we now have anoth
componenttext: Okay. Because it just seemed to me that they can steer where those volumes go. They might not want to send it to a competitor in the acute care business. They had to before because they had no other option, but now they might say, "Okay, we now have another option" and that they would steer it away. But you're not hearing that or seeing that yet?

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: No.
componenttext: No.

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: And there are no further questions.
componenttext: And there are no further questions.

headline: Universal Health Services Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. We thank everybody for their time and look forward to speaking with everybody at the end of the fourth quarter.
componenttext: Okay. We thank everybody for their time and look forward to speaking with everybody at the end of the fourth quarter.
